{{for|the Liberal Party politician|J. Batty Langley}} '''Batty Langley''' (''baptised'' 14 September 1696 – 3 March 1751) was an [[England|English]] [[garden designer]], and prolific writer who produced a number of engraved designs for "[[Gothic Revival architecture|Gothick]]" structures, summerhouses and garden seats in the years before the mid-18th century. An eccentric [[landscape designer]], he gave four of his sons the names [[Hiram (disambiguation)|Hiram]], [[Euclid]], [[Vitruvius]] and [[Archimedes]]. He published extensively, and attempted to "improve" [[Gothic art|Gothic]] forms by giving them classical proportions. [[File:BattyLangleygarden.jpg|thumb|right|250px|A garden plan]] ==Early life== Langley was baptised in [[Twickenham]], Middlesex, the son of a jobbing gardener Daniel Langley and his wife Elizabeth. He bore the name of David Batty, one of his fathers' patrons. He started worked as a gardener, inheriting some of his father's clients in Twickenham, then a village of suburban [[villa]]s within easy reach of London by a pleasant water journey on the [[River Thames|Thames]]. An early client was [[Thomas Vernon (1666-1726)|Thomas Vernon]] of [[Twickenham Park]]. He married Anne Smith in February 1719. They had four children, but she died in June 1726. He had ten further children with his second wife, Catherine. ==Landscape gardening== Langley moved into surveying and [[landscape gardening]]. He published his first book, ''Practical Geometry'', in 1726. Inspired by [[Stephen Switzer|Switzer]]'s ''Ichnographia Rustica'' of 1718, Langley advocated more irregular, informal gardens, with rococo "arti-natural" landscaping. His sinuous forms predated Hogath's [[line of beauty]]. For the [[Palladian architecture|Palladian]] house built at Twickenham by [[James Johnston (Secretary of State)|James Johnston]] in 1710 (later "Orleans House", demolished 1926), Langley, probably on his own endeavour, prepared and published a garden plan, which offered an encyclopaedia of the garden features that were swiftly becoming obsolete by the time the plan (''illustration, right'') was published in Langley's ''A Sure Method of Improving Estates'' (1728): here are several [[maze]]s, a "wilderness" with many tortuous path-turnings, ''cabinets de verdure'' cut into dense woodland, formal stretches of canal and formally shaped basins of water, some with central fountains, a central [[Avenue (landscape)|allée]] of trees leading to an [[exedra]]. His ''New Principles of Gardening'' (1728) included designs for mazes, a feature he could never quite leave behind, with 28 plates engraved by his brother Thomas. He also published ''A Sure Method of Improving Estates'' (1728) and ''Pomona'' (1729). He also undertook work at [[Castle Howard]] and [[Wrest Park]]. ==Architecture== Langley moved from Twickenham to London in 1729, and shifted again from landscape gardening to architecture. Working near [[Exeter Change]] in the Strand, he published ''A Sure Guide to Builders'' in 1729. He moved to Westminster in the 1730s, where he started to teach drawing, geometry, architecture, and garden design, and continued to teach when he moved to Soho in 1738. He also made and sold stone garden ornaments. Despite his literary aspirations, and advertisements in architectural journals, he secured few commissions, submitting an unsolicited proposal for the competition to design a new [[Mansion House, London|Mansion House]] in 1735 and a design for a new [[Westminster Bridge]] in 1736-7. He inclined strongly towards a home-grown English architectural form, publishing articles in the [[Grub Street Journal]] under the pseudonym "Hiram" from July 1734 to March 1735, praising [[Gothic architecture]] (or as he termed it "native Saxon") and rejecting the "imported" [[Palladian architecture]] favoured by [[Lord Burlington]] and his circle. He published a wide range of architectural books, from a huge folio on ''Ancient Masonry'' in parts from 1733 to 1736 with over 450 plates, through ''The Builder's Complete Assistant'' of 1738 (also known as ''The Builder's Complete Chest-Book'') and ''The Builder's Jewel'' of 1741, to the tiny ''The Workman's Golden Rule'' in 1750, in vicesimo-quarto. He is best known for one of his confident self-promotions, ''Ancient Architecture, Restored, and Improved'' published in 1742 and reissued in 1747 as ''Gothic Architecture, improved by Rules and Proportions'', a bit of cockscombry that thoroughly irritated [[Horace Walpole, 4th Earl of Orford|Horace Walpole]], whose Gothick villa at Twickenham, [[Strawberry Hill House|Strawberry Hill]], gave impetus to the stirrings of the [[Gothic Revival]]:
All that his books achieved, has been to teach carpenters to massacre that venerable species, and to give occasion to those who know nothing of the matter, and who mistake his clumsy efforts for real imitations, to censure the productions of our ancestors, whose bold and beautiful fabrics Sir [[Christopher Wren]] viewed and reviewed with astonishment, and never mentioned without esteem. (Walpole, ''Anecdotes of Painting'', 1798, p 484)
His book, with engravings by his brother [[Thomas Langley]], attempted to improve Gothic forms by giving them classical proportions and to create a scheme of architectural orders for Gothic architecture. He provided inspiration for elements of buildings from [[Great Fulford]] and [[Hartland Abbey]] in Devon, to [[Speedwell Castle]] in [[Brewood]] in Staffordshire, and [[Tissington Hall]] in Derbyshire, and the Gothic temple at [[Bramham Park]] in Yorkshire, and gates at [[Castletown House]] in County Kildare. Langley's books were also enormously influential in Britain's American colonies. At [[Mount Vernon]], for example, [[George Washington]] relied upon plate 51 of Langley's ''The City and Country Builder's and Workman's Treasury of Designs'' as the source for the famous Venetian (or Palladian) window in the dining room; upon plate 54 of the same book for the ocular window on Mount Vernon's western facade; and upon plate 75 of Langley's ''The Builder's Jewel'' for the rusticated wood siding.[[The Center for Palladian Studies in America, Inc.]], [http://www.palladiancenter.org/patternbooks.html "Palladio and Architectural Patternbooks in Colonial America."] Batty Langley was also thought to be an important [[Freemason]]; his naming of his son Hiram was a reference to the architect, prominent in Masonic tradition and symbolism, of Solomon's Temple, and many of his books were dedicated to his Masonic brethren. The ''frontispiece'' to ''The Builder's Jewel'' (1741), for example, contains many examples of Masonic symbolism found in the first three degrees of Freemasonry.See Eileen Harris, ''Batty Langley: A Tutor to Freemasons (1696-1751)'', ''The Burlington Magazine'', Vol.119, No 890, May 1977 He was imprisoned for debt in [[Newgate Prison]] and wrote an account of that institution, ''An Accurate Description of Newgate''.[https://books.google.com/books?id=IahbAAAAQAAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false An Accurate Description of Newgate at Google Books] He died at home in Soho.{{cite web|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/16022|title=‘Langley, Batty (bap. 1696, d. 1751)|last=Harris|first=Eileen|year=2004|work=[[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]]|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|doi=10.1093/ref:odnb/16022|accessdate=2009-10-11}} {{ODNBsub}} ==References== {{wikisource|Langley, Batty (DNB00)}} {{reflist}} * [http://www.twickenham-museum.org.uk/detail.asp?ContentID=29 The Twickenham Museum:] Batty Langley * [http://www.library.rochester.edu/index.cfm?PAGE=3573 University of Rochester Book of the Month: Batty Langley, ''New Principles of Gardening'', 1728]. Harry Boller and Clyde Chivens were engineers with degrees from [[California Institute of Technology]]. See Oral History Transcript - Dr. Ira Bowen, August 26, 1969, at [http://www.aip.org/history/ohilist/4524_2.html]. (Chivens was in the Class of 1935. See Clyde Chivens obituary, ''The Tribune'', San Luis Obispo, Ca, March 4, 2008. See also California Institute of Technology, ''Engineering and Science'', "News of Classes," Volume 1:4, March 1938, at [http://calteches.library.caltech.edu/317/1/newsofclasses.pdf]. Chivens worked in the [[Office of Scientific Research and Development]] during World War II. See Folder 2.9 containing OSRD report by Chivens in Guide to the Joseph Foladare Papers, 1943-1946 at [http://www.oac.cdlib.org/data/13030/wd/tf1m3n97wd/files/tf1m3n97wd.pdf].) Harry Boller and Clyde Chivens were also associated in a firm called High Vacuum Electronics (later called Kilovac, now part of [[Tyco Electronics]]), incorporated in California in 1964. See articles of incorporation at [http://www.secinfo.com/dsvRs.717d.b.htm]. A photo of Chivens (left), Boller (center) and Baker-Nunn camera co-developer [[Joseph Nunn]] (right) may be viewed at {{cite web |url=http://home.europa.com/~telscope/B&C/Baker.Nunn.1st.Clyde.Chivens.Harry.Boller.Joseph.Nunn.300dpi.jpg |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-12-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110617015403/http://home.europa.com/~telscope/B%26C/Baker.Nunn.1st.Clyde.Chivens.Harry.Boller.Joseph.Nunn.300dpi.jpg |archivedate=2011-06-17 |df= }}. Birth and death dates from [http://ssdi.rootsweb.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/ssdi.cgi Social Security Death Index.] the company was acquired in 1965 by [[PerkinElmer|Perkin-Elmer]].[https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/courant/access/924555702.html?dids=924555702:924555702&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Mar+04%2C+1965&author=&pub=Hartford+Courant&desc=Perkin-Elmer+Buys+California+Corporation&pqatl=google "Perkin-Elmer Buys California Corporation," ''Hartford Courant'', Hartford, CT, March 4, 1965, p. 38.] In the 1950s, Boller and Chivens collaborated with Perkin-Elmer to develop and manufacture the large-aperture [[Baker-Nunn camera|Baker-Nunn satellite tracking camera]] for the United States [[Project Vanguard|Vanguard]] space satellite program.[https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4202/chapter9.html NASA, ''Vanguard: A History'', Chapter 9, "The Tracking Systems" (see note 17).] ==In culture== A 41-cm (16-inch) Boller and Chivens [[Cassegrain reflector]] originally housed at the [[Harvard–Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics|Harvard-Smithsonian]] [[Oak Ridge Observatory]] in Massachusetts is available for public use at the [[National Air and Space Museum]]'s Public Observatory Project on the [[National Mall]] in Washington, DC.[http://blog.nasm.si.edu/2009/03/29/international-year-of-astronomy-public-observatory-project-at-the-national-air-and-space-museum NASM AirSpace Blog, March 29, 2009.] and [http://www.nasm.si.edu/exhibitions/POPobservatory.cfm NASM Public Observatory Project] ==Notes and references== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.bollerandchivens.com www.bollerandchivens.com]: a site by former employee Don Winans documenting the products made by Boller and Chivens. {{Infobox person | name = Brahim Zniber | image = Brahim Zniber.jpg | image_size = | caption = Brahim Zniber in 2013 | birth_name = | birth_date = 1920 | birth_place = [[Salé]], Morocco | death_date = {{death date and age|2016|9|29|1920}} | death_place = [[Meknès]], Morocco | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | nationality = | other_names = | known_for = | education = | alma mater = | employer = | occupation = Businessman | title = | salary = | networth = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse = [[Rita Maria Zniber]] | children = [[Leyth Zniber]] | parents = Taher Zniber | relatives = }} '''Brahim Zniber''' (1920–2016) was a Moroccan businessman. Through Diana Holding, he was the founder and the owner of [[Celliers de Meknès]], the largest wine producer in Morocco, and owned 85% of the country's wine production. From the 1970s onward, he expanded into fruit and poultry production, and [[Coca-Cola]] bottling plants.
==Early life== Brahim Zniber was born in 1920 in [[Salé]], Morocco.<ref name="forbesnsehedeath">{{cite news|last1=Nsehe|first1=Mfonobong|title=Moroccan Multi-millionaire Brahim Zniber Dies at 96|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/mfonobongnsehe/2016/10/01/moroccan-multi-millionaire-brahim-zniber-dies-at-96/#59c279ac37f1|accessdate=October 2, 2016|work=Forbes|date=October 1, 2016}}</ref> He grew up in [[Sidi Kacem]], then known as Petit Jean.<ref name="telquelobit">{{cite news|title=Le milliardaire Brahim Zniber s’est éteint|url=https://telquel.ma/2016/09/30/brahim-zniber-nest_1516709|accessdate=October 1, 2016|work=[[TelQuel]]|date=September 30, 2016}}</ref> His father, [[Taher Zniber]], was a cereal and wool merchant who was active in the [[Koutla]] political coalition.<ref name="telquelobit"/> He had five brothers and four sisters.<ref name="telquelobit"/>
Zniber studied [[arboriculture]] and [[viticulture]] remotely, taking courses at the Ecole universitaire de Paris.<ref name="telquelobit"/> While he was a student, he became a nationalist activist, serving under [[Mehdi Ben Barka]].<ref name="telquelobit"/> He hid in a remote location near Meknes to flee persecution.<ref name="telquelobit"/>
==Career== Zniber began his career in wine-making in 1956, when he purchased 740 hectares in [[Ait Harz Allah]].<ref name="telquelobit"/> Meanwhile, he joined the board of directors of the regional chapter of the [[Crédit agricole du Maroc]].<ref name="telquelobit"/> By 1958, he founded the Union marocaine de l’agriculture, a trade organization for Moroccan agriculture.<ref name="telquelobit"/>
Zniber was granted 1,100 hectares by King [[Hassan II of Morocco|Hassan II]] in 1958, as French settlers were deprived of their landholdings in the wake of Morocco's independence.<ref name="telquelobit"/><ref name="decestv5monde">{{cite news|title=Décès du "premier vigneron" du Maroc, le millionnaire Brahim Zniber|url=http://information.tv5monde.com/en-continu/deces-du-premier-vigneron-du-maroc-le-millionnaire-brahim-zniber-131327|accessdate=October 1, 2016|work=TV5Monde|date=September 30, 2016}}</ref><ref name="ftmoroccosatlasmountainsseek">{{cite news|last1=Lindsey|first1=Ursula|title=Morocco’s Atlas Mountains seek place on winemaking map|url=https://www.ft.com/content/0daacbf4-cb48-11e5-a8ef-ea66e967dd44|accessdate=October 1, 2016|work=Financial Times|date=March 23, 2016}}</ref> By 1964, he founded Samavin,<ref name="telquelobit"/> later known as Celliers de Meknès.<ref name="decestv5monde"/> He was responsible for the growth of the wine industry in the [[Meknès Prefecture]] and [[Benslimane Province]] from the 1960s onwards.<ref name="bonte145">{{cite journal|last1=Bonte|first1=Marie|title=Ethiques et pratiques éthyliques en milieu urbain marocain|journal=Confluences Méditerranée|date=2011|volume=3|issue=78|pages=145–156|doi=10.3917/come.078.0145|url=http://www.cairn.info/article.php?ID_ARTICLE=COME_078_0145&DocId=162800&hits=771+770+710+709+|accessdate=October 1, 2016|via=[[Cairn.info]]|registration=yes}}</ref> [[File:Château Roslane.JPG|thumb|right|[[Château Roslane]], owned by Zniber]]
Zniber served as a member of the [[House of Representatives (Morocco)|House of Representatives]] in the 1970s.<ref name="telquelobit"/> Meanwhile, he began to grow citrus fruits, apples, apricots, pears, almonds and pistachios.<ref name="telquelobit"/> He acquired a poultry factory in 1975.<ref name="decestv5monde"/> Six years later, in 1981, he acquired Ebertec, a wine production distribution company with two subsidiaries, Thalvin and MR. Renouvo.<ref name="telquelobit"/> Additionally, he invested in two bottling plants for [[Coca-Cola]], one in [[Tangier]] and the other one in [[Oujda]].<ref name="telquelobit"/> He founded Diana Holding in 1986.<ref name="decestv5monde"/><ref name="forbes5moroccanmultmillionaires">{{cite news|last1=Nsehe|first1=Mfonobong|title=5 Moroccan Multi-Millionaires You Should Know|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/mfonobongnsehe/2014/05/03/5-moroccan-multi-millionaires-you-should-know/#3d88ec0371ef|accessdate=October 1, 2016|work=Forbes|date=March 3, 2014}}</ref> In 2005, he established the first "[[appellation d'origine contrôlée]]" in Morocco, known as Les Coteaux de L’Atlas.<ref name="telquelobit"/><ref name="ftmoroccosatlasmountainsseek"/>
By 2014, Zniber was the owner of 2,000 hectares of vineyards near Meknes through Celliers de Meknès, and he sold 35 million bottles every year, making him the largest wine producer in Morocco.<ref name="forbes5moroccanmultmillionaires"/> His flagship vineyard was [[Château Roslane]].<ref name="ftmoroccosatlasmountainsseek"/> His holding company, Diana Holding, had a payroll of 8,000 and annual sales of US$3 billion.<ref name="forbes5moroccanmultmillionaires"/> His investments included the production of [[olive oil]] under the brandname of [[CaracTerre]] and wine via Celliers de Meknès as well as "meat processing and commercial [[Plant nursery|nurseries]]".<ref name="forbes5moroccanmultmillionaires"/>
By 2016, Zniber owned 85% of Morocco's wine production,<ref name="decestv5monde"/> and 8,300 hectares.<ref name="telquelobit"/> Diana Holding was the seventh largest privately owned company in Morocco.<ref name="decestv5monde"/> His main competitor was [[Groupe Castel]].<ref name="bonte145"/>
==Personal life and death== Zniber was married to [[Rita Maria Zniber]].<ref name="forbesmideastthemostpowerful">{{cite news|title=The Most Powerful Arab Women 2015: #30 Rita Maria Zniber|url=http://www.forbesmiddleeast.com/en/lists/people/pname/rita-maria-zniber/pid/86381/|accessdate=October 1, 2016|work=Forbes Middle East|date=April 12, 2015}}</ref> They had a son, [[Leyth Zniber]], who founded [[Eiréné]], an investment fund, in 2014.<ref name="challengelanceunfonds">{{cite news|title=Leyth Zniber lance un fonds d’investissement|url=http://www.challenge.ma/leyth-zniber-lance-un-fonds-dinvestissement-27108/|accessdate=October 1, 2016|work=Challenge|date=May 27, 2014}}</ref>
Zniber died on September 29, 2016 in [[Meknès]], Morocco at the age of 96.<ref name="telquelobit"/><ref name="decestv5monde"/> He received a [[Muslim funeral]] on October 1st and was buried in Meknès.<ref name="forbesnsehedeath"/>

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2014}} {{Use British English|date=January 2014}} '''Celia Kitzinger''' and '''Sue Wilkinson''' are a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[lesbian]] couple who lobbied to have their relationship recognised as a [[marriage]] in [[England]]. ==Celia Kitzinger== Kitzinger is [[Professor]] of Conversation Analysis, Gender and Sexuality in the Department of Sociology at the [[University of York]]. She has a career in academia, having published nine books and contributed over one hundred articles relating to [[language]], [[feminism]] and [[Homosexuality|homosexual]] issues. Kitzinger earned a [[Master of Arts (Oxford, Cambridge and Dublin)|MA]] degree from the [[University of Oxford]] and a PhD from the [[University of Reading]]. After having served from 1999–2000 as [[Visiting scholar|Visiting Professor]] at the [[University of California, Los Angeles|University of California at Los Angeles]], she accepted her current post at York. Kitzinger is also qualified as being a chartered [[psychologist]] within the [[British Psychological Society]], of which she was elected [[fellow]] in 1997. Furthermore, the [[American Psychological Association]] has also honoured her by accepting her as fellow in 2000. Currently, Professor Kitzinger is using [[conversation analysis]] to explore the ordinary mundane reproduction of [[heterosexism]] in everyday talk-in-interaction, and aside from her work at the University of York she also serves as associate editor of ''[[Feminism & Psychology]]''. ==Sue Wilkinson== Wilkinson is Professor of Feminist and Health Studies in the Department of Social Sciences at [[Loughborough University]] in [[Leicestershire]]. Wilkinson completed her undergraduate studies at the [[University of Leicester]], graduating with a [[Bachelor of Science|BSc]] degree in psychology. From there, she proceeded to earn a PhD specialising in gender issues, particularly regarding the role of women in psychology. Wilkinson's first academic post was as a lecturer at the [[University of Liverpool]]; following this she took position as Head of the Psychology department at [[Coventry University]]. After Coventry, Wilkinson accepted a research post at the [[University of Hull]], then left this post to accept a Visiting Professorship at the [[University of Waikato]]. After this position in 1999, Wilkinson was granted a full professorship at Loughborough, having been associated with the university since 1994. Despite this, Professor Wilkinson decided to accept a sabbatical between 2001 and 2002; she spent this year firstly working at the [[University of California, Santa Barbara]], and then serving as a visiting scholar at the University of California, Los Angeles. The following year she took special leave to take chair as the Ruth Wynn Woodward Endowed Professor of Women's Studies at [[Simon Fraser University]], [[Canada]]. It was whilst in Canada that Professor Kitzinger and Professor Wilkinson decided to marry. Wilkinson has received great recognition as an accomplished academic,{{Citation needed|date=June 2010}} and has a strong involvement with the British Psychological Society, being instrumental in the foundation of its ''Psychology of Women'' section, for which she served as the first head, and also its ''Lesbian and Gay Psychology'' section. Wilkinson is currently{{When|date=June 2010}} researching the expression of emotions in talk-in-interaction, as part of her role at Loughborough. Wilkinson has co-authored four books with Kitzinger, and serves as the editor of the academic journal ''Feminism & Psychology''.{{Cite journal | last1 = Wilkinson | first1 = Sue | title = Making connections: Feminism & Psychology and the BPS 'psychology of women' section (editorial) | journal = [[Feminism & Psychology]] | volume = 6 | issue = 4 | pages = 477–480 | publisher = [[SAGE Publications|Sage]] | doi = 10.1177/0959353596064001 | date = November 1996 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1177/0959353596064001 | ref = harv| postscript = .}} ==Marriage status== {{Infobox court case | name = Wilkinson v Kitzinger | court = [[High Court of Justice|High Court of Justice
Family Division]] | image = Royal Coat of Arms of the United Kingdom.svg | imagesize = 100px | caption = | full name = | date decided = 31 July 2006 | citations = [2006] EWHC 2022 (Fam)
[2006] H.R.L.R. 36 | transcripts = | judges = [[Mark Potter (judge)|Potter P]] | prior actions = | subsequent actions = | opinions = | keywords = | italic title = no }} The couple married in [[Yaletown]], [[Vancouver]], in August 2003, a few weeks after [[Same-sex marriage in British Columbia|same-sex marriage]] became legal in [[British Columbia]], where Wilkinson had been working as a Visiting Professor at Simon Fraser University. On their return to the UK, the couple discovered that their relationship had no legal status at all. Two years later, with the implementation of the [[Civil Partnership Act 2004|Civil Partnership Act]], the relationship was automatically converted to a [[civil partnership]]. The couple sued for the recognition of their marriage, the trial beginning on 5 June 2006 before Sir [[Mark Potter (judge)|Mark Potter]], [[President of the Family Division]]. For an overseas marriage to be recognised in the UK, it must be shown that the marriage was legal, recognised in the country in which it was executed, and that nothing in the country's law restricted freedom to marry; Kitzinger and Wilkinson argued that their marriage fulfilled these requirements even though people cannot legally enter into same-sex marriages in the UK. They rejected entering a civil partnership, believing them to be both symbolically and practically a lesser substitute, and asked the court to recognise their overseas marriage in the same way that it would recognise the marriage of an opposite-sex couple. They argued that a failure to do so breached their [[human rights]] under Articles 8 (right to respect for privacy and family life), 12 (right to marry) and 14 (prohibition of discrimination), taken together with Article 8 and/or 12 of the [[European Convention on Human Rights]], which was incorporated into domestic UK law by the [[Human Rights Act 1998]]. In a 21 September 2005 press release issued by [[Liberty (pressure group)|Liberty]],[http://www.equalmarriagerights.org/PressReleases.html Liberty: Press Releases - equalmarriagerights.org] the British [[civil rights]] organisation which supported their case, Kitzinger and Wilkinson said:
This is fundamentally about equality. We want our marriage to be recognised as a marriage - just like any other marriage made in Canada. It is insulting and discriminatory to be offered a civil partnership instead. Civil partnerships are an important step forward for same-sex couples, but they are not enough. We want full equality in marriage.
James Welch, Legal Director at Liberty, said:
Our clients entered into a legal marriage in Canada. It is a matter of fairness and equality that they should be treated the same way as any other couple who marries abroad: their marriage should be recognised here. They shouldn't have to settle for the second-best option of a civil partnership.
The [[High Court of Justice|High Court]] announced its judgement on 31 July 2006, finding that the marriage would continue to be recognised as a civil partnership in England and Wales, but not as a marriage.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/north_yorkshire/5230708.stm BBC News: Lesbians lose legal marriage bid] In handing down his ruling, the President of the Family Division, Sir Mark Potter, gave as his reason that "Abiding single sex relationships are in no way inferior, nor does English Law suggest that they are by according them recognition under the name of civil partnership"[http://news.bbc.co.uk/player/nol/newsid_5230000/newsid_5230800/5230826.stm?bw=bb&mp=wm&news=1&ms3=6&ms_javascript=true&bbcws=2 BBC News: Lesbians lose legal marriage bid (video)] and that marriage was an "age-old institution" which, he suggested, was by "longstanding definition and acceptance" a relationship between a man and a woman. He described this as an "insurmountable hurdle" to the couple's case. While agreeing that they were discriminated against by the [[Civil Partnership Act 2004]], he considered that "To the extent that by reason of that distinction it discriminates against same-sex partners, such discrimination has a legitimate aim, is reasonable and proportionate, and falls within the margin of appreciation accorded to Convention States."[http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWHC/Fam/2006/2022.html Wilkinson v Kitzinger & Ors [2006] EWHC 2022 (Fam) (31 July 2006)], paragraph 122 The Attorney General, as Second Respondent, sought £25,000 in costs. The couple announced their intention to appeal against the decision of the High Court, but later abandoned this due to lack of funds. On 13 March 2014, their overseas marriage was recognised by the Government as a legal marriage as the [[Marriage (Same Sex Couples) Act 2013]] came into force.[https://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/mar/13/gay-couple-wed-overseas-same-sex-marriages-england The Guardian: Gay couple who wed overseas celebrate in UK as same-sex marriage law arrives] ==See also== *[[Same-sex marriage in the United Kingdom]] *''[[Obergefell v. '''Christian Jacob Protten''' also '''Christian Jakobus Africanus Protten''' or '''Uldrich''' (15 September 1715 – 24 August or 23 October 1769) was a [[Gold Coast Euro-Africans|Euro-African]] [[Moravian Church|Moravian]] missionary pioneer, linguist, translator and educationalist-administrator in [[Osu, Accra|Christiansborg]] on the [[Danish Gold Coast]] in the eighteenth century.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://dacb.org/stories/ghana/protten-cj/|title=Christian Jacob Protten|last=Smith|first=Noel|date=|website=dacb.org|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-14}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://dacb.org/stories/ghana/protten-chrisjacob/|title=Christian Jacob Protten|last=Dreydoppel|first=Otto|date=|website=dacb.org|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-14}}</ref><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Simonsen|first=Gunvor|date=April 2015|title=Belonging in Africa: Frederik Svane and Christian Protten on the Gold Coast in the Eighteenth Century|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/itinerario/article/belonging-in-africa-frederik-svane-and-christian-protten-on-the-gold-coast-in-the-eighteenth-century/FD50A3811C421A5A91D9B1E2F7613BEA|journal=Itinerario|language=en|volume=39|issue=1|pages=91–115|doi=10.1017/S0165115315000145|issn=0165-1153|via=|access-date=14 October 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180618045639/https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/itinerario/article/belonging-in-africa-frederik-svane-and-christian-protten-on-the-gold-coast-in-the-eighteenth-century/FD50A3811C421A5A91D9B1E2F7613BEA|archive-date=18 June 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=A History of Moravian Missions|last=Hutton|first=J. E.|publisher=|year=1923|isbn=|location=London|pages=}}</ref><ref name=":5" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sthweb.bu.edu/stories/ghana/protten_chrisjacob.html|title=Protten, Christian Jacob, Ghana, Moravian Church|website=sthweb.bu.edu|access-date=2018-10-25}}</ref><ref name=":9">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oQ8BFk9K0ToC&pg=PA550&lpg=PA550&dq=christian+jacob+protten&source=bl&ots=_8_9kLoAf2&sig=O6nN0lWLQAG4rLEL6k3mDIJBoeU&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjp9cP_9q7eAhWHq1kKHcRsBOsQ6AEwD3oECAMQAQ#v=onepage&q=christian%20jacob%20protten&f=false|title=Biographical Dictionary of Christian Missions|last=Anderson|first=Gerald H.|date=1999|publisher=Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing|isbn=9780802846808|language=en}}</ref> The first recorded grammatical treatise in the [[Ga language|Ga]] and [[Fante language|Fante]] languages were written by Protten and published in [[Copenhagen]] in 1764.<ref name=":3" /><ref>{{Cite book|title=H. W. Debrunner. “Anfaenge Evangelischer Missionarbeit auf der Goldkueste bis 1828,” Evangelisches Missions Magazin|last=Debrunner|first=Hans Werner|publisher=|year=1954|isbn=|location=Basel|pages=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Ein Blatt aus der Geschichte der Brudermission|last=Steiner|first=P.|publisher=|year=1888|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite book|title="En nyttig Grammaticalsk Indledelse til Tvende hidintil gandske ubekiendte Sprog, Fanteisk og Acraisk,"|last=Protten|first=Christian Jacob|publisher=|year=1764|isbn=|location=Copenhagen|pages=}}</ref>
== Early life == === Ancestry and family === Christian Jacob Protten was born on 15 September 1715 in Christiansborg, Gold Coast, now known as the suburb of [[Osu, Accra]] in Ghana.<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=https://www.geni.com/people/Christian-Jakobus-Protten/6000000016682022141|title=Christian Jakobus Protten|website=geni_family_tree|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-14}}</ref><ref name=":9" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://aner.svaner.com/Svane_om/Svane_DK/Famous_persons/Africanus_dk.htm|title=Belonging in Africa: Frederik Svane and Christian Protten on the Gold Coast in the Eighteenth Century|last=|first=|date=|website=aner.svaner.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-14}}</ref> His Danish father, Jacob Protten, alias "Prot", "Prodt", "Prott," was a soldier stationed with the garrison at the Christiansborg Castle in Osu.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":5" /> His [[Ga-Adangbe people|Ga]] mother of [[Togo|Togolese]] ancestry, was a princess and the daughter of a chief or king, Nii Ofori Ashangmo, the ruler of the Ga state from 1660 to 1680.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":5" /> Historical records list his mother’s name simply by her initials, “N. N.”.<ref name=":5" /> Protten had two older siblings: a brother, Wilhelm or Friderich Protten (born 28 April 1709) and a sister, Anna Protten (born 2 February, 1713), both raised in Christiansborg.<ref name=":5" /> Archival records indicate that Christian Protten’s maternal uncle, Ashangmo, also Foli Bebe or Ofori Bembeneen was a coastal chieftain in the former Portuguese slave market of [[Aného|Little Popo]] (Aného) in modern-day Togo, and ruled the Guin/Ge State there from 1694 to 1727 or 1731/33.<ref name=":5" /> After the passing of Ashangmo, his son, Assiongbon Dandjin became the new ruler at Aneho sometime between 1731/33 and 1737. Christian Protten appears to have been a candidate for succession but only matrilineally.
=== Education === Christian Protten’s early education was at the Danish language-[[Osu Castle|Christiansborg Castle School]] for mulattoes, where he was tutored by a [[Lutheranism|Lutheran]] minister.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=June 2012|title=This Month in Moravian History: Christian Protten - Missionary to the Gold Coast of Africa|url=http://www.moravianchurcharchives.org/thismonth/12_06%20Protten.pdf|journal=Moravian Archives|location=Bethlehem, PA.|volume=|issue=74|pages=|via=|access-date=14 October 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160914181657/http://www.moravianchurcharchives.org/thismonth/12_06%20Protten.pdf|archive-date=14 September 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> With the confines of the fort, Protten was introduced to [[Christianity]] and mastered the [[Danish language]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6" /> In 1726, at the age of 11, he was chosen and sent to Copenhagen, Denmark, together with another Euro-African pupil, Friederich Pedersen.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6" /><ref>{{Cite book|title=Tribute for the Negro|last=Wilson|first=Armistead|publisher=|year=1848|isbn=|location=Manchester|pages=}}</ref> Protten recalled that the decision to send him to a school in Denmark was against his will.<ref name=":6" /> His mother's family was also against this development. On the day of his departure, as he was rowed out to the waiting ship, his relatives stood on the beach, hoping the canoe would capsize and Protten would return to safety on the shore. At the age of 12, [[Frederick IV of Denmark|King Frederick IV of Denmark]] (reigned 1699–1730) took interest in his welfare and became his godfather at his baptism on 27 November, 1727.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6" /> After his baptism, he assumed the name Christian Jacob Protten. Protten then enrolled in a trade apprenticeship to become a [[blacksmith]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6" /> Initially, he was disheartened to partake in the vocational training as he desired a more academic education.<ref name=":6" /> In 1732, he finally matriculated at the [[University of Copenhagen]] where he studied [[theology]], completing his studies in 1735 at the age of twenty.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6" />
== Work == === Teaching and Christian mission === [[File:CJ Protten.png|thumb|250px|left|Christian Jacob Protten]] In 1735, Christian Protten met [[Nicolaus Zinzendorf|Nikolaus Ludwig, Reichsgraf von Zinzendorf und Pottendorf]] (1700–60), the Bishop of the [[Moravian Church]], at the Danish court.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dietrich|first=Meyer,|title=Lieberkühn, Samuel|url=https://referenceworks.brillonline.com/entries/religion-past-and-present/lieberkuhn-samuel-SIM_13018|language=en}}</ref> Shortly thereafter, he became acquainted with the Moravian fellowship and moved to [[Herrnhut]], the Moravian colony at [[Berthelsdorf|Berthelsdolf]], which later became Saxony, staying there for the next twelve months and learning German along the way.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6" /> Protten was deeply unhappy in Germany, noting in his diary that that Europeans described him as “''afrikanisch wild''” (African savage) and “''mohrisch''” (Moorish).<ref name=":6" /><ref>{{Cite book|title=Manuscript: Diarium of/by Christian Jakob Protten Africanus (1715-1769)|last=|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> In 1737, Christian Protten, along with Moravia native, Henry Huckoff, sailed from [[Amsterdam]], the [[Netherlands]] to the Gold Coast to begin a new life as Moravian missionaries..<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6" /> Commenting on Protten’s perceived conceitedness, Zinzendorf wrote, ''“Protten has a high opinion of himself. Presumptiveness and a high opinion of oneself only prostitute a person and carry no weight with the Saviour''.”<ref name=":6" /> He was alleged to have been prone to fits of uncontrollable anger. Prior his departure to the Gold Coast, Count Zinzendorf instructed, ''“Dear Christian: In order to convert the Moors, you must leave all your Moorish bad habits in Amsterdam.”'' <ref name=":6" /> Despite these negative remarks before his departure, Protten was nonetheless tasked with establishing a school for Euro-African children in [[Elmina]]. The ship docked at Elmina on 11 May 1737.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6" /> Henry Huckuff passed away, presumably from fever, a month after their arrival. This new situation resulted in a change in plans for Protten who ended up visiting his mother in Little Popo/Aného, [[Togo]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6" /> According to the Gold Coast historian and Basel Mission pastor, [[Carl Christian Reindorf]], Protten visited his relatives at [[Aného]] in September 1737. He was reportedly kept there against his will and only returned to Osu in 1739.
His plans to start a school at Elmina were thwarted by the Dutch Governor at the time, [[List of colonial governors of the Dutch Gold Coast|Martinus François de Bordes]] who viewed Protten as a Danish spy and detained him for three years until 1740.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6" /> de Bordes died in office on 16 March 1740. The political situation at the time was unfavourable as the Dutch had waged a war against the [[Dahomey|Dahomey.]]<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6" /> During Protten’s imprisonment in Elmina, he was infected with [[malaria]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6" /> Upon his release, he served as an educator for a year. In 1741, upon the receipt of a letter of invitation from von Zinzendorf, Christian Protten returned to Herrnhut, after failing to win converts on the Gold Coast..<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6" /> In 1743, he sailed to the island of [[Saint Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands|Saint Thomas]] in the [[West Indies]] as an independent missionary..<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6" /> While in the Caribbean, he remained detached from other missionaries there.<ref name=":6" /> He returned to Germany in 1745 with the aim of going back to the Gold Coast.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6" /> However, the Moravian leaders were not in favour of that proposal, although homesick Protten was desperate to return to his homeland.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6" /> He therefore remained in the Moravian communities for the next decade.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6" />
There were constant tensions between Zinzendorf and Protten due to the latter’s alcoholism and alleged haughtiness.<ref name=":6" /> In 1756, Protten and his wife, Rebecca were banished from the Moravian commune in Herrnhut to the village of [[Großhennersdorf]] in the [[Görlitz]] district.<ref name=":6" /> He received permission to return to West Africa, leaving his wife, who rejoined the religious community at Herrnhut.<ref name=":6" />
In 1757, he received his commission from the Royal Chartered Danish West India and [[Guinea Company (London)|Guinea Company]] to become a teacher and a preacher at his alma mater, the Christiansborg Castle School.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6" /> As the vessel approached the West African coast, it landed on the [[Pepper Coast|Grain Coast]] (now [[Liberia]]) where he stayed for almost four months.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6" /> He arrived in Christiansborg in June 1757 and reconnected with his family.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6" /> He returned to Europe in July 1761, arriving in Herrnhut in 1762; he reunited with his wife and the other Moravians.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6" /> This particular journey occurred after the death of a [[Gold Coast Euro-Africans|Euro-African]] pupil, who Protten had accidentally shot while cleaning his rifle at the castle. Christian Protten was briefly imprisoned for this incident.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6" /> In 1765, he returned to the Gold Coast with his wife, Rebecca. With the blessing of the Moravian church, he became the schoolmaster of the castle school until his death in 1769.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6" /> Earlier in 1764, he had submitted a proposal to the Danish Crown, [[Frederick V of Denmark|King Frederick V of Denmark]] (reigned 1746-66), to establish a boarding school at Christiansborg which would include a curriculum in indigenous languages, highlighting the importance he attached to literacy in his mother tongue.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6" />
Historians have concluded that his education and mission initiatives on the Gold Coast were essentially failed projects. His last years in Christiansborg seem to have been troubled. In the final decades of the 18th century, several other Moravian missionaries who were sent from Europe did not survive beyond the first few months due to tropical afflictions, particularly malaria and yellow fever.<ref name=":6" />
=== Foray into linguistics === In 1764, Christian Jacob Protten wrote his [[Masterpiece|magnum opus]], "''En nyttig Grammaticalsk Indledelse til Tvende hidintil gandske ubekiendte Sprog, Fanteisk og Acraisk''," an introductory treatise to the grammar of the [[Ga language|Ga]] and [[Fante dialect|Fante]] languages which was published in [[Copenhagen]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6" /> Seen as his greatest achievement, the text acted as trilingual (Danish, Fante, Ga) catechesis manual for European missionaries who yearned to learn the two Ghanaian native languages. Furthermore, Protten translated [[Martin Luther]]’s ''Smaller Catechism'' into the Fante and Ga languages..<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6" />
== Selected writings == * '''Protten, Christian Jacob''' (1764), "''En nyttig Grammaticalsk Indledelse til Tvende hidintil gandske ubekiendte Sprog, Fanteisk og Acraisk''," Copenhagen [A Useful Grammatical Introduction to the Ga and Fante languages]<ref name=":4" />
== Personal life == [[File:Rebecca Freundlich.png|thumb|125px|Rebecca Freundlich Protten]] On 6 June 1746, he married [[Rebecca Protten|Rebecca Freundlich]] (1718–1780) in Herrnhut, Germany.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6" /> Freundlich was also known as “Shelly”, a mulatress and a former slave from the [[Caribbean]] who was the widow of a Moravian missionary, Matthäus Freundlich (c. 1681-c. 1742).<ref name=":7">{{Cite web|url=https://www.geni.com/people/Rebecca-Protten-Freundlich/6000000016682046341|title=Rebecca Protten Freundlich|website=geni_family_tree|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-14}}</ref><ref name=":8">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dhM7mdH62UoC&printsec=frontcover&dq=rebecca's+revival&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwim4NqjnPrdAhXGm-AKHeRDCJYQ6AEIJzAA#v=onepage&q=rebecca's%20revival&f=false|title=Rebecca's Revival|last=Sensbach|first=Jon F.|date=2009-06-30|publisher=Harvard University Press|isbn=9780674043459|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tcFAr0vaBxEC&printsec=frontcover&dq=rebecca's+revival&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwim4NqjnPrdAhXGm-AKHeRDCJYQ6AEILTAB#v=onepage&q=rebecca's%20revival&f=false|title=Rebecca's Revival|last=Sensbach|first=Jon F.|date=2006|publisher=Harvard University Press|isbn=9780674022577|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.com/Rebeccas-Revival-Creating-Christianity-Atlantic/dp/0674022572|title=Rebecca's Revival: Creating Black Christianity in the Atlantic World|last=results|first=search|date=2006-10-31|publisher=Harvard University Press|isbn=9780674022577|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts London, England|language=English|access-date=14 October 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160102085441/http://www.amazon.com/Rebeccas-Revival-Creating-Christianity-Atlantic/dp/0674022572|archive-date=2 January 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Rebecca Freundlich was born on the island of [[Antigua]] in [[Antigua and Barbuda]]. Rebecca Freundlich had an arranged marriage to Matthaus Freundlich.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thegospelcoalition.org/article/meet-mother-of-modern-missions/|title=Meet the Mother of Modern Missions|work=The Gospel Coalition|access-date=2018-10-14|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171031230704/https://www.thegospelcoalition.org/article/meet-mother-of-modern-missions|archive-date=31 October 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hup.harvard.edu/catalog.php?isbn=9780674022577|title=Rebecca's Revival — Jon F. Sensbach {{!}} Harvard University Press|website=www.hup.harvard.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-10-14|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180916075019/http://www.hup.harvard.edu/catalog.php?isbn=9780674022577|archive-date=16 September 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.h-net.org/reviews/showrev.php?id=11031|title=Review of Sensbach, Jon F., Rebecca's Revival: Creating Black Christianity in the Atlantic World|last=Sasser|first=Daryl|date=December 2005|website=www.h-net.org|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://khronikosum.wordpress.com/2013/05/09/the-limits-of-rebeccas-revival/|title=The Limits of Rebecca’s Revival|date=2013-05-09|work=khronikos: the blog|access-date=2018-10-14|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.librarything.com/character/Rebecca+Protten|title=Rebecca Protten {{!}} People/Characters {{!}} LibraryThing|website=www.librarything.com|access-date=2018-10-14}}</ref> They were married on 4 May 1738. The Freundlichs were persecuted and imprisoned for their Christian faith while they were sharing the Gospel to slaves in Saint Thomas.<ref name=":8" /> Rebecca Freundlich had a daughter, Anna Maria Freundlich, from her first marriage, who was born circa 1740, on the island of Saint Thomas, now the US Virgin Islands.<ref name=":7" /><ref name=":8" /> Anna Freundlich died in 1744, aged 4 years, in Germany.<ref name=":7" /><ref name=":8" /> The Freundlich family had travelled to Germany due to Matthaus Freundlich’s ill-health.<ref name=":7" /><ref name=":8" /> He however died during the voyage across Germany.<ref name=":7" /> In 1750, Christian and Rebecca Protten had a daughter, Anna Maria Protten who died in infancy in Herrnhut, [[Dresden]] in [[Sachsen]], Germany.<ref name=":5" />
== Death and legacy == Christian Jacob Protten died in 1769 in Christiansborg, Accra, leaving his wife, Rebecca, widowed for a second time. She had not fully acclimatised to the Gold Coast and the Moravian missionaries contemplated sending her back to Saint Thomas. As she was in poor health, it was decided she remained on the Gold Coast, where she eventually died in 1780, aged 62 years.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":7" /><ref name=":8" /> The appendix to Protten’s booklet was the first published grammar of an indigenous language of the Gold Coast.<ref name=":6" /> His linguistic work in the Ga language predated that of the German philologist and Basel missionary, [[Johannes Zimmermann]] (1825–1876) by a century. Zimmerman also translated the entire [[Bible]] into the Ga language.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RLZrAAAAIAAJ&q=Hans+Werner+Debrunner&dq=Hans+Werner+Debrunner&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwitlqb19N3bAhURvVMKHVUzC4oQ6AEIJzAA|title=A history of Christianity in Ghana|last=Debrunner|first=Hans Werner|date=1967|publisher=Waterville Pub. House|language=en|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180620152019/https://books.google.com/books?id=RLZrAAAAIAAJ&q=Hans+Werner+Debrunner&dq=Hans+Werner+Debrunner&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwitlqb19N3bAhURvVMKHVUzC4oQ6AEIJzAA|archivedate=20 June 2018|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.com/history-Christianity-Ghana-Hans-Debrunner/dp/B0006CO3YQ|title=A history of Christianity in Ghana,|last=Debrunner|first=Hans W.|date=1967|publisher=Waterville Pub. House|language=English|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130703222956/http://www.amazon.com/history-Christianity-Ghana-Hans-Debrunner/dp/B0006CO3YQ|archivedate=3 July 2013|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://openlibrary.org/books/OL4877755M/A_history_of_Christianity_in_Ghana|title=A history of Christianity in Ghana|last=Debrunner|first=Hans W.|date=1967|publisher=Waterville Pub. S.|publisher=|year=1971|isbn=|location=Tema|pages=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Geschichte der Basler Mission, 1815-1915, ("History of the Basel Mission, 1815-1915")|last=Schlater|first=Wilhelm|publisher=|year=1916|isbn=|location=Basel|pages=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=The Presbyterian Church of Ghana 1835-1960|last=Smith|first=Noel|publisher=|year=1966|isbn=|location=Accra|pages=}}</ref> In effect, his grammatical output was an example for both Zimmermann and the Basel Mission pastor and historian, [[Carl Christian Reindorf]] (1834–1917), whose literary masterpiece, The History of the Gold Coast and Asante was written in the Ga and English languages and published in 1895 in Basel.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bzNGAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=history+of+the+gold+coast+and+asante&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjl3_SjtobeAhXudN8KHQO6DtYQ6AEIJzAA#v=onepage&q=history%20of%20the%20gold%20coast%20and%20asante&f=false|title=History of the Gold Coast and Asante, Based on Traditions and Historical Facts: Comprising a Period of More Than Three Centuries from about 1500 to 1860|last=Reindorf|first=Carl Christian|date=1895|publisher=The author|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QvYNswEACAAJ&dq=history+of+the+gold+coast+and+asante&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjl3_SjtobeAhXudN8KHQO6DtYQ6AEILTAB|title=History of the Gold Coast and Asante (Classic Reprint)|last=Reindorf|first=Carl Christian|date=2018-04-21|publisher=LULU Press|isbn=9781330819852|language=en}}</ref> Moreover, as a mulatto or an Atlantic [[Creole peoples|Creole]], Protten was able to hone his linguistic talents and abilities by blending his African upbringing and his European education, through a spatial awareness of the missionary settings he lived in the 1700s.<ref name=":3" />
