revision.text:
'''[[Silvio Berlusconi]]''' is an Italian [[media mogul]] and former [[Prime Minister of Italy]] who owns the largest broadcasting company in that country, [[Mediaset]]. His promises to buy off his personal assets to avoid [[conflict of interest|conflicts of interest]] were never fulfilled, which sparked controversy throughout his terms in office. Berlusconi is a controversial figure in modern Italian politics: his tenure as Prime Minister was racked with scandalous sex affairs and poor judgement and decision-making. These events were widely covered by the media, drawing outcry from many of his Italian contemporaries and worldwide counterparts.
==Controversies==
===Economic conflicts of interest=== According to journalists [[Marco Travaglio]] and [[Enzo Biagi]], Berlusconi entered politics to save his companies from bankruptcy and himself from [[conviction (law)|convictions]].<ref name=inciucio>{{Cite book |last1= Travaglio |first1= Marco |authorlink1= Marco Travaglio |last2= Gomez |first2= Peter |title = Inciucio |publisher=RCS MediaGroup |year = 2005 |isbn = 88-17-01020-0}}</ref> From the very beginning he said it clearly to his associates. Berlusconi's supporters hailed him as the "[[novus homo]]", an outsider who was going to bring a new efficiency to the public [[bureaucracy]] and reform the state from top to bottom.
While investigating these matters, three journalists noted the following facts: * [[Mediobanca]]'s annual report about the 10 biggest Italian companies showed that, in 1992, Berlusconi's media and finance group [[Fininvest]] had about 7,140 billion [[Italian lira|lire]] of [[debt]]s, 8,193 billion lire of [[asset]]s (with 35% of liquidity) and a [[net worth]] of 1,053 billion lire. The asset-debt ratio represented a patrimonial situation bordering on bankruptcy.{{Citation needed|date=July 2008}} * Between 1992 and 1993, [[Fininvest]] was investigated several times by [[prosecutor]]s in Milan, Turin and Rome. The investigations regarded: alleged bribes (to political parties and public officials with the aim of getting contracts), alleged fake invoicing by Publitalia, the financing of political congresses and abuse of television frequencies. * On the other hand, [[Bruno Vespa]] noticed that "In January 1994, Silvio Berlusconi was under no proceedings. Two members of the staff from the Ministry of the Finances were charged to be corrupted for a minor episode by a Fininvest manager, but the accusation would have later fallen. [[Aldo Brancher]], who was working with Fininvest at the time, was charged for having financed some stands at the "[[Festa de l'Unità|Feste dell'Unità]]" and "[[L'Avanti!]]", and he would have been declared fully not guilty only in 2004. [[Paolo Berlusconi]] [Silvio Berlusconi's brother] was instead arrested [...] after the Cavaliere went into politics." After having decided to enter the political arena, Berlusconi was investigated for forty different inquests in less than two years.<ref>{{Cite book |last1= Vespa |first1= Bruno |authorlink1= Bruno Vespa |title = Storia d'Italia da Mussolini a Berlusconi |publisher=[[RAI|Rai Eri]] – [[Arnoldo Mondadori Editore|Mondadori]] |year = 2004}}</ref>
Controversy concerning Berlusconi's 'conflicts of interest' are usually centered around the use of his media and marketing power for political gain. However, there is also controversy regarding his financial gains. When RAI was being run by a two-man team appointed by the presidents of the Chamber of Deputies and the Senate (both in Berlusconi's coalition), the state broadcaster increased its viewers, but lost a significant share of its advertising revenue to the rival Mediaset group, owned and run by the Berlusconi family, which has led to large personal gain. {{Citation needed|date=April 2008}}
Berlusconi's governments has passed some laws that have shortened statutory terms for tax fraud. Romano Prodi, who defeated Berlusconi in 2006, claimed that these were ''ad personam laws,'' meant to solve Berlusconi's problems and defend his interests.<ref name="No alle leggi ad personam">{{cite web|url=http://ricerca.repubblica.it/repubblica/archivio/repubblica/2002/08/05/no-alle-leggi-ad-personam.html|title=No alle leggi ad personam|language=Italian|work=la Repubblica|date=5 August 2002}}</ref><ref name="Intini: no alle leggi ad personam">{{cite web|url=http://ricerca.repubblica.it/repubblica/archivio/repubblica/2003/05/05/intini-no-alle-leggi-ad-personam.html|title=Intini: no alle leggi ad personam|language=Italian|work=la Repubblica|date=5 May 2003}}</ref><ref name="Via le leggi ad personam">{{cite web|url=http://ricerca.repubblica.it/repubblica/archivio/repubblica/2006/05/27/via-le-leggi-ad-personam.html|title=Via le leggi ad personam|language=Italian|work=la Repubblica|date=27 May 2006}}</ref><ref name="Berlusconi getta la maschera">{{cite web|url=http://tv.repubblica.it/home_page.php?playmode=player&cont_id=21342&ref=search |title=Berlusconi getta la maschera |language=Italian |publisher=[[Repubblica Radio TV]] |date=17 June 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111003060011/http://tv.repubblica.it/home_page.php?playmode=player&cont_id=21342&ref=search |archivedate=October 3, 2011 }}</ref>
===Relationship with media===
====Media control and conflict of interest==== Berlusconi's extensive control over the media has been widely criticised by some analysts,<ref>{{cite book|last=Hine|first=David|authorlink=David Hine|title=Silvio Berlusconi, i media e il conflitto di interesse|publisher=Il Mulino|year=2002|pages=291–307}}</ref> some press freedom organisations, and extensively on several Italian newspapers, national and private TV channels by opposition leaders and in general opposition parties members, who allege Italy's media has [[Freedom of the press in Italy|limited freedom of expression]]. However such coverage of the complaint in practice put under discussion the point of the complaint itself. The ''Freedom of the Press 2004 Global Survey'', an annual study issued by the American organisation [[Freedom House]], downgraded Italy's ranking from 'Free' to 'Partly Free'<ref name="Ref_l">{{cite web |url=http://www.freedomhouse.org/media/pressrel/042804.htm |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20040503211418/http://www.freedomhouse.org/media/pressrel/042804.htm |archivedate=3 May 2004 |title=Global Press Freedom Deteriorates – Proportion of Global Population With Access to Free Media Plunges to New Low Italy Drops to "Partly Free"}}</ref> due to Berlusconi's influence over RAI, a ranking which, in "Western Europe" was shared only with Turkey ({{As of|2005|lc=on}}). [[Reporters Without Borders]] states that in 2004, "The conflict of interests involving prime minister Silvio Berlusconi and his vast media empire was still not resolved and continued to threaten news diversity".<ref name="Ref_m">{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/article.php3?id_article=10148 |title=Italy – 2004 Annual report |publisher=Reporters Without Borders |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090302045453/http://www.rsf.org/article.php3?id_article=10148 |archivedate=March 2, 2009 }}</ref> In April 2004, the [[International Federation of Journalists]] joined the criticism, objecting to the passage of a law vetoed by [[Carlo Azeglio Ciampi]] in 2003, which critics believe is designed to protect Berlusconi's reported 90% control of the Italian national media.<ref name="strangle">{{cite web |url=http://www.ifj-europe.org/default.asp?index=2451&Language=EN |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040927133724/http://www.ifj-europe.org/default.asp?index=2451&Language=EN |archivedate=27 September 2004 |title=Journalists In New Protest as Berlusconi's Grip on Italian Media Becomes A Stranglehold}}</ref>
Berlusconi owns via [[Mediaset]] 3 of 7 national TV channels: ([[Canale 5]], [[Italia 1]], and [[Rete 4]]). To better understand the controversies over a conflict of interest between Berlusconi's personal business empire and his political office, it is necessary to look at the structure of governmental control over State television.{{According to whom|date=November 2011}} Under the law, the Speakers of the two Houses appoint the [[RAI]] president and board of directors. In practice, the decision is a political one, generally resulting in some opposition representatives becoming directors, while top managerial posts go to people sympathetic to the government. It was normal to have two directors and the president belonging to the parliamentary majority, and two directors who are opposition supporters. A parliamentary supervisory commission also exists, whose president is traditionally a member of the opposition. During the tenure of Mr. Baldassarre as RAI president, the two opposition directors and the one closer to the [[Union of Christian and Centre Democrats]] left over internal disagreements that mainly regarded censorship issues. RAI continued to be run by a two-man team (mockingly nicknamed by the opposition ''the Japanese'' after the [[Japanese holdout|Japanese soldiers who kept fighting on]] in the Pacific Ocean after the end of World War II).{{citation needed|date=November 2011}}
The former Italian center-left coalition of [[Romano Prodi]] was often criticised for failing to pass a law to regulate the potential ''conflict of interest'' that might arise between media ownership and the holding of political office, despite having governed Italy for an entire legislature from 1996 to 2001. In 2002, [[Luciano Violante]], a prominent member of the Left, said in a speech in [[Chamber of Deputies of Italy|Parliament]]: "Honourable Anedda, I invite you to ask the honourable Berlusconi, because he certainly knows that he received a full guarantee in 1994, when the government changed—that TV stations would not be touched. He knows it and the Honourable [[Gianni Letta|Letta]] knows it."<ref name="ReferenceA">[[Luciano Violante]] addressing the [[Chamber of Deputies of Italy]], 28 February 2002)</ref>{{Verify source|date=October 2009}}
The authors of the book ''Inciucio''<ref>{{it icon}} ''Inciucio''. (Peter Gomez and Marco Travaglio, 2005, [[RCS MediaGroup]], {{ISBN|88-17-01020-0}}</ref> cite this sentence as evidence for the idea that the Left made a deal with Berlusconi in 1994, in which a promise was made not to honour a law in the [[Constitutional Court of Italy]] that would have required Berlusconi to give up one of his three TV channels in order to uphold pluralism and competition. According to the authors, this would be an explanation of why the Left, despite having won the 1996 elections, did not pass a law to solve the conflicts of interest between media ownership and politics.
Berlusconi's influence over RAI became evident when in [[Sofia, Bulgaria]] he expressed his views on journalists [[Enzo Biagi]] and [[Michele Santoro]],<ref name="Ref_2002c">{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/article.php3?id_article=3284 |title=Media pluralism more threatened than ever |publisher=Reporters Without Borders |date=6 August 2002 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071205145217/http://www.rsf.org/article.php3?id_article=3284 |archivedate=December 5, 2007 }}</ref> and comedian [[Daniele Luttazzi]]. Berlusconi said that they "use television as a criminal means of communication". They lost their jobs as a result.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Gomez|first1=Peter|last2=Travaglio|first2=Marco|authorlink2=Marco Travaglio|title=Regime|publisher=RCS MediaGroup|year=2004|location=Milan|pages=28–258}}</ref> This statement was called by critics "''[[Editto Bulgaro]]''".
The TV broadcasting of a satirical programme called ''RAIot'' was censored in November 2003 after the comedian [[Sabina Guzzanti]] made outspoken criticism of the Berlusconi media empire.<ref name="Ref_2003">{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/article.php3?id_article=8587 |title=RAI suspends satirical programme after lawsuit by Berlusconi-owned company |publisher=Reporters Without Borders |date=22 November 2003 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071205152755/http://www.rsf.org/article.php3?id_article=8587 |archivedate=December 5, 2007 }}</ref> Mediaset, one of Berlusconi's companies, sued RAI over Guzzanti's program, demanding 20 million euros for "damages"; in November 2003 the show was cancelled by the president of RAI, Lucia Annunziata. The details of the event were made into a [[Michael Moore]]-style documentary called ''[[Viva Zapatero!]]'', which was produced by Guzzanti.
Mediaset, Berlusconi's television group, has stated that it uses the same criteria as the public (state-owned) television [[RAI]] in assigning a proper visibility to all the most important political parties and movements (the so-called 'Par Condicio') – which has been since often disproved.<ref name="Ref_2006">{{cite web|url=http://ricerca.repubblica.it/repubblica/archivio/repubblica/2006/02/15/le-trappole-della-par-condicio.html|title=Le trappole della par condicio|work=la Repubblica|language=Italian|date=15 February 2006}}</ref><ref name="Ref_2002d">{{cite web|url=http://ricerca.repubblica.it/repubblica/archivio/repubblica/2002/05/09/il-bavaglio-del-polo-alla-rai.html|title=Il Bavaglio Del Polo Alla Rai|work=la Repubblica|language=Italian|date=9 May 2002}}</ref> In March 2006, on the television channel [[Rai Tre]], in a television interview with [[Lucia Annunziata]] during his talk show, ''[[In 1/2 h]]'', he stormed out of the studio because of a disagreement with the host journalist regarding the economic consequences of his government.<ref name="Ref_2006a">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/03/12/world/europe/12iht-italy-5839062.html|title=Berlusconi walks off show after a testy exchange |work=International Herald Tribune |date=12 March 2006}}</ref> In November 2007, allegations of news manipulation caused the departure from RAI of Berlusconi's personal assistant.<ref name="Stille2008">{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article5188289.ece|title=Silvio Berlusconi: Yes, yes, yes, Prime Minister|work=The New Yorker /[[The Times]]|date=23 November 2008|location=London|first=Alexander|last=Stille|accessdate=30 March 2010}}</ref>
[[Enrico Mentana]], the news anchor long seen as a guarantor of Canale 5’s independence, walked out in April 2008, saying that he no longer felt “at home in a group that seems like an electoral (campaign) committee”<ref name="Ref_2008d">{{Cite news |url=http://www.economist.com/world/europe/displaystory.cfm?story_id=14560942|title=Muzzling the messengers|work=The Economist |date=1 October 2008| accessdate=12 November 2009}}</ref>
On 24 June 2009, Silvio Berlusconi during the [[Confindustria]] young members congress in [[Santa Margherita Ligure|Santa Margherita Ligure, Italy]] has invited the advertisers to interrupt or boycott the advertising contracts with the magazines and newspapers published by [[Gruppo Editoriale L'Espresso]],<ref name="reuters-0624"/> in particular the ''[[la Repubblica]]'' and the newsmagazine ''[[L'espresso]]'', calling the publishing group "shameless",<ref name="reuters-0624">{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/rbssTechMediaTelecomNews/idUSLO59656320090624|title=L'Espresso calls in lawyers on Berlusconi remarks|publisher=Reuters|date=24 June 2009|accessdate=25 June 2009}}</ref> because is fueling the economic crisis speaking more and more about it and accusing also to make a subversive attack against him to replace with an "un-elected".<ref name="ansa-0624"/> The publishing group has announced to begin legal proceedings against Berlusconi, to protect the image and the interests of the group.<ref name="ansa-0624">{{cite web|url=http://www.ansa.it/site/notizie/awnplus/english/news/2009-06-24_124359124.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090626195319/http://www.ansa.it/site/notizie/awnplus/english/news/2009-06-24_124359124.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=26 June 2009|title=Espresso group to sue Berlusconi|work=[[Agenzia Nazionale Stampa Associata|ANSA]]|date=24 June 2009|accessdate=25 June 2009}} </ref>
On 12 October 2009, Silvio Berlusconi during the [[Confindustria]] [[Province of Monza and Brianza|Monza and Brianza]] members congress, has again invited the industrialists present to a "widespread rebellion" against a "newspaper that hadn't any limits in discrediting the government and the country and indoctrinating foreign newspapers".<ref name="larepubblica-1012">{{cite web|url=http://www.repubblica.it/2009/10/sezioni/politica/giustizia-13/marcegaglia-berlusconi/marcegaglia-berlusconi.html|title=Berlusconi contro Repubblica "Ribellatevi ai giornali anti-italiani"|language=Italian|work=la Repubblica|date=12 October 2009|accessdate=13 October 2009}}</ref>
In October 2009, [[Reporters Without Borders]] secretary-general [[:fr:Jean-François Julliard (Reporters sans frontières)|Jean-François Julliard]] declared that Berlusconi "is on the verge of being added to our list of Predators of Press Freedom", which would be a first for a European leader. He also added that Italy will probably be ranked last in the European Union in the upcoming edition of the RWB [[Reporters Without Borders#Worldwide Press Freedom Index|press freedom index]].<ref name="Ref_n">{{cite web|title=Reporters Without Borders in Rome as Berlusconi gets closer to being declared a "Predator" |url=http://www.rsf.org/spip.php?page=article&id_article=34640 |publisher=[[Reporters Without Borders]] |date= |accessdate=3 October 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100201151726/http://www.rsf.org/spip.php?page=article |archivedate=February 1, 2010 }}</ref>
====''The Economist''==== One of Berlusconi's strongest critics in the media outside Italy is the British weekly ''[[The Economist]]'' (nicknamed by Berlusconi ''"The Ecommunist"''), which in its issue of 26 April 2001 carried a title on its front cover, 'Why Silvio Berlusconi is unfit to lead Italy'.<ref>{{Cite book |last = Ginsborg |first = Paul |title = Italy and Its Discontents |year = 2003 |publisher=Penguin Books |location = London |page = 318 |isbn = }}</ref> The war of words between Berlusconi and ''The Economist'' has gained notoriety, with Berlusconi taking the publication to court in Rome and ''The Economist'' publishing letters against him.<ref name="Ref_j">{{cite web |url=http://www.hebig.org/blogs/archives/main/001105.php |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030817191337/http://www.hebig.org/blogs/archives/main/001105.php |archivedate=17 August 2003 |title=An open letter to Silvio Berlusconi }}</ref> The magazine claimed that the documentation contained in its article proves that Berlusconi is 'unfit' for office<ref name="Ref_2001a">{{Cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/displaystory.cfm?story_id=593654|title=Fit to run Italy?|publisher=Economist|date=26 April 2001}}</ref> because of his numerous conflicts of interest. Berlusconi claimed the article contained "a series of old accusations" that was an "insult to truth and intelligence".
According to ''The Economist'''s findings, Berlusconi, while Prime Minister of Italy, retained effective control of 90% of all national television broadcasting. This figure included stations he owns directly as well as those over which he had indirect control by dint of his position as Prime Minister and his ability to influence the choice of the management bodies of these stations. ''The Economist'' has also claimed that the Italian Prime Minister is corrupt and self-serving. A key journalist for ''The Economist'', David Lane, has set out many of these charges in his book ''Berlusconi's Shadow''.<ref name="shadow">{{Cite book | last = Lane | first = David
| title = Berlusconi's Shadow | year = 2005 | publisher=Penguin Books | location = London | isbn = 0-14-101770-8 }}</ref>
Lane points out that Berlusconi has not defended himself in court against the main charges, but has relied upon political and legal manipulations, most notably by changing the statute of limitation to prevent charges being completed in the first place. In order to publicly prove the truth of the documented accusations contained in their articles, the newspaper has publicly challenged Berlusconi to sue ''The Economist'' for libel. Berlusconi did so,<ref name="Ref_k">{{Cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/media/pdf/20080905122118632.pdf |title=Document from the Milan court of justice |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2 March 2010 |work=The Economist}}</ref> losing versus ''The Economist'', and being charged for all the trial costs on 5 September 2008, when the Court in Milan issued a judgment rejecting all Mr Berlusconi's claims and sentenced him to compensate for legal expenses.
In June 2011, ''The Economist'' published a strong article dealing with Mr. Berlusconi, titled "The Man who screwed an entire country".<ref name=autogenerated1>{{Cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/node/18805327 |title= The man who screwed an entire country|date= |accessdate=2 March 2010 |work=The Economist}}</ref>
===Friendship with Bettino Craxi=== Berlusconi's career as an entrepreneur is also often questioned by his detractors. The allegations made against him generally include suspicions about the extremely fast increase of his activity as a construction entrepreneur in years 1961–63, hinting at the possibility that in those years he received money from unknown and possibly illegal sources. These accusations are regarded by Berlusconi and his supporters as empty [[slander]], trying to undermine Berlusconi's reputation as a self-made man. Also frequently cited by opponents are events dating to the 1980s, including supposed "favour exchanges" between Berlusconi and [[Bettino Craxi]], the former Socialist prime minister and leader of the [[Italian Socialist Party]] convicted in 1994 for various corruption charges. The Milan magistrates who indicted and successfully convicted Mr. Craxi in their "[[Mani pulite|Clean Hands]]" investigation laid bare an entrenched system in which businessmen paid hundreds of millions of dollars to political parties or individual politicians in exchange for sweetheart deals with Italian state companies and the government itself.<ref name="Friedman2000">{{Cite news|work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/01/20/news/20iht-obit.2.t_32.html?scp=2&sq=craxi&st=cse |title=Bettino Craxi, Italian Socialist Leader, Dies in Tunisiader |date=20 January 2000|accessdate=11 November 2009 | first=Alan | last=Friedman}}</ref> Berlusconi acknowledges a personal friendship with Craxi.
===Legislative changes=== On some occasions, which raised a strong upheaval in the Italian political opposition, laws passed by the Berlusconi administration have effectively delayed ongoing trials on him. Relevant examples are the law reducing punishment for all cases of false accounting and the law on ''legitimate suspicion'', which allowed defendants to request their cases to be moved to another court if they believe that the local judges are biased against them.<sup>[[#References|7]], [[#References|8]]</sup> Because of these legislative actions, political opponents accuse Berlusconi of passing these laws for the purpose of protecting himself from legal charges. An enquiry realised by the newspaper ''La Repubblica'' sustained that Berlusconi passed 17 different laws which have advantaged himself;<ref name="Ref_2009f">{{cite web|url=http://www.repubblica.it/2009/11/sezioni/politica/giustizia-18/inchiesta-davanzo/inchiesta-davanzo.html |title=Per Silvio Berlusconi 18 salvacondotti in 15 anni |language=Italian |work=la Repubblica |date=23 November 2009 |accessdate=2 March 2010}}</ref> Berlusconi and his allies, on the other hand, maintain that such laws are consistent with everyone's right to a rapid and just trial, and with the principle of ''presumption of innocence'' (guarantism); furthermore, they claim that Berlusconi is being subjected to a political "witch hunt", orchestrated by certain (allegedly left-wing) judges<sup>[[#References|11]]</sup>.
For such reasons, Berlusconi and his government have an ongoing quarrel with the Italian judiciary, which reached its peak in 2003 when Berlusconi commented to a foreign journalist that judges are "mentally disturbed" and "anthropologically different from the rest of the human race", remarks that he later claimed he meant to be directed to specific judges only, and of a humorous nature<sup>[[#References|12]]</sup>. More seriously, the Berlusconi administration has long been planning a judiciary reform intended to limit the flexibility currently enjoyed by judges and magistrates in their decision-making, but which, according to its critics, will instead limit the magistrature's independence, by ''de facto'' subjecting the judiciary to the executive's control. This reform has met almost unanimous dissent from the Italian judges<sup>[[#References|13]], [[#References|14]]</sup> and, after three years of debate and struggle, was passed by the Italian parliament in December 2004, but was immediately vetoed by the Italian President, [[Carlo Azeglio Ciampi]] <sup>[[#References|15]]</sup>, because of the unconstitutionality of some of the passed laws.
Berlusconi has also been indicted in Spain for charges of tax fraud and violation of anti-trust laws regarding the private television network [[Telecinco]], but his status as a member of the European Parliament allowed him to gain immunity from prosecution until 2005.<sup>[[#References|16]]</sup> All the accused have been [[acquittal|acquitted]] by the Spanish [[Supreme Court of Spain|Supreme Court]] in July 2008.<ref name="Ref_e">[http://www.ansa.it/ansalatina/notizie/rubriche/italia/20080724222034698613.html]{{dead link|date=August 2010}}</ref><ref name="Ref_f">{{cite web|url=http://www.ansa.it/opencms/export/site/notizie/rubriche/daassociare/visualizza_new.html_730968525.html |accessdate=November 14, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080805125339/http://www.ansa.it/opencms/export/site/notizie/rubriche/daassociare/visualizza_new.html_730968525.html |archivedate=August 5, 2008 }}</ref>
During the night hours between 5 and 6 March 2010, the Berlusconi-led Italian government passed a decree ''interpreting'' the electoral law so as to let the PDL candidate run for governor in Lazio after she had failed to properly register for the elections. The Italian Constitution states that electoral procedures can only be changed in Parliament, and must not be changed by governmental decree. Italy's President, whose endorsement of the decree was required by law, said amid much controversy that the measure taken by the government may not violate the Constitution.<ref name="Ref_2010b">{{cite web|url=http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/news/international/Italy_opposition_protest_for_second_day_over_decree.html?cid=8432170 |title=Italy opposition protest for second day over decree |date=7 March 2010 |work=[[swissinfo]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110511210247/http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/news/international/Italy_opposition_protest_for_second_day_over_decree.html?cid=8432170 |archivedate=2011-05-11 |df= }}</ref><ref name="Ref_2010c">{{cite web|url=http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/news/international/Italy_opposition_protests_at_ballot_decree.html?cid=8428120 |title=Italy opposition protests at ballot decree |date=6 March 2010 |work=[[swissinfo]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110511210254/http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/news/international/Italy_opposition_protests_at_ballot_decree.html?cid=8428120 |archivedate=2011-05-11 |df= }}</ref>
===Alleged links to the Mafia=== {{rquote|right| Berlusconi, in order to solve his problems, has to solve ours.|Mafia boss [[Giuseppe Guttadauro]] in a wiretapped conversation.<ref name="Ref_g">[http://www.allvoices.com/s/event-6350957/aHR0cDovL3d3dy5mb3JlaWducG9saWN5LmNvbS9hcnRpY2xlcy8yMDEwLzA3LzE2L21hcnJpZWRfdG9fdGhlX21vYg== Married to the Mob] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707115303/http://www.allvoices.com/s/event-6350957/aHR0cDovL3d3dy5mb3JlaWducG9saWN5LmNvbS9hcnRpY2xlcy8yMDEwLzA3LzE2L21hcnJpZWRfdG9fdGhlX21vYg%3D%3D# |date=2011-07-07 }}, by [[Alexander Stille]], Foreign Policy, 16 July 2010</ref>}} Silvio Berlusconi has never been tried on charges relating to ''[[Cosa Nostra]]'', although several Mafia turncoats have stated that Berlusconi had connections with the Sicilian criminal association. The claims arise mostly from the hiring of [[Vittorio Mangano]], charged for Mafia association, as a gardener and stable-man at Berlusconi's Villa San Martino in [[Arcore]], a small town near Milan. It was Berlusconi's friend [[Marcello Dell'Utri]] who introduced Mangano to Berlusconi in 1973.<ref name=eco260401>[http://www.economist.com/world/displaystory.cfm?story_id=587107 An Italian Story], The Economist, 26 April 2001</ref><ref name=bbc080103>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/2638609.stm Berlusconi accused of Mafia links], BBC News, 8 January 2003</ref> Berlusconi denied any ties to the Mafia. Marcello Dell'Utri even stated that the Mafia did not exist at all.
In 2004 Dell'Utri, co-founder of [[Forza Italia]], was sentenced to nine years by a [[Palermo]] court on charge of "external association to the Mafia",<ref name=bbc080103/><ref name=rep111204>{{cite web|url=http://www.repubblica.it/2004/l/sezioni/politica/dellutri/dellusentenza/dellusentenza.html|title=Accusa e difesa del senatore "M" Una vicenda lunga dieci anni|language=Italian|work=la Repubblica|date=11 December 2004}}</ref> a sentence describing Dell'Utri as a mediator between the economical interests of Berlusconi and members of the criminal organisation. Berlusconi refused to comment on the sentence. In 2010, Palermo's appeals court cut the sentence to seven years but fully confirmed Dell'Utri's role as a link between Berlusconi and the mafia until 1992.<ref name=reu191110>[http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKTRE6AI5D120101119 UK.reuters.com], Reuters UK, 19 November 2010</ref>
In 1996, a Mafia informer, [[Salvatore Cancemi]], declared that Berlusconi and Dell'Utri were in direct contact with [[Salvatore Riina]], head of the [[Sicilian Mafia]] in the 1980s and 90s. Cancemi disclosed that Fininvest, through Marcello Dell'Utri and mafioso [[Vittorio Mangano]], had paid Cosa Nostra 200 million lire (between 100 000 and 200 000 of today's euro) annually. The alleged contacts, according to Cancemi, were to lead to legislation favourable to Cosa Nostra, in particular the harsh 41-bis prison regime. The underlying premise was that Cosa Nostra would support Berlusconi's Forza Italia party in return for political favours.<ref name=gua100501>[https://www.theguardian.com/Archive/Article/0,4273,4183973,00.html Berlusconi friend on trial for 'aiding Mafia'], ''The Guardian'', 10 May 2001</ref> After a two-year investigation, magistrates closed the inquiry without charges. They did not find evidence to corroborate Cancemi’s allegations. Similarly, a two-year investigation, also launched on evidence from Cancemi, into Berlusconi’s alleged association with the Mafia was closed in 1996.<ref name=eco260401/>
According to yet another [[pentito|Mafia turncoat]], [[Antonino Giuffrè]] – arrested on 16 April 2002 – the Mafia turned to Berlusconi's [[Forza Italia]] party to look after the Mafia's interests, after the decline in the early 1990s of the ruling [[Christian Democracy (Italy)|Christian Democrat]] party, whose leaders in Sicily looked after the Mafia's interests in Rome. The Mafia's fall out with the Christian Democrats became clear when [[Salvo Lima]] was killed in March 1992. "The Lima murder marked the end of an era," Giuffrè told the court. "A new era opened with a new political force on the horizon which provided the guarantees that the Christian Democrats were no longer able to deliver. To be clear, that party was Forza Italia."<ref name=gua080103>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2003/jan/08/italy.philipwillan|title=Berlusconi aide 'struck deal with mafia'|work=The Guardian |date=8 January 2003 | location=London | first=Philip | last=Willan | accessdate=30 March 2010}}</ref> Dell'Utri was the go-between on a range of legislative efforts to ease pressure on mafiosi in exchange for electoral support, according to Giuffrè. "Dell'Utri was very close to Cosa Nostra and a very good contact point for Berlusconi," he said.<ref name=obs120103>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2003/jan/12/italy.philipwillan Mafia supergrass fingers Berlusconi], ''The Observer'', 12 January 2003</ref> Mafia boss [[Bernardo Provenzano]] told Giuffrè that they "were in good hands" with Dell'Utri, who was a "serious and trustworthy person". Provenzano stated that the Mafia's judicial problems would be resolved within 10 years after 1992, thanks to the undertakings given by Forza Italia.<ref name=bbc080103/><ref name=gua080103/>
Giuffrè also said that Berlusconi himself used to be in touch with [[Stefano Bontade]], a top Mafia boss, in the mid 1970s. At the time Berlusconi still was just a wealthy real estate developer and started his private television empire. Bontade visited Berlusconi's villa in [[Arcore]] through his contact [[Vittorio Mangano]].<ref name="guardian05122002"/> Berlusconi's lawyer dismissed Giuffrè's testimony as "false" and an attempt to discredit the Prime Minister and his party. Giuffrè said that other Mafia representatives who were in contact with Berlusconi included the Palermo Mafia bosses Filippo Graviano and [[Giuseppe Graviano]].<ref name="Ref_2002a">{{cite web|url=http://www.repubblica.it/online/cronaca/giuffredue/verbale/verbale.html|title=Giuffré: il boss Graviano era il tramite con Berlusconi|language=Italian|work=la Repubblica|date=3 December 2002}}</ref> The Graviano brothers allegedly treated directly with Berlusconi through the business-man [[Gianni Letta]], somewhere between September/October 1993. The alleged pact with the Mafia fell apart in 2002. Cosa Nostra had achieved nothing.<ref name="Ref_2002b">{{cite web|url=http://www.repubblica.it/online/cronaca/giuffredue/patto/patto.html|title=Giuffrè, gli obiettivi della confessione|language=Italian|work=la Repubblica|date=4 December 2002}}</ref>
Dell'Utri's lawyer, Enrico Trantino, dismissed Giuffrè’s allegations as an "anthology of hearsay". He said Giuffrè had perpetuated the trend that every new turncoat would attack Dell'Utri and the former [[Christian Democracy (Italy)|Christian Democrat]] prime minister [[Giulio Andreotti]] in order to earn money and judicial privileges.<ref name="guardian05122002">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2002/dec/05/italy.philipwillan|title=Berlusconi implicated in deal with godfathers|work=The Guardian |date=5 December 2002 | location=London | first=Philip | last=Willan | accessdate=30 March 2010}}</ref>
In October 2009, [[Gaspare Spatuzza]], a Mafioso turned pentito in 2008, has confirmed Giuffrè statements. Spatuzza testified that his boss Giuseppe Graviano had told him in 1994 that Berlusconi was bargaining with the Mafia, concerning a political-electoral agreement between Cosa Nostra and Berlusconi’s Forza Italia. Spatuzza said Graviano disclosed the information to him during a conversation in a bar Graviano owned in the upscale Via Veneto district of the Italian capital Rome. Dell'Utri was the intermediary, according to Spatuzza. Dell'Utri has dismissed Spatuzza's allegations as "nonsense". Berlusconi’s lawyer and MP for the PdL, [[Niccolò Ghedini]] said that "the statements given by Spatuzza about prime minister Berlusconi are baseless and can be in no way verified."<ref name=aki231009>[http://www.adnkronos.com/AKI/English/Politics/?id=3.0.3909367513 Lawyer rejects turncoat's claims linking Berlusconi to mafia], Adnkronos International, 23 October 2009</ref>
===Foreign relations===
====Russia==== [[File:Vladimir Putin 28 May 2002-14.jpg|thumb|right|Berlusconi and [[Vladimir Putin]].]]
Berlusconi has a warm relationship with [[Vladimir Putin]].<ref name="Ref_2008c">{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/0,1518,583212,00.html|title=The Silvio Show: Berlusconi's Extended Honeymoon|work=Der Spiegel |date=10 September 2008}}</ref>
In November 2007 Italy’s state-owned energy company [[Eni]] signed an agreement with Russian state-owned [[Gazprom]] to build the [[South Stream]] pipeline.<ref name="hexagon"/> Investigating Italian parliament members discovered that [[Central Energy Italian Gas Holding]] (CEIGH), a part of the [[Centrex Group]], was to play a major role in the lucrative agreement. [[Bruno Mentasti-Granelli]], a close friend of Berlusconi, owned 33 percent of CEIGH. Italian parliament blocked the contract and accused Berlusconi of having a personal interest in the Eni-Gazprom agreement.<ref name="hexagon">{{cite web|url=http://www.jamestown.org/single/?no_cache=1&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=34194|title=Berlusconi, Centrex, Hexagon 1 and 2 and Gazprom|publisher=[[The Jamestown Foundation]]|date=1 December 2008|access-date=2011-11-14|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120920/http://www.jamestown.org/single/?no_cache=1&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=34194#|archive-date=2012-09-20|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref name="Ref_h">[http://www.kommersant.com/page.asp?id=636565 The Putin and Pals Project] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120920/http://www.kommersant.com/page.asp?id=636565# |date=2012-09-20 }}. Kommersant. 24 December 2005</ref>
On 1 December 2010, Wikileaks leaked American state diplomatic cables showing that American officials voiced concerns over Berlusconi's extraordinary closeness to Putin, "including 'lavish gifts,' lucrative energy contracts and a 'shadowy' Russian-speaking Italian go-between". Diplomats consider him "to be the mouthpiece of Putin" in Europe.<ref name="nyt_cables_2">[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/29/world/29cables.html?pagewanted=2 Cables Obtained by WikiLeaks Shine Light Into Secret Diplomatic Channels – Page 1]; New York Times. Retrieved 28 November 2010.</ref>
According to one of the leaked cables the Georgian ambassador in Rome has told to the American officials that Georgia believes Putin has promised Berlusconi a percentage of profits from any pipelines developed by [[Gazprom]] in coordination with [[Eni S.p.A.]].<ref name="Ref_i">{{Cite web |url=http://213.251.145.96/cable/2009/01/09ROME97.html# |title=Viewing cable 09ROME97, Italy-Russia elations: the view from Rome |access-date=2011-11-14 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101206132718/http://213.251.145.96/cable/2009/01/09ROME97.html# |archive-date=2010-12-06 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
====Belarus==== Berlusconi visited [[Belarus]] and met its authoritarian president [[Alexander Lukashenko]] in 2009. Berlusconi became the first Western leader to visit Lukashenko since the latter came to power in 1994. In the press conference Berlusconi paid compliments to Lukashenko and said "Good luck to you and your people, whom I know love you".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.eubusiness.com/news-eu/belarus-italy.1pq |title=Italy's Berlusconi visit ends Belarus isolation |publisher=EUbusiness |accessdate=22 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402042242/http://www.eubusiness.com/news-eu/belarus-italy.1pq |archivedate=2 April 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Disputed Belarus Vote Shows ‘Love’ for Leader, Berlusconi Says |publisher=Bloomberg |date=30 November 2009 |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aeTaYgPv3vAE}}</ref>
====Libya==== During much of Berlusconi's government Italy gradually reconciled with [[Libya]] of [[Muammar Gaddafi]]. Italy gets a quarter of its [[Petroleum|oil]] and about 10% of its [[Natural gas|gas]] from Libya, and enterprises from both countries have strong interests in the other economy. Berlusconi's [[Call girl|escort girls]] helped Gaddafi to gain the leadership of the [[African Union]] in 2009.<ref>"[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/silvio-berlusconi/8364768/Berlusconi-sent-escorts-to-Gaddafi-opponent-as-favour-to-Libya-leader.html Berlusconi 'sent escorts to Gaddafi opponent as favour to Libya leader']". Telegraph. 6 March 2011</ref> During the first days of the [[2011 Libyan civil war]] Berlusconi was initially cautious, painting Libya not as a military priority but a humanitarian one. In the following days the Italian government condemned the use of violence and suspended the friendship treaty with Libya signed in 2008.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-12612405 |title=Italy and Silvio Berlusconi face Libya dilemma |date=1 March 2011 | publisher=BBC}}</ref>
===Remarks on Western civilisation and Islam=== After the [[11 September 2001 attacks]] in [[New York City|New York]], Berlusconi said: "We must be aware of the superiority of our civilisation, a system that has guaranteed well-being, respect for human rights and – in contrast with Islamic countries – respect for religious and political rights, a system that has as its value understanding of diversity and tolerance."<ref name="Ref_2001b">{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/storm-over-berlusconi--inferior-muslims-remarks-670971.html|title=Storm over Berlusconi 'inferior Muslims' remarks|work=The Independent |location=UK|date=27 September 2001 | accessdate=30 March 2010}}</ref><ref name="Ref_2001c">{{cite web|url=http://www.wsws.org/articles/2001/sep2001/ital-s29.shtml|title=Racist vomit from Italy’s PM Berlusconi|work=[[World Socialist Web Site|WSWS]]|date=29 September 2001}}</ref> This declaration caused an uproar, not only in the Arab and Muslim world, but also all around Europe, including Italy.<ref name="bbc-berlu-islam">{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/1565664.stm|title=EU deplores 'dangerous' Islam jibe|publisher=BBC News|date=27 September 2001}}</ref> Subsequently Berlusconi told the press: "We are aware of the crucial role of moderate Arab countries... I am sorry that words that have been misunderstood have offended the sensitivity of my Arab and Muslim friends."<ref name="Henneberger2001">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/09/29/world/berlusconi-stands-by-remarks-on-islam.html|title=Berlusconi Stands By Remarks on Islam|work=New York Times |date=29 September 2001 | first=Melinda | last=Henneberger | accessdate=30 March 2010}}</ref>
===Right-to-die case=== After the family of [[Eluana Englaro]] (who had been comatose for 17 years) succeeded in having her [[right to die]] recognised by the judges and getting doctors to start the process of allowing her to die in the way established by the court, Berlusconi issued a decree to stop the doctor from letting her die. Stating that, "This is murder. I would be failing to rescue her. I'm not a [[Pontius Pilate]]", Berlusconi went on to defend his decision by claiming that she was "in the condition to have babies",<ref name="Day2008">{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/feb/08/englaro-italy-vatican |work=Guardian |title=Italy faces constitutional crisis over coma woman |date=8 February 2008 | location=London | accessdate=30 March 2010 | first=Michael | last=Day}}</ref> arguing that comatose women were still subject to [[menstruation]]. Critics said that this controversial move had been staged to repair relations with the Vatican, following harsh criticism of the treatment of immigrants by the Berlusconi administration.{{citation needed|date=April 2011}}
===Jokes, gestures, and blunders=== [[File:Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva and Silvio Berlusconi 20080709.jpg|thumb|right|Berlusconi with the President of Brazil [[Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva]]]]
Berlusconi has developed a reputation for making gaffes or insensitive remarks.<ref name=Insensitive>{{cite news|title=Editorial: Touched by Crassness|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/leading_article/article6062638.ece|work=The Times|accessdate=4 October 2011|location=London|first=Mal|last=Siret}}</ref>
On 2 July 2003, Berlusconi suggested that German [[Social Democratic Party of Germany|SPD]] [[Member of the European Parliament|MEP]] [[Martin Schulz]], who had criticised his domestic policies, should play a [[Nazi]] [[concentration camp]] [[Kapo (Arbeitslager)|guard]] in a film.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/3037386.stm |title=Berlusconi in EU 'Nazi' slur |publisher=BBC News |date=2 July 2003 |accessdate=1 November 2011}}</ref> Berlusconi insisted that he was joking, but accused Schulz and others to be "bad-willing tourists of democracy". This incident caused a brief cooling of Italy's relationship with Germany.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ricerca.repubblica.it/repubblica/archivio/repubblica/2003/07/03/berlusconi-lite-strasburgo.html|title=Berlusconi, lite a Strasburgo|work=la Repubblica|language=Italian|date=3 July 2003|accessdate=30 May 2009}}</ref>
Addressing traders at the [[New York Stock Exchange]] in September 2003, Berlusconi listed a series of reasons to invest in Italy, the first of which was that "we have the most beautiful secretaries in the world". This remark resulted in uproar in Italy where female members of parliament took part in a one-day cross-party protest.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/3137406.stm |title=Berlusconi vaunts Italy's secretaries |publisher=BBC News |date=24 September 2003 | accessdate=2 September 2011}}</ref> Berlusconi's list also included the claim that Italy had "fewer communists, and those who are still here deny having been one".<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/italy/5106644/Silvio-Berlusconis-top-10-gaffes-and-pranks.html |title=Silvio Berlusconi's top 10 gaffes and pranks |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=UK |date=4 April 2009 | accessdate=2 September 2011 |first=Nick |last=Squires}}</ref>
In 2003, during an interview with Nicholas Farrell, then editor of ''[[The Spectator]]'', Berlusconi claimed that [[Benito Mussolini|Mussolini]] "had been a benign dictator who did not murder opponents but sent them 'on holiday'".<ref name="Owen2008">{{Cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article3746319.ece|title=Profile: the irrepressible Silvio Berlusconi|work=The Times |date=14 April 2008|accessdate=16 April 2008 | location=London | first=Richard | last=Owen}}</ref>
[[File:Kotipizza Berlusconi.JPG|thumb|left|upright|[[Kotipizza]] ''Pizza Berlusconi'']] Berlusconi had made disparaging remarks about [[Finland|Finnish]] cuisine during negotiations to decide on the location of the [[European Food Safety Authority]] in 2001. He caused further offence in 2005, when he claimed that during the negotiations he had had to "dust off his playboy charms" in order to persuade the Finnish president, [[Tarja Halonen]], to concede that the EFSA should be based in [[Parma]] instead of Finland, and compared Finnish smoked [[reindeer]] unfavourably to [[culatello]]. The Italian [[ambassador]] in [[Helsinki]] was summoned by the Finnish foreign minister.<ref name="Ref_2005a">{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4122596.stm|title='Playboy' Berlusconi irks Finland |publisher=BBC News|date=23 June 2005}}</ref> One of Berlusconi's ministers later 'explained' the comment by saying that "anyone who had seen a picture of Halonen must have been aware that he had been joking". Halonen took the incident in good humour, retorting that Berlusconi had "overestimated his persuasion skills".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://yle.fi/uutiset/news/2010/09/halonen_and_berlusconi_meet_in_rome_1965672.html| title=Halonen and Berlusconi meet in Rome |date=8 September 2010 |publisher=YLE.fi}}</ref> The Finnish pizza chain [[Kotipizza]] responded by launching a variety of pizza called ''Pizza Berlusconi'', using smoked reindeer as the topping. The pizza won first prize in America's Plate International pizza contest in March 2008.<ref name="Ref_t">{{cite web|url=http://www.kotipizza.fi/Suomeksi/Menu/Pizzat |title=Menu of Kotipizza pizza chain, note the Berlusconi pizza |publisher=Kotipizza.fi |date= |accessdate=2 March 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081217031359/http://www.kotipizza.fi/Suomeksi/Menu/Pizzat |archivedate=December 17, 2008 }}</ref><ref name="Ref_u">{{cite web|url=http://www.care2.com/news/go/671026 |accessdate=November 14, 2011 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
In March 2006, Berlusconi alleged that Chinese communists under [[Mao Zedong]] had "boiled [children] to fertilise the fields".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://seattletimes.com/html/nationworld/2002896399_babies29.html |title=Chinese angered by Italian premier's allegation that country boiled babies |author=Maria Sanminiatelli |publisher=Seattle Times |date=29 March 2006 |accessdate=24 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005010136/http://seattletimes.com/html/nationworld/2002896399_babies29.html |archivedate=5 October 2013 |df= }}</ref> His opponent [[Romano Prodi]] criticised Berlusconi for offending the Chinese people and called his comments 'unthinkable'.<ref name="Ref_2006b">{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4857226.stm|title=Berlusconi baby gaffe riles China|publisher=BBC News|date=29 March 2006}}</ref>
In the run-up to the [[Italian general election, 2008|2008 Italian general election]], Berlusconi was angrily accused of [[sexism]] for saying that female politicians from the right were "more beautiful" and that "the left has no taste, even when it comes to women".<ref name="Ref_2008e">{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7338415.stm|title=Berlusconi: Left has uglier women|publisher=BBC News|date=9 April 2008}}</ref> In 2008 Berlusconi criticised the composition of the Council of Ministers of the [[Spanish Government]] as being too 'pink' by virtue of the fact that it has (once the President of the Council, [[José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero]], is counted) an equal number of men and women. He also stated that he doubted that such a composition would be possible in Italy given the "prevalence of men" in Italian politics.<ref name="Ref_2008f">{{cite web|url=http://www.elmundo.es/elmundo/2008/04/15/internacional/1208272351.html|title=Berlusconi 'regaña' a Zapatero: 'Su Gobierno es demasiado rosa'|language=Spanish|work=[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]]|date=15 April 2008}}</ref>
Also in 2008 Berlusconi caused controversy at a joint press conference with [[Russia]]n president [[Vladimir Putin]]. When Russian journalist [[Nezavisimaya Gazeta]] asked a question about Mr. Putin's personal relationships, Berlusconi made a gesture towards the journalist imitating a gunman shooting.<ref name="TVG">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XpNx5-9ZOyQ|title=Berlusconi e Putin in Sardegna — TG3|publisher=YouTube}}</ref><ref name="Ref_2008g">{{cite web|url=http://russiatoday.ru/Top_News/2008-04-20/Berlusconi_to_lobby_EU_on_behalf_of_Russian_travellers.html |title=Berlusconi to lobby EU on behalf of Russian travellers |publisher=[[Russia Today]] |quote=See embedded video |date=20 April 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090627235124/http://russiatoday.ru/Top_News/2008-04-20/Berlusconi_to_lobby_EU_on_behalf_of_Russian_travellers.html |archivedate=2009-06-27 |df= }}</ref>
On 6 November 2008, two days after [[Barack Obama]] was elected the first black US President, Berlusconi referred to Obama as "young, handsome and even tanned":<ref name="Ref_v">{{cite web |title=Berlusconi Obama Suntanned |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ErsgFMFhoPQ |publisher=Repubblica Radio TV |accessdate=22 July 2011}}</ref><ref name="Sisto2008">{{Cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUKTRE4A562120081106|title=Italy's Berlusconi hails "suntanned" Obama|publisher=Reuters|date=6 November 2008 | first=Alberto | last=Sisto}}</ref><ref name="Ref_2008i">{{cite web|url=http://tv.repubblica.it/copertina/l-abbronzato-fa-il-giro-del-mondo/26102?video|title=L'abbronzato fa il giro del mondo|publisher=Repubblica Radio TV|date=7 November 2008}}</ref> On 26 March 2009 he said "I'm paler [than Mr. Obama], because it's been so long since I went sunbathing. He's more handsome, younger and taller."<ref name="Squires2009">{{Cite news |title=Silvio Berlusconi says he is 'paler' than Barack Obama |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/italy/5055633/Silvio-Berlusconi-says-he-is-paler-than-Barack-Obama.html |date=26 March 2009 |work=The Daily Telegraph | location=London | first=Nick | last=Squires | accessdate=30 March 2010}}</ref>
Subsequently, at a tent camp on the outskirts of L'Aquila housing some of the more than 30,000 people who lost their homes during the [[2009 L'Aquila earthquake|2009 earthquake]] he said to an African priest: "you have a nice tan."<ref name="dailymail01">{{Cite news |title=He's done it AGAIN! Berlusconi tells black priest: 'I wish I had time to get as tanned as you'|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/worldnews/article-1170655/Hes-AGAIN-Berlusconi-tells-black-priest-I-wish-I-time-tanned-you.html |date=17 April 2009 |work=Daily Mail |location=UK | first=Nick | last=Pisa}}</ref>
On 24 January 2009, Berlusconi announced his aim to increase the numbers of military patrolling the Italian cities from 3,000 to 30,000 in order to crack down on what he called an "evil army" of criminals. Responding to a female journalist who asked him if this tenfold increase in patrolling soldiers would be enough to secure Italian women from being raped, he said: "We could not field a big enough force to avoid this risk [of rape]. We would need as many soldiers as beautiful women and I don't think that would be possible, because our women are so beautiful." Opposition leaders called the remarks insensitive and in bad taste. Berlusconi retorted that he had merely wanted to compliment Italian women. Other critics accused him of creating a "[[police state]]".<ref name="Squires2009a">{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/italy/4339817/Silvio-Berlusconi-criticised-for-pretty-girl-rape-comment.html|title=Silvio Berlusconi criticised for 'pretty girl' rape comment |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=4 April 2009 | location=London | first=Nick | last=Squires | accessdate=30 March 2010}}</ref>
On 3 April 2009, Berlusconi appeared to have annoyed Queen [[Elizabeth II]] at a photo session during the [[2009 G-20 London summit|G20 summit]]. During the photo session, Berlusconi shouted "Mr. Obama, Mr. Obama", prompting her to turn around and chastise Berlusconi, “What is it? Why does he have to shout?”.<ref name="Ref_2009al">{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/7980912.stm|title=Queen is not amused by Berlusconi |publisher=BBC News|date=3 April 2009}}</ref><ref name="Ref_2009am">{{Cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/G20/article6031910.ece|title=Queen shows Silvio Berlusconi how to be a head of state at London summit|work=The Times |location=UK |date=4 April 2009|first=Mal|last=Siret}}</ref> The following day, at the [[NATO]] meeting in [[Kehl]], Berlusconi was seen talking on his mobile phone, while Merkel and other NATO leaders waited for him for a photo on a [[Rhine]] bridge<ref name="Ref_2009an">{{Cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/topNews/idUKTRE5330S420090404|title=Berlusconi skips NATO ceremonies to talks to Turkey|publisher=Reuters|date=4 April 2009}}</ref> (afterwards, Berlusconi claimed he was talking to [[Turkey|Turkish]] Prime Minister [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]] about accepting the Secretary Generalship of [[Anders Fogh Rasmussen]]). Responding to the Italian media's reaction to these incidents, he said he was considering "hard measures" against reporters, and referred to some of their claims as "slander".<ref name="Nick2009">{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/italy/5110631/Silvio-Berlusconi-threatens-news-blackout-after-reports-of-latest-gaffes.html|title=Silvio Berlusconi threatens news blackout after reports of latest gaffes|author=Nick Squires|work=The Daily Telegraph |date=6 April 2009|accessdate=6 April 2009 | location=London}}</ref>
Two days after the [[2009 L'Aquila earthquake]], Berlusconi suggested that people left homeless should view their experience as a camping weekend.<ref name="Hooper2009">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/apr/08/italy-earthquake-berlusconi|title=Berlusconi: Italy earthquake victims should view experience as a camping weekend|work=The Guardian |date=8 April 2009|accessdate=8 April 2009 | location=London | first=John | last=Hooper}}</ref> While touring the earthquake site, he asked councillor Lia Beltrami, "Can I fondle you?".<ref name="Ref_2009ao">{{Cite news|url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/news/article2416229.ece|title=Fondle gaffe for PM Berlusconi|work=The Sun |location=UK |date=7 May 2009}}</ref>
In May 2009, Berlusconi alleged that he had once had to travel three hours to see a two-hundred-year-old church in the Finnish countryside which, in his opinion, would have been demolished if it was in Italy. Berlusconi had made a non-official visit to Finland in 1999 and had never seen any Finnish church, but had just been visiting [[Iceland]].<ref name="Ref_2009ap">{{cite web|url=http://www.hs.fi/english/article/Berlusconi%E2%80%99s+church+comments+met+with+astonishment+in+Finland/1135245796052|title=Berlusconi’s church comments met with astonishment in Finland|publisher=[[Helsingin Sanomat]]|date=9 May 2009}}</ref><ref name="Ref_2009aq">{{cite web|url=http://newsroom.finland.fi/stt/showarticle.asp?intNWSAID=21628&group=General|title=Berlusconi rolls out another Finnish gaffe|publisher=[[Suomen Tietotoimisto]]|date=7 May 2009}}</ref>
In October 2010, Berlusconi was chastised by the Vatican newspaper ''[[L'Osservatore Romano]]'' after he was filmed telling "offensive and deplorable jokes", including one whose punchline was similar to one of the gravest blasphemies in the Italian language. It was also revealed he had made another anti-Semitic joke a few days previously. Berlusconi responded to the allegations by saying the jokes were "neither an offence nor a sin, but merely a laugh".<ref name="Kington2010">{{Cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/oct/03/silvio-berlusconi-under-fire-jokes | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Tom | last=Kington | title=Silvio Berlusconi condemned by Vatican newspaper for 'deplorable' jokes | date=3 October 2010}}</ref>
On 1 November 2010, after once again being accused of involvement in juvenile prostitution, he suggested that an audience at the Milan trade fair should stop reading newspapers: "Don't read newspapers any more because they deceive you. [...] I am a man who works hard all day long and if sometimes I look at some good-looking girl, it's better to be fond of pretty girls than to be gay".<ref name="Ref_2010f">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d1RX_ppWuRg|title=Berlusconi and girls|date=1 Nov 2010}}</ref> The remarks were immediately condemned by [[Arcigay]], Italy's main [[gay rights]] organisation, on behalf of both women and gay people; speaking on behalf of the organisation, its president Paolo Patanè said that it was "unacceptable for a head of government to foster a chauvinistic and vulgar attitude" with such a statement, and requested that Berlusconi apologise. Politicians including [[Nichi Vendola]], [[Antonio Di Pietro]], and [[Franco Grillini]] released similar statements, with the latter commenting that it was "better to be gay than to be a sex-addicted schemer like Berlusconi."<ref name="Ref_2010g">{{Cite news|url=http://www.libero-news.it/news/522513/Berlusconi___Meglio_guardare_le_belle_ragazze_che_essere_gay_.html |publisher=Libero |date=2 November 2010 |title=Berlusconi: "Meglio guardare le belle ragazze che essere gay" |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005062234/http://www.libero-news.it/news/522513/Berlusconi___Meglio_guardare_le_belle_ragazze_che_essere_gay_.html |archivedate=2011-10-05 |df= }}</ref><ref name="Vendola2010">{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Pbd_iaGJEa8 |publisher=Youtube |last=Vendola |first=Nichi |date=2 November 2010 |accessdate=4 December 2010 |title=Nichi Vendola – videolettera a Silvio Berlusconi – Il teatro della virilità}}</ref> Flavia Madaschi, president of Agedo, the Italian equivalent of [[PFLAG]], also commented that it was "better to be gay than Berlusconi."<ref name="Ref_2010h">{{Cite news |url=http://ricerca.repubblica.it/repubblica/archivio/repubblica/2010/11/05/movimenti-militanti-sinistra-in-piazza-si-meglio.html |title=Movimenti, militanti e sinistra in piazza – Sì, meglio essere gay che Berlusconi |publisher=La Repubblica |date=5 November 2010}}</ref> Activists staged an anti-homophobia protest outside [[Palazzo Chigi]].<ref name="Ref_2010i">{{Cite news |url=http://www.corriere.it/politica/10_novembre_02/reazioni-berlusconi_2145515c-e674-11df-a903-00144f02aabc.shtml |publisher=Corriere della Sera |title=Bersani: "Ruby? Maroni venga in aula – Frase sui gay, il premier ci porta nel caos" |date=2 November 2010}}</ref>
On 13 July 2011, according to a leaked telephone surveillance transcript, Berlusconi told his presumed [[blackmail]]er Valter Lavitola: "The only thing they can say about me is that I screw around [...] Now they're spying on me, controlling my phone calls. I don't give a fuck. In a few months [...] I'll be leaving this shit country that makes me sick."<ref>"a me, l'unica cosa che possono dire di me è che scopo. È chiaro? E quindi mi mettono le spie dove vogliono.. mi controllano le telefonate.. non me ne fotte niente... io.. tra qualche mese me ne vado per i cazzi miei... da un'altra parte e quindi... vado via da questo paese di merda... di cui sono nauseato. Punto e basta." {{cite web|url=http://inchieste.repubblica.it/it/repubblica/rep-it/2011/09/02/news/sfogo_berlusconi_verbali-21135410/ |title=Lo sfogo del premier: "Paese di merda. Tra qualche mese me ne vado"|publisher=repubblica.it |date=2 September 2011|last1=Del Porto |first1=Dario |last2=Sannino |first2=Conchita |language=Italian |accessdate=25 September 2011}}</ref> He had already made a comment about sending a postcard from the [[Bahamas]] in 2005.<ref>{{cite web|author=Marco Travaglio|language=Italian|url=http://bananabis.splinder.com/post/4560913 |title=Forza Bahamas|publisher= [[L'Unità]]|date=17 April 2005|accessdate=12 November 2009}} and {{cite web|url=http://www.onemoreblog.org/archives/005805.html |title=OneMoreBlog 2.31 |publisher=Onemoreblog.org |date= |accessdate=12 November 2009}} This article has been also published in a book ''Berluscomiche'' (Marco Travaglio, 2005, Garzanti Libri, {{ISBN|88-11-59765-X}}), pp. 431–433.</ref>
===Assault at rally=== On 13 December 2009 Berlusconi was hit in the face with an alabaster<ref name="Ref_2009ar">{{Cite news | title = Tartaglia interrogato dai pm 'Gesto folle, ma premeditato' | language = Italian | publisher=La Repubblica | date = 15 December 2009 | url = http://www.repubblica.it/2009/12/sezioni/politica/giustizia-22/testimone-nuovo/testimone-nuovo.html }}</ref> statuette of [[Milan Cathedral]] after a rally in Milan's ''[[Piazza del Duomo, Milan|Piazza del Duomo]]''. As Berlusconi was shaking hands with the public, a man in the crowd stepped forward and launched the statuette at him. The assailant was subsequently detained and identified as Massimo Tartaglia, a 42-year-old surveyor with a history of mental illness but no criminal record, living in the outskirts of Milan.<ref name="Ref_2009as">{{Cite news | title = Da perito a inventore, è in cura da dieci anni | language = Italian | publisher="[[Corriere della Sera]]'' | date = 14 December 2009 | page = 4 | url = http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/2009/dicembre/14/perito_inventore_cura_dieci_anni_co_8_091214010.shtml | accessdate =4 January 2010}}</ref><ref name="Ref_2009at">{{Cite news | title = Silvio Berlusconi punched in the face in Milan |work=The Guardian | date = 13 December 2009 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/dec/13/silvio-berlusconi-punched-in-face | location=London | accessdate=30 March 2010}}</ref> According to a letter released to the Italian news agency [[Agenzia Nazionale Stampa Associata|ANSA]], Tartaglia has apologised for the attack, writing: "I don't recognise myself", and adding that he had "acted alone [with no] form of militancy or political affiliation". Berlusconi suffered facial injuries, a broken nose and two broken teeth; he was subsequently hospitalised.<ref name="Owen2009a">{{Cite news | author=Owen, Richard | title = Silvio Berlusconi will need weeks of treatment after Milan attack |work=The Times | date = 15 December 2009 | url = http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article6956607.ece | accessdate =4 January 2010 | location=London}}</ref> Italian president [[Giorgio Napolitano]] and politicians from all parties in Italy condemned the attack.
In the night of 15–16 December a 26-year-old man was stopped by police and Berlusconi's bodyguards while trying to gain access to Berlusconi's hospital room. A search revealed that he carried no weapons, although three hockey sticks and two knives were later found in his car. The suspect was known to have a history of mental illness and mandatory treatment in mental institutions.<ref name="night_attack">{{Cite news|work=Reggio 24 ore|date=21 December 2009|title=Berlusconi colpito al volto da una statuetta. Dimesso dall'ospedale|url=http://www.reggio24ore.com/Sezione.jsp?titolo=Berlusconi+colpito+al+volto+da+una+statuetta.+Dimesso+dall%27ospedale&idSezione=8681|access-date=2011-11-14|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161231002804/http://www.reggio24ore.com/Sezione.jsp?titolo=Berlusconi+colpito+al+volto+da+una+statuetta.+Dimesso+dall%27ospedale&idSezione=8681#|archive-date=2016-12-31|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
Berlusconi was discharged from the hospital on 17 December 2009.<ref name="Squires2009b">{{Cite news | author=Squires, Nick | title = Doctors fear for Berlusconi 'morale' | work=The Daily Telegraph | date = 16 December 2009 | page = 17 | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/italy/6818922/Fears-for-Silvio-Berlusconis-morale.html | accessdate =4 January 2010 | location=London}}; {{Cite news | author=Squires, Nick | title = Battered and bandaged Berlusconi says his pain need not be in vain | work=The Daily Telegraph | date = 18 December 2009 | page = 23 | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/italy/6834114/Silvio-Berlusconi-leaves-hospital-covered-in-bandages.html | accessdate =4 January 2010 | location=London}}</ref>
==Sexual scandals==
===Wiretaps and accusations of corruption=== In December 2007 the audio recording of a phone call between Berlusconi, then leader of the opposition parties, and Agostino Saccà (general director of [[RAI]]) were published by the magazine ''[[L'espresso]]'' and caused a scandal in several media.<ref name="Ref_2007">{{cite web|url=http://www.repubblica.it/2007/12/sezioni/politica/berlusconi-indagato/berlusconi-regime/berlusconi-regime.html|title=Inchiesta Berlusconi "Saccà va sospeso" L'ex premier: "Solleva il morale del Capo"|language=Italian|work=la Repubblica|date=13 December 2007}}</ref> The wiretap was part of an investigation by the Public Prosecutor Office of [[Naples]], where Berlusconi was investigated for corruption.<ref name="Ref_2007a">{{cite web|url=http://www.corriere.it/cronache/07_dicembre_12/berlusconi_indagato_corruzione_sacca_a47dd26e-a884-11dc-8e86-0003ba99c53b.shtml|title=Berlusconi indagato per corruzione|language=Italian|work=Corriere della Sera|date=12 December 2007}}</ref> In the phone call, Saccà expresses words of impassioned political support to Berlusconi and criticises the behaviour of Berlusconi's allies. Berlusconi urges Saccà to broadcast a telefilm series which was strongly advocated by his ally Umberto Bossi. Saccà laments that many people have spread rumours on this agreement causing problems to him. Then Berlusconi asks Saccà to find a job in RAI for a young woman explicitly telling him that this woman would serve as an asset in a secret exchange with a senator of the majority who would help him to cause Prodi, with his administration, to fall.<ref name="Ref_2007b">{{cite web|url=http://espresso.repubblica.it/dettaglio/Pronto-Silvio-sono-Sacca/1917587 |title=Pronto Silvio, sono Saccà |language=Italian |work=L'espresso |location=Italy |date=20 December 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130622044420/http://espresso.repubblica.it/dettaglio/pronto-silvio-sono-sacca/1917587 |archivedate=2013-06-22 |df= }}</ref>{{Clarify|date=February 2011}} After the publication of these wiretaps, Berlusconi has been accused by other politicians and by some journalists of political corruption through the exploitation of prostitution. Berlusconi said, in his own defence: "In the entertainment world everybody knows that, in certain situations in RAI TV you work only if you prostitute yourself or if you are leftist. I have intervened on behalf of some personalities who are not leftists and have been completely set apart by RAI TV."<ref name="Ref_2007c">{{cite web|url=http://www.corriere.it/politica/07_dicembre_20/berlusconi_rai_sinistra_4933f5e8-aefe-11dc-8fe5-0003ba99c53b.shtml|title=Berlusconi: "In Rai tutti raccomandati"|language=Italian|work=Corriere della Sera|date=20 December 2007}}</ref> In the [[US State Department]]'s 2011 Trafficking in Persons report authorized by Secretary of State [[Hillary Clinton]] Mr. Berlusconi was explicitly named as a person involved in the "commercial sexual exploitation of a Moroccan child".<ref name="britmetro">{{cite web |url=http://e-edition.metro.co.uk/2011/10/31/index.html?p=11 |title=Metro UK - 31/10/2011 digital edition |publisher=E-edition.metro.co.uk |date= |accessdate=1 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20131004235614/http://e-edition.metro.co.uk/2011/10/31/index.html?p=11 |archivedate=4 October 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref name="brittelegraph">{{cite news|last=Pisa |first=Nick |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/silvio-berlusconi/8858275/Silvio-Berlusconi-named-on-US-government-report-on-people-trafficking.html |title=Silvio Berlusconi named on US government report on people trafficking |publisher=Telegraph |date= 30 October 2011|accessdate=1 November 2011 |location=London}}</ref>
===Prostitution scandal and divorce=== [[File:Noémie Laetizia, 66ème Festival de Venise (Mostra).jpg|thumb|upright|Noemi Letizia at the [[2009 Venice Film Festival]].]]
At the end of April 2009, [[Veronica Lario]] wrote an [[open letter]] expressing her anger at Berlusconi's choice of young, attractive female candidates—some with little or no political experience—to represent the party in the [[European Parliament election, 2009|2009 European Parliament elections]]. Berlusconi demanded a public apology, claiming that for the third time his wife had "done this to me in the middle of an election campaign", and stated that there was little prospect of his marriage continuing.<ref name="Ref_2009g">{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/8032392.stm|title=Berlusconi demands wife apology|publisher=BBC News|date=4 May 2009|accessdate=4 May 2009}}</ref> On 3 May, Veronica Lario announced she was filing for divorce following her husband's attendance at a girl's 18th birthday party in [[Casoria]], Naples.<ref name="Ref_2009h">{{cite 2009|work=la Repubblica|language=Italian}}</ref><ref name="Ref_2009i">{{cite
