The inconsistencies of a political case|date=14 May 2009|work=la Repubblica|language=Italian}}</ref> However, on 14 May, newspaper ''la Repubblica'' published an article showing the many inconsistencies and contradictions arisen so far and formally asking Berlusconi to answer ten questions in order to clarify the situation.<ref name="rep10" /><ref name="nyt1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/29/world/europe/29berlusconi.html|title=Prime Minister's Escapades Finally Raise Eyebrows|accessdate=31 May 2009|date=28 May 2009|work=New York Times | first=Rachel | last=Donadio}}</ref>
Ten days later, Letizia's ex-boyfriend Luigi Flaminio claimed that Berlusconi had contacted the girl personally in October 2008, impressed by her "purity" and "angelic face" after seeing pictures of her in a photobook, brought to him by the journalist [[Emilio Fede]] (director of [[TG4 (news program)|TG4]]). Flaminio also mentioned that she had spent a week without her parents at Berlusconi's Sardinian villa around New Year's Eve 2009,<ref name="Ref_2009m">{{cite web|url=http://www.repubblica.it/2009/05/sezioni/politica/berlusconi-divorzio-2/parla-gino/parla-gino.html|title=Così papi Berlusconi entrò nella vita di Noemi|language=Italian|date=24 May 2009|work=la Repubblica}}</ref> a fact confirmed later by her mother.<ref name="Ref_2009n">{{cite web|url=http://www.lastampa.it/redazione/cmsSezioni/politica/200905articoli/44139girata.asp|title=Macché amante. Vorrei parlare con Veronica Lario|language=Italian|date=29 May 2009|work=La Stampa|location=Italy|access-date=2011-11-14|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140512223317/http://www1.lastampa.it/redazione/cmsSezioni/politica/200905articoli/44139girata.asp#|archive-date=2014-05-12|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Photographs of the event taken by a paparazzo were confiscated by the Prosecutor's Office of Rome for violation of privacy<ref name="Ref_2009o">{{cite web|url=http://www.corriere.it/politica/09_maggio_30/berlusconi_garante_foto_784e933c-4cdd-11de-82fb-00144f02aabc.shtml|title=E Berlusconi scrive al Garante "Bloccate le foto di Villa Certosa"|language=Italian|date=30 May 2009|work=Corriere della Sera}}</ref> but a selection of those photos was published in ''[[El País]]'' on 4 June.<ref name="Ref_2009p">{{Cite news |url=http://www.elpais.com/articulo/internacional/The/pictures/vetoed/by/Berlusconi/elpepuint/20090605elpepuint_3/Tes|publisher=[[El País]] |title=The pictures vetoed by Berlusconi|date=5 June 2009}}</ref><ref name="Ref_2009q">{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8084694.stm|title=Berlusconi fury over naked photos|publisher=BBC News|date=5 June 2009}}</ref><ref name="Ref_2009r">{{Cite news |url=http://www.elpais.com/fotogaleria/imagenes/censuradas/Berlusconi/6527-1/elpgal/|language=Spanish|work=[[El País]]|title=Las imágenes censuradas de Berlusconi|date=5 June 2009}}</ref>
On 28 May 2009, Silvio Berlusconi said that he had never had "spicy" relations with Noemi Letizia, swearing also on his children's heads. He said also that if any such thing had occurred, he would have resigned immediately.<ref name="Ref_2009s">{{Cite news |url=http://www.corriere.it/english/09_maggio_29/berlusconi_4939b106-4c49-11de-b7be-00144f02aabc.shtml |work=Corriere della Sera |title=I Never Had Spicy Relations With Noemi. Ι Swear On My Children |date=29 May 2009 |accessdate=30 May 2009}}</ref>
On 17 June 2009, Patrizia D'Addario, a 42-year old escort and retired actress<ref name="Follain2009">{{Cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article6590890.ece|work=The Sunday Times |title=Silvio Berlusconi brands sex claims by Patrizia D’Addario as trash|date=28 June 2009 | location=London | first=John | last=Follain | accessdate=30 March 2010}}</ref> from [[Bari]], Italy, claimed that she had been recruited twice (by a mutual friend, who paid her 2000 Euros) in order to spend the evening, and once also the night, with Berlusconi.<ref name="Ref_2009t">{{cite web|url=http://www.corriere.it/politica/09_giugno_17/patrizia_sarzanini_intervista_b943f0c0-5afd-11de-8305-00144f02aabc.shtml|title=Incontri e candidatura Ecco la mia verità|language=Italian|date=17 June 2009|work=Corriere della Sera}}</ref> Magistrates in Bari are investigating this case, since the friend could be prosecuted for favouring [[Prostitution in Italy|prostitution]].
Silvio Berlusconi denied any knowledge of D'Addario being a paid escort: "I have never paid a woman… I have never understood what satisfaction there is if the pleasure of conquest is absent".<ref name="Ref_2009u">{{cite web|url=http://www.corriere.it/politica/09_giugno_23/berlusconi_veronica_chi_f5a40176-5ffe-11de-bd53-00144f02aabc.shtml|title=D'Addario agisce su mandato preciso|language=Italian|date=23 June 2009|work=Corriere della Sera}}</ref> He also accused an unspecified person of manoeuvring and paying D'Addario (accusations which she vehemently denied).<ref name="Ref_2009v">{{Cite news |url=http://www.corriere.it/english/09_giugno_24/daddario_3ff75134-60ad-11de-9ec2-00144f02aabc.shtml |work=Corriere della Sera |title=D’Addario Denies PM’s Accusation of Acting on Orders |date=24 June 2009 |accessdate=25 June 2009}}</ref>
Other young women have also described to the press the parties held in Berlusconi's Rome residence (Palazzo Grazioli),<ref name="Ref_2009w">{{cite web|url=http://www.corriere.it/english/09_giugno_17/berlusconi_0c8f8f9e-5c13-11de-b8d9-00144f02aabc.shtml|title=Magistrate Questions Three More Women|date=18 June 2009|accessdate=25 June 2009|work=Corriere della Sera}}</ref> while photos and transcripts of audio cassettes circulated widely in the press. These descriptions have raised, in particular, concerns about the lack of security measures and the uncontrolled access to the prime minister's residence.<ref name="Ref_2009x">{{Cite news |url=http://www.corriere.it/english/09_giugno_22/bari_1a9644c6-5f3c-11de-bd53-00144f02aabc.shtml |work=Corriere della Sera |title=Bari Magistrates Claim Access to Premier’s Residence was Uncontrolled |date=22 June 2009 |accessdate=25 June 2009}}</ref>
On 26 June 2009, the "[[10 questions to Berlusconi|10 questions]]" to Berlusconi were reformulated by ''la Repubblica'' newspaper, and then frequently republished on it.<ref name="Ref_2009y">{{cite web|url=http://temi.repubblica.it/repubblicaspeciale-repubblicaspeciale-ten-new-questions-to-silvio-berlusconi/2009/06/26/ten-new-questions-to-silvio-berlusconi/|title=Ten new questions to Silvio Berlusconi|date=26 June 2009|accessdate=28 August 2009|work=la Repubblica}}</ref> No answers were given, until 28 August 2009, when Berlusconi sued [[Gruppo Editoriale L'Espresso]], the owner company of the newspaper, and defined these ten questions as "defamatory" and "rhetorical".<ref name="Ref_2009z">{{Cite news |url=http://www.adnkronos.com/AKI/English/CultureAndMedia/?id=3.0.3707372087|work=[[Adnkronos|AKI]]|title=Berlusconi to sue left-wing daily for over €1 mln|date=28 August 2009|accessdate=28 August 2009}}</ref>
Berlusconi's lifestyle has raised eyebrows in Catholic circles, with vigorous criticism being expressed in particular by the newspaper ''[[Avvenire]]'', owned by the [[Conferenza Episcopale Italiana]] (Conference of Italian Bishops). This was followed by the publication in the newspaper il Giornale (owned by the Berlusconi family) of details with regard to legal proceedings against the editor of ''Avvenire'', Dino Boffo, which seemed to implicate him for a harassment case against the wife of his ex-partner.<ref name="Ref_2009aa">{{Cite news |url=http://www.ilgiornale.it/a.pic1?ID=377663|title=Boffo, il supercensore condannato per molestie|language=Italian|publisher=il Giornale|date=28 August 2009|accessdate=22 September 2009}}</ref> Dino Boffo has always declared the details of the proceedings to be false, although he has not denied the basic premise.<ref name="Ref_2009ab">{{Cite news |url=http://www.ilgiornale.it/a.pic1?ID=378630|title=Boffo: "E' una patacca". Feltri: "Ecco le carte"|language=Italian|publisher=il Giornale|date=31 August 2009|accessdate=22 September 2009}}</ref>
After a period of tense exchanges and polemics, on 3 September 2009, Boffo resigned from his editorial position<ref name="Ref_2009ac">{{Cite news |url=http://www.avvenire.it/boffo/boffo+dimissioni_200909031239587930000_200909041332052000000.htm |title=La lettera di Boffo al Card. Bagnasco |language=Italian |work=Avvenire |location=Italy |date=17 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110821003413/http://www.avvenire.it/boffo/boffo%2Bdimissioni_200909031239587930000_200909041332052000000.htm |archivedate=August 21, 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref name="Ref_2009ad">{{Cite news |url=http://www.ilgiornale.it/a.pic1?ID=379661|title=Avvenire, Boffo lascia: "La mia vita violentata"|language=Italian|work=il Giornale|date=4 September 2009|accessdate=22 September 2009}}</ref> and the assistant editor Marco Tarquinio became editor ''[[ad interim]]''.<ref name="Ref_2009ae">{{Cite news|url=http://www.avvenire.it/Cronaca/SEMERARO_200909031625106270000.htm |title=Interim del giornale a Tarquinio |language=Italian |work=Avvenire |location=Italy |date=3 September 2009 |accessdate=22 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090906102736/http://www.avvenire.it/Cronaca/SEMERARO_200909031625106270000.htm |archivedate=September 6, 2009 }}</ref>
On 22 September 2009, after a press conference, Silvio Berlusconi declared that he had asked his ministers not to respond anymore to questions regarding "gossip". He stated also that the Italian press should talk only about the "successes" of Italian Government in internal and foreign policies, adding also that the press now will be able only to ask questions such as "how many apartments will be given in [[L'Aquila]]", i.e. relating to his administration and not to [[gossip]].<ref name="Ref_2009af">{{Cite news|url=http://www.agi.it/english-version/italy/elenco-notizie/200909221932-pol-ren0047-berlusconi_ministers_not_to_respond_to_questions_on_gossip |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161231002911/http://www.agi.it/english-version/italy/elenco-notizie/200909221932-pol-ren0047-berlusconi_ministers_not_to_respond_to_questions_on_gossip |dead-url=yes |archive-date=31 December 2016 |title=Berlusconi: Ministers not to respond to questions on gossip |work=[[Agenzia Giornalistica Italia|AGI]] |date=22 September 2009 |accessdate=22 September 2009 }}</ref>
During a contested<ref name="Ref_2009ag">{{Cite news |url=http://www.repubblica.it/2009/10/sezioni/politica/rai-5/primo-ottobre/primo-ottobre.html|title="Berlusconi indignato per Annozero" E sulla Rai è scontro Cicchitto-Pd|language=Italian|work=la Repubblica|date=1 October 2009|accessdate=2 October 2009}}</ref><ref name="Ref_2009ah">{{Cite news |url=http://www.adnkronos.com/AKI/English/CultureAndMedia/?id=3.0.3833543339|title=Call girl 'fixer' tries to gag popular TV show|work=[[Adnkronos|AKI]]|date=1 October 2009|accessdate=2 October 2009}}</ref> episode of ''[[AnnoZero]]'' on 1 October 2009, the journalist and presenter [[Michele Santoro]] interviewed Patrizia D'Addario.<ref name="Ref_2009ai">{{Cite news |url=http://www.ansa.it/web/notizie/rubriche/english/2009/09/30/visualizza_new.html_963761042.html|title=Escort to appear on talk show|work=[[Agenzia Nazionale Stampa Associata|ANSA]]|date=30 September 2009|accessdate=2 October 2009}}</ref> She stated she was contacted by Giampaolo Tarantini – a businessman from Bari – who already knew her and requested her presence at Palazzo Grazioli with "the President".<ref name="Ref_2009aj">{{Cite news |url=http://www.lastampa.it/multimedia/multimedia.asp?p=1&pm=3&IDmsezione=9&IDalbum=21013&tipo=FOTOGALLERY#mpos|title=Patrizia D'Addario ospite ad "Annozero" – La prima sera|language=Italian|work=La Stampa |location=Italy|date=2 October 2009|accessdate=2 October 2009}}</ref> D'Addario also stated that Berlusconi knew that she was a paid escort.<ref name="Ref_2009ak">{{Cite news|url=http://www.lastampa.it/redazione/cmsSezioni/politica/200910articoli/47861girata.asp|title=D'Addario in tv: il premier sapeva che ero una escort|language=Italian|work=La Stampa|location=Italy|date=2 October 2009|accessdate=2 October 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005000048/http://www1.lastampa.it/redazione/cmsSezioni/politica/200910articoli/47861girata.asp#|archive-date=2013-10-05|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
===Ruby Rubacuori=== In November 2010, teenage Moroccan [[belly dance]]r and alleged prostitute Karima El Mahroug (better known as "[[Ruby Rubacuori]]") claimed to have been given $10,000 by Berlusconi at parties at his private villas. The girl told prosecutors in Milan that these events were like orgies where Berlusconi and 20 young women performed an African-style ritual known as the "[[bunga bunga]]" in the nude.<ref name="Ref_2010d">{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/11/09/3061762.htm?section=justin|title=Exile an option for besieged Berlusconi|publisher=[[ABC News (Australia)]]|date=9 November 2010|accessdate=9 November 2010}}</ref><ref name="Ref_q">[http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2010-11-07/silvio-berlusconis-bunga-bunga-parties/ Berlusconi’s "Bunga Bunga Orgies":] ''Daily Beast'' 7 November 2010 Retrieved 25 November 2010</ref> It was also found out that, on 27 May 2010, El Mahroug had been arrested for theft by the Milan police but (being still a minor) she was directed to a shelter for juvenile offenders. However, following two telephone calls by Berlusconi to the police authorities (in which, in particular, he falsely indicated that El Mahroug was a close relative of President [[Hosni Mubarak]] of [[Egypt]]), the young woman was released and entrusted to the care of [[The People of Freedom|PDL]] regional counselor (and Berlusconi's personal dental hygienist) Nicole Minetti.<ref name="Ref_2010e">{{Cite news|url=http://www.rainews24.rai.it/it/news.php?newsid=146858|title=Ruby fu affidata a una Comunità, non a Nicole Minetti|publisher=[[RaiNews24]]|date=30 October 2010|accessdate=17 November 2010}}</ref><ref name="Ref_r">{{Cite news|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Silvio-Berlusconis-Dental-Hygienist-Nicole-Minetti-To-Contest-Italys-Regional-Elections/Article/201002315553227 |title=Silvio Berlusconi's dental hygienist Nicole Minetti to contest Italy's regional elections }}</ref> The investigation of Berlusconi for [[extortion]] (''[[:it:concussione]]'') and [[child prostitution]] regarding Karima El Mahroug has been referred to as "[[Rubygate]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ilfattoquotidiano.it/2011/01/14/ruby-b-under-investigation-for-child-prostitution-videos-and-photos-found-in-girl%E2%80%99s-laptop/86481/ |title=Ruby, B. under investigation for child prostitution Videos and photos found in girl’s laptop | Redazione Il Fatto Quotidiano | Il Fatto Quotidiano |publisher=Ilfattoquotidiano.it |date=14 January 2011 |accessdate=1 November 2011}}</ref> MP Gaetano Pecorella proposed to lower the [[age of majority]] in Italy to solve the case.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://rassegna.governo.it/testo.asp?d=55045063 |title=Governo Italiano — Rassegna stampa |publisher=Rassegna.governo.it |date= |accessdate=1 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111214150134/http://rassegna.governo.it/testo.asp?d=55045063 |archivedate=14 December 2011 |df= }}</ref>
Berlusconi has also come under fire for reportedly spending $1.8 million in state funds from [[RAI|RAI Cinema]] to further the career of a largely unknown Bulgarian actress, Michelle Bonev. The fact that this coincided with severe cuts being made to the country's arts budget provoked a strong reaction from the public.
On 24 June 2013, Berlusconi was convicted for paying for sex with Karima El Mahroug and sentenced to seven years in prison, although his sentence will not start until after the appeal process is concluded.<ref name="GuardianJune24-2013">{{cite news|title=Silvio Berlusconi found guilty of paying for sex with underage prostitute|newspaper=The Guardian|date=June 24, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-23034167|title=Italian ex-PM Berlusconi sentenced in Ruby sex case|publisher=BBC News Online|date=24 June 2013|accessdate=24 June 2013}}</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Corey Johnson |office = Speaker of the [[New York City Council]] |term_start = January 3, 2018 |term_end = |predecessor =[[Melissa Mark-Viverito]] |successor = |office2 = Member of the [[New York City Council]] from the 3rd District |term_start2 = January 1, 2014 |term_end2 = |predecessor2 = [[Christine Quinn]] |successor2 = |image = Corey Johnson 2015.jpg |imagesize = 200px |caption = Johnson in 2015 |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1982|4|28|mf=yes}} |birth_place = [[Beverly, Massachusetts]] |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] |spouse = |children = |alma_mater = |website = [http://council.nyc.gov/d3/html/members/home.shtml Official website] |religion = }} '''Corey Johnson''' (born April 28, 1982) is the Speaker of the [[New York City Council]]<ref>{{cite web|last1=Lavers|first1=Michael|title=Corey Johnson elected speaker of NYC Council|url=http://www.washingtonblade.com/2018/01/03/corey-johnson-elected-speaker-nyc-council/|website=The Washington Blade|accessdate=January 3, 2018}}</ref> and a City Council member for the 3rd District. He is a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]]. The district includes [[Hell’s Kitchen]], [[Chelsea, Manhattan|Chelsea]], the [[West Village]], and parts of [[Flatiron District|Flatiron]], [[SoHo]] and the [[Upper West Side]] in [[Manhattan]].
Prior to his election as Speaker, Johnson was frequently named as a potential candidate, and was perceived as a leading contender.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/15/nyregion/new-york-city-speaker.html | title=New York City Girds for Political Brawl Over Looming Speaker Vacancy | website=The New York Times|access-date=July 29, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gothamgazette.com/city/7008-corey-johnson-s-very-busy-campaign-weekend | title=Corey Johnson’s Very Busy Campaign Weekend | website=Gotham Gazzette|access-date=July 29, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/city-council-speaker-front-runner-won-seek-reelection-article-1.3212782 | title=City Council speaker race heats up as Melissa Mark-Viverito’s heir apparent won’t seek reelection | website=New York Daily News|access-date=July 29, 2017}}</ref> In mid-December 2017, with the public support of Mayor de Blasio, the concession of other front runners, and backing of the Bronx and Queens Democratic Parties, Johnson corralled the requisite number of votes to become the presumptive favorite for the position, with the full Council voting on January 3, 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cityandstateny.com/articles/politics/new-york-city/corey-johnson-new-york-city-council-speaker-race.html#.Wj6TrVSpnOQ|title=Reports Say Corey Johnson is Steps Away from Becoming the next New York City Council Speaker|website=City & State|access-date=December 23, 2017}}</ref>
==Early life== Johnson was raised in [[Middleton, Massachusetts]], in a union household by his mother, Ann Queenan Richardson, a homeless services provider, and his step-father, Rodney Richardson, a Teamster.<ref name="Council bio">{{Cite web|url=http://council.nyc.gov/d3/html/members/bio.shtml|title=Biography|website=council.nyc.gov|access-date=December 12, 2016}}</ref> Johnson's birth father, David Johnson, was born to an American father and Korean mother in South Korea.<ref name="sober">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/03/nyregion/council-speaker-corey-johnson.html|title=Sober and H.I.V. Positive, New Council Speaker Has Weathered Adversity|first=J. David|last=Goodman|date=January 4, 2018|publisher=|accessdate=January 4, 2018|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref>
Johnson made national headlines in 2000 when, as captain of his high school football team at [[Masconomet Regional High School]], he publicly revealed that he was gay. His story was reported by major national news outlets including ''[[The New York Times]]'' and ''[[20/20 (U.S. TV series)|20/20]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/04/30/sports/icon-recast-support-for-a-gay-athlete.html|title=Icon Recast: Support for a Gay Athlete|date=April 30, 2000|website=The New York Times|accessdate=December 28, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=GB PFLAG|title=A Life Rooted in Courage Part 1 of 2|date=February 12, 2015|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M4hEJkoAcz0|accessdate=December 12, 2016}}</ref>
Shortly after graduating high school, Johnson moved to New York City and became engaged in [[LGBT rights in the United States|LGBT rights]] activism, after only spending less than one semester at [[George Washington University]].<ref name="sober"/> Johnson was a contributor and eventually the political director of the LGBT blog [[Andy Towle|Towleroad]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.towleroad.com/2013/09/corey-johnson-declares-victory-in-nyc-city-council-race/|title=Corey Johnson Declares Victory in NYC City Council Race - Towleroad|date=September 10, 2013|newspaper=Towleroad|language=en-US|access-date=December 12, 2016}}</ref>
In 2005, Johnson joined [[Manhattan Community Board 4]] (CB4), to which he said in 2014 “You don’t spend eight years on the community board because it’s sexy,”, “You’re on the community board because you care about the community.”<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cityandstateny.com/articles/personality/interviews-and-profiles/meet-the-city-council%E2%80%99s-new-members-corey-johnson.html|title=Meet the City Council’s New Members: Corey Johnson|last=admin|date=2014-01-28|work=CSNY|access-date=2018-02-18|language=en}}</ref> In 2011, Johnson was elected Chair of CB4, becoming the youngest Community Board Chair in New York City at the time.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cityandstateny.com/articles/personality/interviews-and-profiles/meet-the-city-council%E2%80%99s-new-members-corey-johnson.html#.V9BdR_krKUk|title=Meet the City Council’s New Members: Corey Johnson|last=State|first=City &|website=cityandstateny.com|access-date=December 12, 2016}}</ref> In 2011, Johnson was profiled by ''[[City & State]]'' as a "rising star" in New York City politics.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archives.cityandstateny.com/rising-stars-40-under-40-corey-johnson/|title=Rising Stars 40 Under 40: Corey Johnson|date=September 19, 2011|website=City & State|accessdate=December 30, 2017}}</ref>
==New York City Council== In 2013, [[Christine Quinn]] ran for Mayor of New York City as her term in the City Council was expiring. Johnson, then Chair of Community Board 4, ran to succeed Quinn and was elected in November 2013 with 86% of the vote.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/projects/elections/2013/general/city-council/results.html|title=New York City Council - 2013 Election Results|website=The New York Times|access-date=December 12, 2016}}</ref> Johnson assumed office on January 1, 2014. As of December 2016, Johnson had passed 18 pieces of legislation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://legistar.council.nyc.gov/PersonDetail.aspx?ID=125479&GUID=32D93D23-C637-4D79-B96E-47F3D0472147|title=The New York City Council - Corey D. Johnson|last=Tajanko|first=Darius|website=legistar.council.nyc.gov|access-date=December 12, 2016}}</ref>
Among his key areas of focus have been strengthening rent regulation and tenant protection, and enhancing services for New Yorkers with HIV and AIDS. As of December 2017, Johnson, who is HIV-positive,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/states/new-york/albany/story/2017/11/28/corey-johnsons-charm-offensive-123490|title=Corey Johnson's charm offensive |date=November 28, 2017|author=Gloria Pazmino|website=Politico.com|accessdate=December 30, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cityandstateny.com/articles/personality/interviews-and-profiles/six-things-to-know-about-corey-johnson.html#.WkfZoDdG3iX|title=Six Things to Know About Corey Johnson|date=December 26, 2017|author=Rebecca Lewis|website=City & State|accessdate=December 30, 2017}}</ref> has been identified as the only openly HIV-positive politician in the State of New York.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cityandstateny.com/articles/personality/rising-stars/new-york-city-40-under-40-all-stars.html#.WkfdRTdG3iV|title=Still Rising: The NYC 40 Under 40 all-stars|date=October 24, 2017|author=Gabe Ponce de Leon|website=City & State|accessdate=December 30, 2017}}</ref>
In the Council, Johnson serves as Chair of the Committee on Health, and is a member of the Contracts, Finance, General Welfare, Waterfronts and Mental Health, Developmental Disability, Alcoholism, Drug Abuse and Disability Services committees. Johnson is Co-Chair of the Manhattan Delegation to the City Council with [[Margaret Chin|Council Member Margaret Chin]] and is the former Chair of the [[New York City Council LGBT Caucus|LGBT Caucus]].<ref name="Council bio"/>
;Health As Chair of the City Council’s Committee on Health, Council Member Johnson has overseen a number of hearings on major health issues affecting New York City, including the [[2015 Bronx Legionnaires' disease outbreaks|Legionnaires’ outbreak of 2015]] and the proliferation of [[synthetic marijuana]], known as K2, in New York.
On April 6, 2016, [[Bill de Blasio|Mayor Bill de Blasio]] signed into law Johnson’s bill that prohibits the use of [[smokeless tobacco]] products, such as [[chewing tobacco]], at sports stadiums and arenas that host events that require a ticket for admission.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/07/sports/baseball/smokeless-tobacco-ban-new-york-yankees-mets.html|title=It’s Official: Smokeless Tobacco Is Out|last=Berkman|first=Seth|date=April 6, 2016|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=December 12, 2016}}</ref> The legislation effectively banned chewing tobacco from professional baseball in New York City. A similar ban had previously been enacted in cities including San Francisco, Boston, Los Angeles, and Chicago.
Johnson’s legislation to require transparency regarding health services administered at [[Rikers Island]] was signed into law on June 16, 2015.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://observer.com/2015/05/council-passes-rikers-island-health-reporting-bill/|title=Council Passes Rikers Island Health Reporting Bill|date=May 27, 2015|newspaper=Observer|language=en-US|access-date=December 12, 2016}}</ref>
Johnson’s legislation requiring [[automated external defibrillator]]s to be present at public ball fields in New York City, which was co-sponsored by Minority Leader [[Steven Matteo]], was passed by the City Council on April 20, 2016 and signed into law on May 10, 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://legistar.council.nyc.gov/LegislationDetail.aspx?ID=2460446&GUID=BD95524A-A1A7-4B96-BD57-70142322453B&Options|title=The New York City Council - File #: Int 0902-2015|last=Tajanko|first=Darius|website=legistar.council.nyc.gov|access-date=December 12, 2016}}</ref>
;Criminal justice reform On August 16, 2016, the City Council passed legislation introduced by Johnson and Council Speaker [[Melissa Mark-Viverito]] to create a City office responsible for the coordination of social and healthcare services for individuals who have been released from the [[New York City Department of Correction]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://pix11.com/2016/08/16/council-passes-bill-to-help-ex-cons/|title=New York City Council passes bill to help ex-cons|date=August 16, 2016|website=New York's PIX11 / WPIX-TV|access-date=December 12, 2016}}</ref>
;LGBT rights In 2014, Council Member Johnson introduced legislation that removed surgical requirements for [[transgender]] New Yorkers to correct their birth certificates. The legislation passed the City Council on December 8, 2014 and was adopted on January 8, 2015.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/blogs/dailypolitics/transgender-birth-certificate-bill-passes-council-blog-entry-1.2038261|title=Transgender birth certificate bill passes Council|newspaper=NY Daily News|access-date=December 12, 2016}}</ref>
;Women's issues Johnson’s first legislation to pass the City Council was a bill that granted a presumption of eligibility for people transitioning from domestic violence shelters to [[New York City Department of Homeless Services|Department of Homeless Services]] shelters. The bill allows these individuals to bypass extensive intake procedures that they already underwent during their first shelter placement.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://legistar.council.nyc.gov/LegislationDetail.aspx?ID=1805812&GUID=944FD9D2-FA00-423E-87F9-BC82207C20F3&Options|title=The New York City Council - File #: Int 0361-2014|last=Tajanko|first=Darius|website=legistar.council.nyc.gov|access-date=December 12, 2016}}</ref>
;Education Johnson introduced legislation with Council Member [[Vanessa Gibson]] to require the [[New York City Department of Education|Department of Education]] to report on the use of disciplinary measures in public schools. The legislation was passed on September 30, 2015 and signed into law on October 13, 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://legistar.council.nyc.gov/LegislationDetail.aspx?ID=2253272&GUID=9BACC627-DB3A-455C-861E-9CE4C35AFAAC&Options|title=The New York City Council - File #: Int 0730-2015|last=Tajanko|first=Darius|website=legistar.council.nyc.gov|access-date=December 12, 2016}}</ref>
Johnson later introduced legislation requiring the Department of Education to regularly report on student health services in public schools, to ensure that such services are adequately serving New York City students. This legislation was signed into law by Mayor de Blasio on February 8, 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://legistar.council.nyc.gov/LegislationDetail.aspx?ID=2271074&GUID=838E8B8C-C57D-44A6-884D-9B096E94D101&Options|title=The New York City Council - File #: Int 0771-2015|last=Tajanko|first=Darius|website=legistar.council.nyc.gov|access-date=December 12, 2016}}</ref>
;Environment In October 2015, the City Council passed Johnson’s legislation that requires the City to conduct regular air quality surveys that identify the major local and regional sources of [[air pollution]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://legistar.council.nyc.gov/LegislationDetail.aspx?ID=2240464&GUID=5E02466F-FDB2-4AD4-A4D7-4197A2E78F33&Options=Advanced&Search|title=The New York City Council - File #: Int 0712-2015|last=Tajanko|first=Darius|website=legistar.council.nyc.gov|access-date=December 12, 2016}}</ref>
;Rent regulation Council Member Johnson was the prime sponsor of legislation to declare a housing shortage emergency in 2015, which allowed rent stabilization laws to be extended.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/city-council-votes-extend-expiring-rent-laws-article-1.2146497|title=City Council votes to extend expiring rent laws|newspaper=NY Daily News|access-date=December 12, 2016}}</ref>
On June 3, 2015, Johnson was arrested in [[Albany, New York|Albany]] in an act of [[civil disobedience]] while protesting for the extension of [[rent regulation]] and the reform of the rent laws in New York State. In total, 55 protesters were arrested for blocking the entrance to Governor [[Andrew Cuomo|Andrew Cuomo’s]] office in this demonstration.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://thevillager.com/2015/06/04/pols-arrested-in-albany-as-rent-war-ratchets-up/|title=Pols arrested in Albany as rent war ratchets up {{!}} The Villager Newspaper|access-date=December 12, 2016}}</ref>
;Seniors Johnson passed legislation in collaboration with Council Members Margaret Chin and [[Paul Vallone]] to create oversight for all of New York City’s social adult day care centers. The bill requires all social adult day care centers operating in New York City to register with the City’s [[New York City Department for the Aging|Department for the Aging]] (DFTA), and requires them to adhere to State regulations. The legislation also creates a DFTA ombudsman to take complaints regarding any lack of compliance with these requirements.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://legistar.council.nyc.gov/LegislationDetail.aspx?ID=1805819&GUID=05C4F9D7-932B-4057-BAA5-183452CA6B69&Options|title=The New York City Council - File #: Int 0358-2014|last=Tajanko|first=Darius|website=legistar.council.nyc.gov|access-date=December 12, 2016}}</ref>
;Animal welfare Johnson worked with Council Member [[Elizabeth Crowley]] in 2014 to introduce a set of bills to regulate the sale of pets in New York City, with the purpose of [[Animal rights|animal protection]]. The bills regulate irresponsible breeders, combat overpopulation, provide for the safe accounting of animals and ensure that known animal abusers are unable to obtain animals. The package of legislation was passed on December 17, 2014.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/blogs/dailypolitics/council-passes-bill-ban-pets-puppy-mills-blog-entry-1.2048942|title=Council passes bill to ban pets from puppy mills|newspaper=NY Daily News|access-date=December 12, 2016}}</ref>
In 2015, Council Member Johnson introduced legislation mandating that either fire sprinklers or supervision be present in all establishments that house animals for more than 24 hours.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2015/08/14/pet-stores-fire-sprinklers/|title=New Law Requires Automatic Fire Sprinklers In NYC Businesses With Animals|access-date=December 12, 2016}}</ref> The bill was signed into law on September 2, 2015, after more than a decade of advocacy by animal rights activists.
In 2016, Council Member Johnson co-sponsored legislation by Council Member Rosie Mendez to ban the use of wild animals in circuses. In October 2016, Johnson held a hearing in the Health Committee and spoke passionately in support of the legislation, saying to the media "trucking wild animals in and out of the city strictly for entertainment purposes is not a humane way to be treating them.”<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wtop.com/canada/2016/10/animal-advocates-push-ban-in-nyc-on-exotic-circus-animals/|title=Animal advocates push ban in NYC on exotic circus animals|date=October 13, 2016|publisher=|accessdate=December 28, 2017}}</ref> On June 15, 2017, Johnson Chaired a meeting of the Health Committee and successfully passed the bill by a vote of 7-0. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/city-council-pushing-wild-animal-ban-circuses-article-1.3250440|title=City Council still pushing for wild animal ban at circuses|publisher=|accessdate=December 28, 2017}}</ref> The bill heads to the full City Council for a vote on June 21, 2017.
;Transportation On May 27, 2015 the City Council passed Johnson’s legislation that requires all heavy-duty vehicles in New York City’s fleet to be equipped with sideguards, which are devices meant to reduce casualties commonly caused to pedestrians and cyclists by large trucks.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://legistar.council.nyc.gov/LegislationDetail.aspx?ID=1687945&GUID=9621FABE-B038-4D87-BD30-54547AD24E3F&Options|title=The New York City Council - File #: Int 0198-2014|last=Tajanko|first=Darius|website=legistar.council.nyc.gov|access-date=December 12, 2016}}</ref>
;Labor In response to a growing trend of hotel rooms being converted into luxury condominiums, Johnson introduced legislation to limit the number of condo conversions that hotel owners can make. The goal of this legislation was to protect jobs in the hotel industry. It was passed by the City Council on May 14, 2015 and signed into law on June 2, 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://therealdeal.com/2015/05/15/city-council-passes-hotel-conversion-bill/|title=City Council passes hotel conversion bill|last= |first=|date=May 15, 2015|website=The Real Deal New York|access-date=December 12, 2016}}</ref>
;District improvements Johnson’s District includes all or part of the West Side neighborhoods of [[Chelsea, Manhattan|Chelsea]], [[Hell's Kitchen, Manhattan|Hell’s Kitchen]], [[Greenwich Village]], [[SoHo, Manhattan|SoHo]], [[Hudson Square]], the [[Upper West Side]], [[Times Square]], [[Flatiron District|FlatIron]], [[Hudson Yards Redevelopment|Hudson Yards]], the [[High Line]], the [[Theater District, Manhattan|Theater District]], and the [[Garment District, Manhattan|Garment District]].
Since assuming office, Johnson has allocated $10 million in capital funding to improve schools, parks, libraries and other neighborhood institutions. He has allocated a further $1.35 million to support local non-profit institutions through discretionary funding.
Johnson introduced [[participatory budgeting]] to his district, funding items such as the creation of a park on West 20th Street, a new library for City Knoll Public Middle School, new bathrooms for the NYC Lab High School.{{cn|date=March 2018}}
;Endorsements On May 21, 2018, Johnson endorsed Public Advocate Letitia James in her campaign to become Attorney General of New York.<ref>http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/city-council-speaker-endorses-letitia-james-state-ag-article-1.4002007</ref> On June 24, 2018,<ref>https://wcbs880.radio.com/articles/speaker-johnson-endorses-cuomo-reelection</ref> he endorsed Andrew Cuomo in his bid for re-election as Governor of New York.<ref>http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/city-council-speaker-endorses-letitia-james-state-ag-article-1.4002007</ref><ref>http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/ny-johnson-endorses-cuomo-reelection-20180623-story.html</ref>

'''Denburg Edison Clifford Coleman''' (January 8, 1931 – February 6, 1994) was a radio pioneer, comedian and journalist. He worked primarily with [[Radio Belize]] and is recognized as having brought that station to a position of prominence in the small Central American nation.
== Biography == Coleman was born in [[Benque Viejo del Carmen]] to descendants of Honduran immigrants from Isla Roatan. Having attended primary school in Benque Viejo and [[St. John's College, Belize|high school in Belize City]], he became involved in the nationalist movement on the labour front, working with [[George Cadle Price|George Price]] and the [[General Workers' Union (Belize)|General Workers' Union]] in the 1950s. He had also gotten a part-time job with Radio Belize as a temporary announcer, at first working only in Spanish because the bosses thought he did not have the right accent for delivering an English-language newscast. He received a certificate and a job as Labor Inspector but was fired a few months later after an altercation with a fellow employee. He fell back on his job at Radio Belize and within a decade had risen to become the voice of Belize, with a sometimes risque repartee of jokes and witticisms and a ready supply of listener approved music. About this time he married childhood sweetheart Carmen "Panchita" Aguallo; they had one son, current broadcaster with [[Positive Vibes FM]] Gerard Coleman. He also had a step granddaughter, Susan Hernandez, whom he loved very much like his own blood granddaughter. He often let her speak over the radio and pick songs for the playlist. Coleman also frequently performed at the former Bliss Institute, now Center for the Performing Arts. He died in 1994, at Radio Belize's ebb in [[Belize City]], [[Belize]], prior to the station's demise in 1998.
== Radio style == Coleman was termed a perfectionist by some of his coworkers. But he always kept them- and listeners- on edge with his own brand of humor, much of it focused on unseen companion "Panchita", which many listeners thought represented his wife, though this was not the case. Among several bad habits was his lack of judgement with regard to time, some mornings barely making it to studios in downtown Belize City; and his rampant alcoholism, which only after several scares was repudiated in the late 1970s. Coleman succeeded because he represented the resiliency of Belizeans in the face of the many disasters affecting the nation as it struggled toward independence.
== References == * Hunter, Fr. Charles, S.J. "Denburg Edison Clifford Coleman", ''Christian Herald'', Apr. 1994. * "Edison Coleman", ''Brukdown Magazine'', 1980s.

[[Marjolein Beumer]] (sister) }} '''Famke Beumer Janssen''' ({{IPA-nl|ˈfɑmkə ˈjɑnsə(n)|lang}}; born {{circa|1964}}) is a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] actress, director, screenwriter and former fashion model. She played [[Xenia Onatopp]] in ''[[GoldenEye]]'' (1995), [[Jean Grey]] / [[Phoenix Force (comics)|Phoenix]] in the [[X-Men (film series)|''X-Men'' film series]] (2000–2014), [[Ava Moore]] on ''[[Nip/Tuck]]'', and Lenore Mills in the [[Taken (franchise)|''Taken'' film trilogy]] (2008–2014). In 2008, she was appointed a [[Goodwill Ambassador]] for Integrity by the United Nations. She made her directorial debut with ''[[Bringing Up Bobby (2011 film)|Bringing Up Bobby]]'' in 2011. She is also known for her role in the Netflix original series ''[[Hemlock Grove (TV series)|Hemlock Grove]]'' and for her role in ABC's ''[[How To Get Away With Murder]]''. Janssen starred in the 2017 [[NBC]] [[crime thriller]] ''[[The Blacklist: Redemption]]''. == Early life and education == Famke Beumer Janssen{{cite web |url=https://movies.yahoo.com/person/famke-janssen/biography.html |title=Famke Janssen- Biography |publisher=[[Yahoo! Movies]] |accessdate=23 December 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120805213716/http://movies.yahoo.com/person/famke-janssen/biography.html |archivedate=5 August 2012}} was born {{circa|1964}}{{cite AV media | url = http://www.npo.nl/college-tour/26-09-2014/VPWON_1229976 | title = College Tour: Famke Janssen kijk je op | date = 26 September 2014 | time = 30:36 | website = npo.nl | access-date = 26 January 2015}}{{cite web | url =https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/17/arts/television/famke-janssen-plays-another-lethal-woman-in-a-blacklist-spinoff.html | title =Famke Janssen Plays Another Lethal Woman in a ‘Blacklist’ Spinoff|last =Shattuck|first =Kathryn|date = 17 February 2017 |work =The New York Times|access-date =25 February 2017 |quote = So how old are you? ... I’m 52.}} in [[Amstelveen]] in the Netherlands.{{cite web | url = http://www.filmreference.com/film/49/Famke-Janssen.html | title =Famke Janssen Biography (1964?-)| publisher = FilmReference.com | accessdate = 2 May 2016 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160303191930/http://www.filmreference.com/film/49/Famke-Janssen.html | archivedate = 3 March 2016}}{{cite news | first = Justine | last = Elias | title = Famke Janssen; Transformations As a Way of Life, Not Just on Screen | newspaper = [[The New York Times]] | date = 15 November 1998 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/15/movies/holiday-films-up-coming-famke-janssen-transformations-way-life-not-just-screen.html | accessdate = 16 October 2011}} She was given both her mother and father's surnames: Beumer and Janssen. She retained the name Janssen.{{cite web |url=http://www.newnetherlandinstitute.org/history-and-heritage/dutch_americans/famke-janssen/ |title=Famke Janssen [1965] Stage and Screen Performer |publisher=New Netherland Institute |accessdate=2 May 2016 |quote=Also note that Famke retained her family name Janssen but her sisters changed their family name to Beumer.}} She has two sisters, director [[Antoinette Beumer]] and actress [[Marjolein Beumer]], both of whom changed their surnames to simply Beumer.{{cite news | first = Jamie | last = Malanowski | title = A Scene Stealer's Big Score | newspaper = [[The New York Times]] | date = 20 August 2000 |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2000/08/20/movies/film-a-scene-stealer-s-big-score.html?pagewanted=all | accessdate = 16 October 2009}} In addition to her native Dutch, Janssen speaks English and French. She also learned German but has not kept up with it.{{cite journal | first = Drew | last = Toal | title = The Hot Seat: She's a hustler, baby | journal = [[Time Out (company)|Time Out New York]] | date = 7–13 May 2008 | url = http://www.timeout.com/newyork/articles/hot-seat/29235/famke-janssen | accessdate = 16 October 2011}} Following her high school graduation, Janssen studied economics for a year at the [[University of Amsterdam]], which she later called "the stupidest idea I ever had." In the early 1990s, she enrolled at [[Columbia University]] to study creative writing and literature. She graduated in 1992 with a Bachelor of Arts degree. == Career == ===Modelling and early 1990s=== In 1984, Janssen moved to the United States to begin her professional career as a fashion model. She signed with [[Elite Model Management]] and worked for [[Yves Saint Laurent (brand)|Yves Saint Laurent]], [[Giorgio Armani]], [[Chanel]], and [[Victoria's Secret]]. She starred in a 1988 commercial for the perfume Exclamation by [[Coty, Inc.]]{{cite web | title = Famke Janssen Exclamation perfume commercial | via = YouTube | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QZVWblJ2utI | accessdate = 16 October 2011}} Her looks have been compared to [[Hedy Lamarr]] and other 1940s films stars. After retiring from modelling in the early 1990s, Janssen had guest roles on several television series, including a starring role in the 1992 ''[[Star Trek: The Next Generation]]'' episode "[[The Perfect Mate]]", as empathic metamorph Kamala, opposite [[Patrick Stewart]], with whom she later starred in the ''X-Men'' film series. That same year, Janssen was offered the role of [[Jadzia Dax]] in ''[[Star Trek: Deep Space Nine]]'' but turned it down to pursue film roles.{{cite web|title=Famke Janssen|url=http://www.buddytv.com/info/famke-janssen-info.aspx|work=[[BuddyTV]]|accessdate=23 December 2012}} Her first film role was alongside [[Jeff Goldblum]] in the 1992 crime drama film ''[[Fathers & Sons (film)|Fathers & Sons]]''. ===1990s=== [[File:FamkeeJanssenOct08.jpg|thumb|upright|Janssen in October 2008]] In 1995, Janssen appeared in [[Pierce Brosnan]]'s first [[James Bond]] film, ''GoldenEye'', as [[femme fatale]] Xenia Onatopp. She also appeared in ''[[Lord of Illusions]]'' with [[Scott Bakula]]. In an attempt to fight against [[typecasting (acting)|typecasting]] after her [[Bond girl]] performance, Janssen began seeking out more intriguing support roles, appearing in [[John Irvin]]'s ''[[City of Industry (film)|City of Industry]]'', [[Woody Allen]]'s ''[[Celebrity (film)|Celebrity]]'', [[Robert Altman]]'s ''[[The Gingerbread Man (film)|The Gingerbread Man]]'', and [[Ted Demme]]'s ''[[Monument Ave.]]''{{cite web |url=https://www.pbs.org/kcet/tavissmiley/archive/200805/20080506_janssen.html |accessdate=16 October 2011 |title=Famke Janssen on ''Tavis Smiley'' |work=[[PBS]] |date=6 May 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100523213246/http://www.pbs.org/kcet/tavissmiley/archive/200805/20080506_janssen.html |archivedate=23 May 2010 }} [[Denis Leary]], her co-star in ''Monument Ave.'', was impressed by how easily she blended in, initially not recognizing her as she was already in character. In the late 1990s, she also appeared in ''[[The Faculty]]'', ''[[Rounders (1998 film)|Rounders]]'', ''[[Deep Rising]]'', and ''[[House on Haunted Hill (1999 film)|House on Haunted Hill]]''. ===''X-Men'' films=== In 2000, Janssen played [[superhero]] Dr. Jean Grey in the [[Marvel Studios]] film ''[[X-Men (film)|X-Men]]''. She later reprised the role in the 2003 sequel, ''[[X2 (film)|X2]]'' where her character shows signs of increasing powers but at the end of the film, she is presumably killed. Janssen returns as a very much alive Jean whose death in ''X2'' awoke her dark alternate personality, [[Phoenix Force (comics)|Phoenix]] in ''[[X-Men: The Last Stand]]'' (2006). At the end of the film, she is killed by Wolverine (played by [[Hugh Jackman]]), who only does it because Jean asks him to, not wanting to hurt anyone when Phoenix is in control. For that role, she won a [[Saturn Award for Best Supporting Actress]].{{cite web |url=http://www.newnetherlandinstitute.org/history-and-heritage/dutch_americans/famke-janssen/ |title=Famke Janssen [1965] Stage and Screen Performer |publisher=New Netherland Institute |accessdate=2 May 2016 |quote=In 2007 she won three awards, the Saturn Award for Best Supporting Actress...}} She returned as Jean in the 2013 film ''[[The Wolverine (film)|The Wolverine]]'' as a hallucination of Wolverine's.{{cite web|author1=Robert Yaniz Jr.|title=‘The Wolverine’: Hugh Jackman on Jean Grey’s Return|url=http://screenrant.com/wolverine-hugh-jackman-jean-grey-famke-janssen/|work=Screen Rant|accessdate=24 June 2014}} In 2014, Janssen reprised her role of Jean Grey in a brief cameo for ''[[X-Men: Days of Future Past (film)|X-Men: Days of Future Past]]'', as did a few of the original actors from the first three films including [[Halle Berry]], [[Kelsey Grammer]], [[Anna Paquin]] and [[James Marsden]]. In the film, Wolverine went back in time and changed the course of the future, the result being that the events of the third movie, including the deaths of Jean Grey and Cyclops, never happened.{{cite web|author1=Rob Keyes|title=Famke Janssen on ‘X-Men: Days of Future Past’ Return: ‘Stay Tuned’|url=http://screenrant.com/x-men-days-of-future-past-famke-janssen-jean-grey/|work=Screen Rant|accessdate=24 June 2014}}{{cite web|first=Marc|last=Malkin|title=X-Men: How Famke Janssen Kept Her Days of Future Past Cameo a Secret|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/546666/x-men-how-famke-janssen-kept-her-days-of-future-past-cameo-a-secret|work=[[E! News]]|date=30 May 2014|accessdate=24 June 2014}} ===2002–present=== [[File:Famke Janssen by Gage Skidmore (2) (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|Janssen at the 2013 WonderCon]] In 2002, Janssen landed the role of villainess Serleena in ''[[Men in Black II]]'', but had to abandon the film due to a death in her family and was replaced by [[Lara Flynn Boyle]].{{cite news |url=https://variety.com/2001/film/news/inside-move-janssen-out-of-mib-2-1117803054/ |title=Inside Move: Janssen out of ‘MIB:2’ |accessdate=November 27, 2017 |last=Brodesser |first= Claude|date=July 18, 2001 |work= [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]}} In addition, Janssen had a prominent role in the second season of the popular TV series ''[[Nip/Tuck]]'', as the seductive and manipulative [[life coach]] [[Ava Moore]], which earned her Hollywood Life's Breakthrough Artist of the Year Award.{{cite web|url=http://www.gettyimages.com/detail/video/famke-janssen-at-the-hollywood-life-magazines-news-footage/75783322|title=Famke Janssen at the Hollywood Life Magazine's Breakthrough of the...|publisher=Getty Images}} She reprised her role in the final two episodes of the series. In 2007, she starred in ''[[Turn the River]]'', for which she was awarded the Special Recognition Best Actress Award at the [[Hamptons International Film Festival]].{{cite web | title = 2007 Hamptons International Film Festival Awards | website = HamptonsFilmFest.org | date = 4 January 2008 | url = http://hamptonsfilmfest.org/2008/01/2007-hamptons-international-film-festival-awards/ | accessdate = 16 October 2011 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110930060723/http://hamptonsfilmfest.org/2008/01/2007-hamptons-international-film-festival-awards/ | archivedate = 30 September 2011 | df = dmy-all }} The following year, she starred in [[Luc Besson]]'s ''Taken''. Janssen also continued to work in television, appearing in TV pilots for [[NBC]]'s cop drama ''Winters'' and [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]]'s ''The Farm'', a spinoff of ''[[The L Word]]'' set in a women's prison. Both pilots were rejected by their respective networks. Janssen also provided the [[Dutch language]] narration for the Studio Tram Tour at all [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney]] theme parks. In 2011, Janssen made her directorial début with the drama ''[[Bringing Up Bobby (2011 film)|Bringing Up Bobby]]''. She also wrote the screenplay to the film, which stars [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Bill Pullman]] and [[Marcia Cross]].{{cite news | first = Joan | last = Gilmore | title = Around Town: Bobby crew at JRB gallery | newspaper = The Journal Record | date = 5 August 2010 | url = http://journalrecord.com/2010/08/05/around-town-bobby-opinion/ | accessdate = 16 October 2011}} She reprised her role as Lenore Mills in ''[[Taken 2]]'' (2012) and ''[[Taken 3]]'' (2014). She starred as the main villain Muriel in ''[[Hansel and Gretel: Witch Hunters]]'' (2013). Janssen has starred in the [[Netflix Original Programing|Netflix original]] [[horror fiction|horror]] [[thriller fiction|thriller]] television series ''[[Hemlock Grove (TV series)|Hemlock Grove]]'' since 2013 where she plays the role of family matriarch Olivia Godfrey.{{cite web|author1=Gina McIntyre|title=‘Hemlock Grove’ first look: Famke Janssen, Bill Skarsgard in Season 2|url=http://herocomplex.latimes.com/tv/hemlock-grove-first-look-famke-janssen-bill-skarsgard-in-season-2/|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=27 May 2014|accessdate=24 June 2014}} Janssen was cast in a starring role in the NBC crime thriller, ''[[The Blacklist: Redemption]]'', a spinoff of the NBC series ''[[The Blacklist (TV series)|The Blacklist]]'', in March 2016;{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2016/03/the-blacklist-spinoff-famke-janssen-star-nbc-1201728137/|title=''The Blacklist'' Spinoff Starring Famke Janssen In the Works At NBC|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=29 March 2016|accessdate=29 March 2016}} it was picked up to series in May 2016.{{cite web |first=Nellie|last=Andreeva |url=http://deadline.com/2016/05/the-blacklist-redemption-spinoff-series-cruel-intentions-nbc-title-1201755724/ |title=The Blacklist Spinoff Picked Up To Series, NBC, Cruel Intentions Alive |work=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |date=14 May 2016 |accessdate=16 May 2016}} == Personal life and activism == Janssen was married to writer and director [[Tod Williams (filmmaker)|Kip Williams]], son of architect [[Tod Williams Billie Tsien Architects|Tod Williams]], from 1995 to 2000. Janssen appeared with her dog, Licorice, a [[brindle]] [[Boston Terrier]], in a 2007 [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals|PETA]] campaign to raise awareness for animal rights. The campaign used the slogan "Be an Angel for Animals."{{cite web | title = Famke Janssen Is an Angel for Animals | publisher= [[PETA]] | url = http://www.peta2.com/OUTTHERE/o-famke.asp | accessdate = 16 October 2011}} On 28 January 2008, she was appointed a [[Goodwill Ambassador|Goodwill Ambassador for Integrity]] for the [[United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime]] at a United Nations anti-corruption conference held in [[Nusa Dua]], [[Bali]].{{cite web | title = UN Anti-Corruption Conference Opens in Bali | publisher = United Nations Information Service Vienna | date = 28 January 2008 | url = http://www.unis.unvienna.org/unis/pressrels/2008/unisnar1021.html | accessdate = 16 October 2011}} In 2016, Janssen showed frustration in not being cast in the new ''X-Men'' movie ''[[X-Men: Apocalypse]]'' saying Hollywood was sexist towards older women.{{cite journal |last=Child |first=Ben |title=Jansen said she could not understand why other X-men actors have been given older versions of themselves |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/25/famke-janssen-x-men-replacement |journal= |location= |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=25 April 2016 |access-date= 25 April 2016}} She said “Women, it’s interesting because they’re replaced, and the older versions are never to be seen again... whereas the men are allowed to be both ages.” == Filmography == === Film === {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Gringo Honasan] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160315040531/http://www.thedailypedia.com/2015/06/the-story-of-kai-and-gringo-honasan/ |date=2016-03-15 }} news magazine article with video accessed 14 March 2016 | residence = [[Manila]] | alma_mater = [[San Beda College]]
[[Philippine Military Academy]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]]) | profession = [[Soldier]] | religion = [[Christian]] |allegiance = {{flag|Philippines|1986}} |branch= [[Philippine Army]] |serviceyears=1971–1989 |rank= Colonel |unit= |battles=[[Insurgency in the Philippines]] |awards=Presidential Government Medal
Distinguished Conduct Star }} '''Gregorio Ballesteros Honasan II''' (born March 14, 1948), better known as '''Gringo Honasan''', is a retired [[Philippine Army]] officer who led unsuccessful [[coup d'état|coups d'état]] against President [[Corazon Aquino]]. He played a key role in the [[1986 EDSA Revolution]] that toppled President [[Ferdinand Marcos]]. After 1986, he led a series of unsuccessful but violent coup attempts against the administration of [[Corazon Aquino]]. President [[Fidel Ramos]] granted him amnesty in 1992. He entered politics and became a [[Philippine Senator|senator]] from 1995 to 2004 and again since 2007. He ran for vice president of the Philippines, being [[Jejomar Binay]]'s running-mate in 2016, but were defeated by [[Leni Robredo]] and [[Rodrigo Duterte]] respectively. ==Early life== Gregorio Honasan was born in [[Baguio City]] to Colonel Romeo Gillego Honasan and Alicia "Alice" Masip Ballesteros, both from [[Sorsogon]] province.[http://www.senate.gov.ph/senators/former_senators/gregorio_honasan.htm Senate of the Philippines - Gregorio Honasan] Honasan spent his elementary days at [[San Beda College]] from Kindergarten to Grade 6. After which, he went to Taiwan and studied at the [[Dominican International School|Dominican School]], Taipei, Taiwan. He then returned to the Philippines and finished his high school at [[Don Bosco Technical College]]. He attained his [[Bachelor of Science]] degree at the [[Philippine Military Academy]], where he received the title of "Class Baron", the academy's highest leadership award. ==Military career== After graduating in 1971, he joined the [[Armed Forces of the Philippines|Philippine Army's]] [[special forces]], [[Scout Ranger Regiment]] and went into combat against separatist and communist insurgents in [[Luzon]] and [[Mindanao]]. He was wounded in action at battles in [[Lebak, Sultan Kudarat|Lebak]] and [[Jolo, Sulu|Jolo]]. Making his way up through the armed forces, he became [[aide-de-camp]] to Defense Minister [[Juan Ponce Enrile]] in 1974, and later became the Defense Ministry's Chief of Security. Concurrent with his position as security chief, he was a board member of the Northern Mindanao Development Bank and president of the Beatriz Marketing Company.{{Cite web |url=http://www.i-site.ph/Databases/Congress/12thSenate/personal/honasan-personal.html |title=i-site.ph - Gregorio Honasan |access-date=2006-02-24 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051224205813/http://www.i-site.ph/Databases/Congress/12thSenate/personal/honasan-personal.html |archive-date=2005-12-24 |dead-url=yes |df= }} ==Political career== ===People Power=== In 1986, Honasan and a cabal of colonels, backed by Enrile, tried to use popular unrest to overthrow the [[dictatorship]] of President [[Ferdinand Marcos]].[http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/storypage.aspx?StoryID=56268 Honasan: Anti-Marcos poster boy turned coup leader]{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} When the plot was uncovered, the conspirators sought refuge in the military headquarters and called on civilians, the media, and the [[Catholic Church]] for protection. Hundreds of thousands of people served as human shields to protect Honasan and his men from Marcos' forces, sparking the 1986 [[People Power Revolution]] that led to Marcos' fall from power and the installation of [[Corazon Aquino]] as president. ===Coups d'état=== {{regchangeRP}} Aquino awarded Honasan a Distinguished Conduct Star for the EDSA Revolution and the Presidential Government Medal in 1986. Under the new government, he was head of a special group in the defense ministry. Using his position, he was covertly involved in various coup attempts against Aquino. On August 28, 1987, fighting broke out in the streets and Honasan ordered his men to attack government installations, resulting in the deaths of dozens, including many civilians. The attack was put down by government forces, but Honasan was able to escape. He was later captured and imprisoned on a Navy ship in [[Manila Bay]]. He later escaped once again by convincing his guards to join his cause. ===Senate=== {{main|Jejomar Binay presidential campaign, 2016}} Philippine President [[Fidel Ramos]], who was elected in 1992, granted [[amnesty]] to his comrade Honasan. Honasan utilized his rebel infamy to enter politics in 1995, becoming the first independent candidate in Philippine history to win a seat in the [[Senate of the Philippines|Senate]]. He was re-elected in 2001, filled the vacant seat left by Senator [[Teofisto Guingona Jr.]], who was appointed by President [[Gloria Macapagal Arroyo]] as [[Vice President of the Philippines|Vice President]]. From April 30 to May 1, 2001, together with [[Juan Ponce Enrile]], [[Miriam Defensor Santiago]], [[Panfilo Lacson]] and [[Vicente Sotto III]], he led the [[EDSA III]] protests in support of [[Joseph Estrada]].{{cite news|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/90521/miriam-gma-resign-or-we-will-storm-palace|title= Miriam to GMA: Resign or we will storm palace |publisher=''[[Philippine Star]]''|date=April 30, 2001|accessdate=April 27, 2016}} On May 1, 2001, the protesters stormed [[Malacañang Palace]].{{cite news|url=http://www.rappler.com/newsbreak/in-depth/104045-edsa-3-iglesia-ni-cristo|title= Remembering the Iglesia-led EDSA 3 |publisher=''[[Rappler]]''|date=August 25, 2015|accessdate=April 27, 2016}} He left the Senate when the term expired in 2004. In the [[Philippine general election, 2007|general election]] held in May 2007, he was again elected to the Senate. Running as an [[Independent (politician)|independent candidate]], he polled some 11.6 million votes, finishing 10th out of 37 candidates for 12 Senate vacancies. He took up his post on June 30. He was reelected during the [[Philippine Senate election, 2013|2013 elections]], placing twelfth, his fourth consecutive term. On June 2015, Justice Undersecretary Justiniano amended the complaint against Senator Honasan for his alleged part in the [[Pork Barrel Scam]] involving allegations of corrupt malversation of public funds. Following the alleged collapse of talks between UNA presidential candidate [[Jejomar Binay]] Honasan became Binay's running mate. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130226092144/http://honasankana.squarespace.com/ Official campaign site of Gregorio Honasan] *[http://www.rappler.com/nation/politics/elections/2016/108938-gringo-honasan-leader-i-want] {{Candidates in the Philippine presidential election, 2016}} {{navboxes |title = Senatorial history of Gregorio Honasan II |list= {{PhilSenMajority}} {{10th Congress of the Philippines senators}} {{11th Congress of the Philippines senators}} {{12th Congress of the Philippines senators}} {{14th Congress of the Philippines senators}} {{15th Congress of the Philippines senators}} {{16th Congress of the Philippines senators}} {{17th Congress of the Philippines senators}} }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Honasan, Gregorio}} [[Category:1948 births]] [[Category:Independent politicians in the Philippines]] [[Category:Bicolano politicians]] [[Category:Filipino military personnel]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Baguio]] [[Category:People from Sorsogon]] [[Category:Philippine Army personnel]] [[Category:Philippine Military Academy alumni]] [[Category:Recipients of the Distinguished Conduct Star]] [[Category:Reform the Armed Forces Movement]] [[Category:Philippine vice-presidential candidates, 2016]] [[Category:Senators of the 10th Congress of the Philippines]] [[Category:Senators of the 11th Congress of the Philippines]] [[Category:Senators of the 12th Congress of the Philippines]] [[Category:Senators of the 14th Congress of the Philippines]] [[Category:Senators of the 15th Congress of the Philippines]] [[Category:Senators of the 16th Congress of the Philippines]] [[Category:Senators of the 17th Congress of the Philippines]] [[Category:United Nationalist Alliance politicians]] [[Category:People of the People Power Revolution]]
