4 daughters |education = [[United States Military Academy]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Science|BS]])}}
[[Yale University]] {{small|([[Juris Doctor|JD]])}}
[[University of Alaska Fairbanks|University of Alaska, Fairbanks]] {{small|([[Master of Arts|MA]])}} |allegiance = {{flag|United States}} |branch = {{army|United States}} |serviceyears = 1989–1992 Army
1992–1997 Army Reserves |rank = [[File:US-O3 insignia.svg|15px]] [[Captain (United States)|Captain]] |unit = [[File:United States Army 1st Infantry Division CSIB.svg|14px]] [[1st Infantry Division (United States)|1st Infantry Division]]
[[United States Army Reserve]] |battles = [[Gulf War]] |mawards = [[Bronze Star]] }} '''Joseph Wayne Miller''' (born May 10, 1967) is an [[United States|American]] attorney and politician. Miller rose to national prominence as the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] nominee and the [[Tea Party movement|Tea Party]] favorite in the [[United States Senate election in Alaska, 2010|2010 U.S. Senate election in Alaska]]. He faced [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] [[Scott McAdams]] and incumbent Republican Senator [[Lisa Murkowski]] who, after losing the primary to Miller, mounted a large and well-funded campaign as a [[write-in]] candidate in the general election and went on to win the Senate seat. Before running for the Senate, Miller worked as an attorney in private general practice, a local government attorney, and a [[United States magistrate judge|U.S. magistrate judge]] assisting the Alaska federal district court with its caseload. A 1995 graduate of [[Yale Law School]], he was a combat veteran of the [[1991 Gulf War]], and a graduate of the [[United States Military Academy|U.S. Military Academy]] at West Point. He is originally from [[Kansas]] and the father of eight children; he and his wife and family moved to Alaska in the mid-1990s. Miller sought the Republican nomination to challenge incumbent Democratic Senator [[Mark Begich]] in 2014, but was defeated by [[Dan Sullivan (senator)|Dan Sullivan]] in the [[United States Senate election in Alaska, 2014#Republican primary|Republican primary]].{{cite web|title=Joe Miller Files Papers for Senate|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2013/05/joe-miller-alaska-senate-2014-91960.html?hp=r5/|work=Joe Miller Files Papers for Senate|accessdate=2013-05-31}}{{cite web|url=http://www.elections.alaska.gov/results/14PRIM/data/results.htm|title=2014 Primary Elections August 19, 2014 Unofficial Results|publisher=State of Alaska Division of Elections|accessdate=August 20, 2014}} Cean Stevens, the Libertarian party primary winner, stepped aside to allow Miller to receive the [[Libertarian Party of Alaska|Libertarian]] nomination, so that Miller could run in the crowded [[United States Senate election in Alaska, 2016|2016 Senate election]]. He placed second in the general election, receiving just under 30% of the vote.[http://www.adn.com/politics/2016/09/06/joe-miller-to-run-as-libertarian-in-hopes-of-unseating-us-sen-lisa-murkowski/ Joe Miller to run as Libertarian in hopes of unseating U.S. Senator Lisa Murkowski], ''[[Alaska Dispatch News]], Nathaniel Herz and Erica Martinson, September 6, 2016. Retrieved 22 September 2016. ==Early life and education== Miller was born and raised in [[Osborne, Kansas|Osborne]], [[Kansas]], the son of Sharry and Rex Miller.{{cite news|url=http://www.hutchnews.com/Localregional/miller-s-KS-connection--2|title=Alaskan candidate has deep Kan. roots|author=Mary Clarkin|date=September 1, 2010|publisher=The Hutchinson News|location=Hutchinson, Kansas|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719032503/http://www.hutchnews.com/Localregional/miller-s-KS-connection--2|archivedate=July 19, 2011|df=}} His father was a [[Minister (Christianity)|minister]] who owned a Christian book and gift store. He attended elementary school in [[Salina, Kansas]] and [[Salina High School Central|Salina Central High School]], participating in debate, forensics, and student congress, and graduating in 1985. He has said that growing up during the [[Vietnam War]] era made him aware of the military, and eventually led to his enrollment at the [[United States Military Academy]] at [[West Point, New York|West Point]] in 1985.{{cite news|url=http://www.newsminer.com/view/full_story/10030190/article-Joe-Miller-promotes-his-military-experience-at-Fairbanks-meet?instance=local_news|title=Joe Miller promotes his military experience|date=October 26, 2010|author=Chris Freiberg|newspaper=Fairbanks Daily News-Miner|accessdate=November 3, 2010}} While at West Point, he was a member of the Officer's Christian Fellowship and the Hunting and Fishing and Survival Games clubs.{{cite news|author= William Yardley|title=Alaska Winner, Lover of Privacy, Loses His Own|date=September 3, 2010|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/04/us/politics/04alaska.html|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=September 5, 2010}} Miller later graduated from [[Yale Law School]] with a [[Juris Doctor]] degree.http://alaskadispatch.com/dispatches/politics/6617-at-yale-law-school-joe-miller-discovers-federalist-society ==Career== Miller served three years of active duty in the [[United States Army]]. An armor officer, he served in the [[34th Armor Regiment (United States)|2nd Battalion, 34th Armor Regiment]] within the [[1st Infantry Division (United States)|1st Infantry Division]]https://web.archive.org/web/20101028220701/http://joemiller.us/about-2/candidate-records/ at [[Fort Riley]], [[Kansas]]. In 1991 Miller deployed to the Persian [[Gulf War]], where he served as a leader of a [[tank]] platoon that helped drive [[Saddam Hussein]]'s army from [[Kuwait]].{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/sep/07/nation/la-na-alaska-miller-20100907|title=For Alaska's restive right, it's Joe Miller time|date=September 7, 2010|author=Kim Murphy|newspaper= Los Angeles Times}} His superiors called him "a true warrior leader tested under fire" and he received a [[Bronze Star]] for leadership in combat. He has a service-connected hearing loss.{{cite news|url=http://www.adn.com/2010/10/29/1526299/joe-miller-out-to-change-dc.html|title=Joe Miller: Out to change D.C.|author=Sean Cockerham|date=October 30, 2010}} He was honorably discharged on September 1, 1992, during a time when the U.S. was downsizing its military. He then served in the [[United States Army Reserve|U.S. Army Reserve]] until his honorable discharge on May 30, 1997.https://web.archive.org/web/20101028232613/http://joemiller.us/download/Honorable_Discharge_Army_Reserves.pdf Following his discharge from active duty, Miller attended [[Yale Law School]], where he was a member of the flagship chapter of the [[Federalist Society]].{{cite news|url=http://alaskadispatch.com/dispatches/politics/6617-at-yale-law-school-joe-miller-discovers-federalist-society|title=At Yale Law School, Joe Miller discovers Federalist Society|author=Joshua Saul and Amanda Coyne|publisher=''Alaska Dispatch''|date=August 30, 2010}} He moved to Alaska in 1995 after earning his law degree, and accepted a position with Condon Partnow & Sharrock, a [[law firm]] in [[Anchorage]].{{cite news|title=Fairbanks attorney files to run against Sen. Lisa Murkowski |newspaper=Fairbanks Daily News-Miner |date=April 19, 2010 |url=http://www.newsminer.com/view/full_story/7148533/article-Fairbanks-attorney-files-to-run-against-Sen--Lisa-Murkowski |author=Staff reporter |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5uxxx3ehY?url=http://www.newsminer.com/view/full_story/7148533/article-Fairbanks-attorney-files-to-run-against-Sen--Lisa-Murkowski |archivedate=December 14, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} During Miller's Senate campaign, Alaskan media criticized him for his 1995 sworn application in which he claimed to be indigent and a one-year continuous resident of Alaska to obtain a hunting and fishing license for $5, a $295 discount from the non-resident fee.{{cite news|url=http://alaskadispatch.com/voices/medred/6986-joe-millers-hunting-and-fishing-license-likely-violated-residency-requirement|title=Joe Miller's hunting and fishing license likely violated residency requirement|author=Craig Medred|date=September 28, 2010|newspaper=Alaska Dispatch}} The campaign responded that Miller had been a full-time student the previous year living on student loans, and that he was an Alaska resident when he purchased the license. Miller was appointed a state court magistrate for the remote village of [[Tok, Alaska|Tok]], as well as a superior court master for the Alaska's Fourth Judicial District in 1998. During his U.S. Senate campaign, Miller, who had said federal entitlement programs are unconstitutional, was criticized for having received federal assistance from Medicaid and a federally funded Alaska health care program for low income families at this time of his life. His campaign responded that Miller had not received the aid since 2002. Miller said he did not oppose the state program itself, but did oppose its expansion.{{cite news|url=http://community.adn.com/adn/node/153548|title= Joe Miller says he received Medicaid, Denali KidCare|author=Alaska Politics Staff|date=October 7, 2010|publisher=Anchorage Daily News}} In 2002, after moving to Fairbanks, Miller was appointed an acting state District Court judge for several months. From 2002 to 2004 he also served as a part-time [[U.S. magistrate judge]], employing his wife for part of that time as a clerical assistant.{{cite news|url=http://articles.ktuu.com/2010-10-04/nepotism_24130018|title=Miller responds to allegations of nepotism |date=October 4, 2010|publisher=KTUU-TV|author=Rhonda McBride|accessdate=September 18, 2014}} In 2010, while Miller was being scrutinized by the media, allegations were made that he had violated nepotism rules by hiring his wife, and he was criticized because she collected unemployment compensation after being forced to quit the job. Miller responded that the nepotism rules were different at the time she was hired, and the court verified that he initially had clearance from his superiors to employ her.{{cite news|url=http://www.adn.com/article/court-answers-questions-about-millers-judgeship-0|title=Court answers questions about Miller's judgeship|author=Jill Burke|date=October 8, 2010|publisher=Alaska Dispatch}} Miller's former supervising judge on the federal court later criticized Miller for quitting the federal magistrate job without notice in 2004, saying it left Fairbanks without a judicial officer for many months, and gave him a "negative opinion" of Miller.{{cite news|url=http://www.adn.com/2010/11/10/1547601/judge-with-negative-opinion-of.html|title=Judge with 'negative opinion' of Miller bows out of write-in case QUIT: Republican nominee left his job without notice when Sedwick was his supervisor|author=Richard Mauer|newspaper=Anchorage Daily News}} Miller spent seven years as a part-time assistant attorney for the [[Fairbanks North Star Borough, Alaska|Fairbanks North Star Borough]] (2002–2009) while maintaining a private law practice from which he earned the bulk of his income. One of his major cases as borough assistant attorney involved successfully defending the borough's levy of a tax increase on the companies that own the [[Trans-Alaska Pipeline System|Trans-Alaska Pipeline]]. In 2008 he misused the borough's computers for political purposes (to pad a poll as part of his campaign for Republican Party state chair).{{cite news|url=http://www.adn.com/2010/10/13/1500580/borough-mayor-calls-miller-dishonest.html|title=Ex-mayor says Miller disciplined over ethics|date=October 14, 2010|work=Anchorage Daily News|author=Sean Cockerham and Richard Mauer}} He was disciplined for his actions and for lying about them when first confronted by his superiors, facts that became public knowledge during the last ten days of the 2010 Senate campaign.{{cite news|author=William Yardley|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/30/us/politics/30alaska.html|title=Palin Renews Support for Miller in Alaska Race|newspaper=The New York Times|date=October 29, 2010|accessdate=October 29, 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://www.alaskadispatch.com/dispatches/politics/7283-miller-i-lied-about-accessing-all-of-the-computers |title=Miller: 'I lied about accessing all of the computers'|publisher=Alaska Dispatch|date=October 27, 2010|accessdate=October 27, 2010|author=Jill Burke and Patti Epler}} His supervisor said that Miller was under stress at the time.{{cite news|author=Becky Bohrer|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/politics/2013264853_apusalaskasenatemillerrecords.html|title=Records: Miller admits to computer use, lying|newspaper=The Seattle Times|date=October 27, 2010|accessdate=November 5, 2010}} He resigned from the assistant attorney post in September 2009 over disputes involving a possible conflict of interest in a case and his request for time off under the [[Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993|Family and Medical Leave Act]].{{cite news|title= Miller admitted lies, deleted borough e-mails|author= Sean Cockerham|newspaper=Anchorage Daily News|date=October 27, 2010|url= http://www.adn.com/2010/10/26/1520106/miller-admits-to-lies-about-his.html|accessdate=November 1, 2010}} As of early December 2010, the borough was considering pursuing charges against Miller for deleting more than 15,000 e-mails in the days following his resignation. Miller's attorney responded that it was routine to delete non-essential e-mails and that the borough's inquiries were an attempt to threaten a candidate and illegally interfere with an election.{{cite news|url=http://newsminer.com/bookmark/10531354-Fairbanks-borough-investigates-missing-Miller-e-mails|title=Fairbanks borough investigates missing Miller e-mails|author=Amanda Bohman|date=December 4, 2010|publisher=Fairbanks Daily News-Miner}}{{cite news|url=http://alaskadispatch.com/dispatches/politics/7710-the-case-of-joe-millers-missing-e-mails|title=The case of Joe Miller's missing e-mails|author=Jill Burke|date=December 2, 2010|newspaper=The Alaska Dispatch}} The Alaska Republican Party chair, Randy Ruedrich, said the borough was engaging in "cheap drama". In 2008 Miller earned a [[master's degree]] in [[Natural resource economics|Resource]] and [[Applied Economics]] from the [[University of Alaska Fairbanks]].{{cite web|url=http://www.uaf.edu/files/commence/2008/degree/som.html#master|title=Commencement 2008 Degree Candidates|publisher=University of Alaska Fairbanks|accessdate=November 5, 2010}} He currently lives in Fairbanks, where he owns a law practice.{{cite web|url=http://www.linkedin.com/in/joewmiller|title=Profile: Joe Miller|publisher=LinkedIn}} ==2004 and 2008 political activities== In 2004 Miller ran for a seat in the [[Alaska House of Representatives]], winning the Republican primary. He ran as a moderate Republican in the general election, but lost to Democratic incumbent [[David Guttenberg]].{{cite news|url=http://www.juneauempire.com/stories/100810/loc_717574213.shtml|title=Conservative star Miller ran as a moderate before|author=Pat Forgey|newspaper=Juneau Empire|date=October 8, 2010|accessdate=October 18, 2010}}{{cite news|title=Fairbanks Republican seeks support from conservatives|author=Sean Cockerham|date=May 3, 2010|work=Anchorage Daily News|url=http://www.adn.com/2010/05/03/1261898/fairbanks-republican-seeks-support.html}} In 2008, while serving as Interior regional chairman of the Alaska Republican Party, he unsuccessfully tried to oust Randy Ruedrich as the state Republican Party chairman. The ''Alaska Dispatch'' described Miller's effort as part of a power struggle between "the old guard versus the new Palin-led faction", reporting that Miller arrived at the state Republican Party convention accompanied by a security detail of four bodyguards.{{cite news|url=http://www.alaskadispatch.com/dispatches/politics/7342-millers-paranoia-at-fairbanks-borough-ran-deeper-than-records-reveal|title=Joe Miller's paranoid attempt to overthrow the Alaska Republican Party|author=Jill Burke|publisher=Alaska Dispatch|date=October 31, 2010|accessdate=November 3, 2010}} Miller resigned his regional chairmanship and temporarily quit the GOP the day after the 2008 convention. ==2010 Senate campaign== {{Infobox U.S. federal election campaign |committee=Joe Miller for Senate 2010 |logo= |campaign=[[United States Senate election in Alaska, 2010|U.S. Senator from Alaska]] |candidate=Joe Miller |cand_id=S0AK00121 |fec_date=October 13, 2010 |status=[[United States Senate election in Alaska, 2010|Conceded defeat]] |affiliation=[[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] |headquarters=[[Fairbanks, Alaska|Fairbanks]], [[Alaska]], [[United States|U.S.]] |key_people=Randy DeSoto |receipts=1,980,296 }} {{See also|United States Senate election in Alaska, 2010}} ===Republican primary election=== Miller announced his candidacy in April 2010 saying that the U.S. republic needed to be defended from a "head-long plunge into socialism and more government control". His chief opponent for the Republican nomination was incumbent U.S. Senator Murkowski. He quickly picked up endorsements from current and former Alaska politicians including State Senators Fred Dyson and [[John Coghill]], and State Representative [[Tammie Wilson]]. Former Governor [[Sarah Palin]] endorsed Miller's candidacy in early June 2010.{{cite news|title=Palin Endorses GOP Challenger in Alaska Senate|agency=Associated Press |newspaper=U.S. News & World Report|author=AP staff reporter|date=June 3, 2010|url=http://politics.usnews.com/news/articles/2010/06/03/palin-endorses-gop-challenger-in-alaska-senate.html|accessdate=November 5, 2010}} The [[Tea Party Express]] began funding TV, radio, and direct mail ads on Miller's behalf shortly after, spending $600,000 on what the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' called a "blitz" of "attack ads" against Murkowski.{{cite news|title='Tea party' group behind defeat of GOP Senate incumbent in Alaska|date=September 1, 2010|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/sep/01/nation/la-na-alaska-vote-20100902|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=September 2, 2010|authors=Kathleen Hennessey and Michael A. Memoli}} Miller said he spent approximately $100,000 of his own funds on the primary campaign. ''[[The New York Times]]'' described Murkowski as an establishment candidate and called Miller a "Tea Party upstart",{{cite news|author=William Yardley and Carl Hulse|title=In Alaska, Murkowski Trails Tea Party Upstart|date=August 25, 2010|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/26/us/politics/26primaries.html|work=[[New York Times]]|accessdate=August 25, 2010}} and the race was viewed as a test of the power of the [[Tea party movement]].{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2010/08/alaskas-senate-primary-a-test-of-tea-party-money/61977/|title=Alaska's Senate Primary: A Test of Tea Party Money|author=Chris Good|date=August 24, 2010|publisher=The Atlantic}}{{cite news|author=AP staff reporter|title=Murkowski-Miller contest for Alaska Senate too close to call|date=August 24, 2010|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/politics/2010-08-25-alaska-senate_N.htm?csp=34news|accessdate=August 25, 2010|agency=Associated Press|newspaper=USA Today}} Miller won the August 24 primary by garnering 1,668 more votes than Murkowski, according to the initial count. Murkowski did not concede until one week later when, after more than 15,000 absentee and other uncounted ballots were tallied, she still remained 1,630 votes behind Miller.{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2010/08/31/sen-lisa-murkowski-concedes-alaska-primary-race-joe-miller/|title=US Sen. Lisa Murkowski concedes Alaska primary race to Joe Miller|date=August 31, 2010|author=AP staff reporter|agency=Associated Press|publisher=''Fox News''}} ===General election=== [[File:Joe Miller Alaska 1.jpg|thumb|right|Joe Miller campaigning in September 2010]] Miller faced two candidates in the general election, Democrat [[Scott McAdams]], and Lisa Murkowski, who announced a write-in campaign on September 17.{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-09-18/murkowski-says-she-will-run-as-write-in-candidate-in-senate-race-in-alaska.html|title=Murkowski Says She Will Run as Write-In Candidate in Senate Race in Alaska|author=John McCormick and Patrick O'Connor|date=September 17, 2010|publisher=''Bloomberg News''}} After securing the Republican Party nomination, he received backing from the state Republican Party, Senator [[Jim DeMint]], and the [[National Republican Senatorial Committee]]. Various groups from outside Alaska endorsed Miller and contributed large sums of money to his general election campaign, including the [[Tea Party Express]], the [[Safari Club International]], and the [[National Right to Life Committee]].{{cite news|url=http://community.adn.com/adn/node/153506|title=Miller draws additional outside interest group money from hunting, anti-abortion interests|author=Erika Bolstad|newspaper=Anchorage Daily News|date=October 6, 2010}} Alaska's only representative in the House, Republican [[Don Young]], declined to endorse either Murkowski or Miller. Sarah Palin appeared at a campaign rally with Miller for the first time in late October 2010. During his general election campaign, Miller said he supported sharp reductions in federal spending and stronger states' rights. He told the Washington D.C. newspaper ''The Hill'' that the nation's problems were caused by [[judicial activism|activist judges]] who had permitted government growth and allowed dependency and "the entitlement state to grab hold".{{cite news|author=Jordan Fabian|title=Before election, Miller eyes Senate posts|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/116907-before-election-miller-eyes-committee-posts|date=September 2, 2010|work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|accessdate=September 2, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5uxy79Y1n?url=http://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/116907-before-election-miller-eyes-committee-posts|archivedate=December 14, 2010|deadurl=yes}} The [[Democratic National Committee]] and other Democrats began painting him as a [[Far-right politics|far right]] candidate. Confident of his election, Miller told the media that he wanted to serve on the Senate Judiciary and Armed Services committees. Following a mid-October leak of information about his work record as a borough attorney, Miller held a news conference telling reporters that he was drawing a line in the sand and would not answer any more questions about his past.{{cite news|url=http://sify.com/news/miller-refuses-to-answer-questions-about-past-news-international-kkoaa8hbgid.html|title=Miller refuses to answer questions about his past|author=Staff|date=October 14, 2010|agency=Associated Press|publisher=SiFy.com|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5ueE5SHW4?url=http://sify.com/news/miller-refuses-to-answer-questions-about-past-news-international-kkoaa8hbgid.html|archivedate=December 1, 2010|deadurl=yes}} ====Journalist handcuffed==== Miller received national press attention after campaign security guards handcuffed and made a 30-minute private arrest of a [[Journalism|journalist]] following a [[Town hall meeting|town hall]] campaign event in an Anchorage public school on October 17, 2010.{{cite news|url=http://www.adn.com/2010/10/17/1506223/miller-security-guards-handcuff.html|title=Miller security guards handcuff journalist Public Event: Incident took place after town hall meeting at middle school|date=October 18, 2010|author=Richard Mauer|newspaper=Anchorage Daily News|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101019014343/http://www.adn.com/2010/10/17/1506223/miller-security-guards-handcuff.html|archivedate=October 19, 2010|df=}}{{cite news|url=http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/10/18/news-editor-detained-by-guards-for-alaska-senate-candidate/|title=News Editor Detained by Security Guards for Alaska Senate Candidate|author=William Yardley|date=October 18, 2010|newspaper=The New York Times}}{{cite news|title=Miller guard says editor refused to leave private event|url=http://alaskadispatch.com/dispatches/news/7187-miller-guard-says-editor-refused-to-leave-private-event|author=Craig Medred|publisher=''Alaska Dispatch''|date=October 17, 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://alaskadispatch.com/dispatches/news/7186-alaska-dispatch-editor-detained-at-miller-event-updated|title=Dispatch editor detained at Miller event|date=October 17, 2010|author=Craig Medred|publisher=''Alaska Dispatch''}}{{cite news|url=http://www.ktuu.com/news/ktuu-2010elect-miller-security-hopfinger-arrest-101710,0,2454854.story|title=Miller security handcuffs journalist at town hall|date=October 17, 2010|author=Jackie Bartz|publisher=KTUU-TV}} Bill Fulton, the owner of the unlicensed security firm said the journalist, Tony Hopfinger, was trespassing at a private event and had assaulted a Miller supporter by shoving him. Fulton was subsequently named as the federal informant who supplied weapons to a radical accused of plotting the deaths of officials in Fairbanks.{{cite web |url=http://tpmmuckraker.talkingpointsmemo.com/bill-fulton/2011/11/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-12-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120413020828/http://tpmmuckraker.talkingpointsmemo.com/bill-fulton/2011/11/ |archivedate=2012-04-13 |df= }} The ''Anchorage Daily News'' described the event as public, and a school district spokesperson noted that the hallway where the arrest took place was a public area.{{cite news|author=Richard Mauer|url=http://www.adn.com/2010/10/18/1507982/questions-surround-use-of-security.html|title=Miller bodyguards at forum included active-duty soldiers|newspaper=Anchorage Daily News|date=October 18, 2010|accessdate=November 3, 2010}} Hopfinger said he had been trying to ask Miller whether he had been disciplined while working as a local government lawyer, when he was suddenly surrounded by guards and supporters, and bumped or shoved against one of them. No charges were filed against anyone in relation to the incident.{{cite news|author=Richard Mauer|url=http://www.adn.com/2010/10/19/1509238/no-charges-to-be-filed-after-sunday.html|title=City won't prosecute in Miller forum scuffle|newspaper=Anchorage Daily News|date=October 20, 2010|accessdate=November 3, 2010}} Miller responded that Hopfinger's actions were "beyond the pale" because he had followed Miller into the men's room.{{cite web|author=Matt Felling |url=http://www.ktva.com/ci_16370971?source=pkg|title=Miller: Blogger Followed "Me into the Bathroom" |publisher=KTVA |date=October 18, 2010|accessdate=October 27, 2010}} Hopfinger said that he asked no questions until after the townhall event when both men were back in the hallway. After the incident, Miller granted interviews and discussed certain issues regarding his past employment with national news outlets, though he had previously refused to discuss the same issues with the Alaskan media.{{cite news|author=Sean Cockerham|url=http://www.adn.com/2010/10/18/1507733/miller-admits-borough-disciplined.html|title=Miller admits he was disciplined by borough over computer use|newspaper=Anchorage Daily News|date=October 19, 2010|accessdate=November 3, 2010}} The information about Miller's discipline and suspension that Hopfinger was attempting to ask Miller about was released by the borough on October 26, in response to a lawsuit filed by several Alaska news organizations. ====Allegations of media bias==== In late October 2010, Sarah Palin announced on [[Fox News Channel]] that the Anchorage CBS-TV affiliate, KTVA, had been conspiring to make up stories about Miller and that the campaign had proof.{{cite news|title=KTVA-TV cancels 2 newscasts so staff can discuss ethics, VOICE MAIL: Channel 11 staffers address trust issues in wake of bias accusations|author=Casey Grove|date=November 11, 2010|url=http://www.adn.com/2010/11/10/1547664/ktva-cancels-newscasts-so-staff.html#ixzz154XUMLLp|accessdate=November 12, 2010}} It seemed that KTVA personnel had failed to hang up a phone after leaving a message for Miller's campaign spokesman and that their later comments were recorded on the spokesman's voicemail.{{cite news|author=Vauhini Vara|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2010/10/31/phone-recording-sets-off-firestorm-in-alaska|title=Phone Recording Sets Off Firestorm in Alaska|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=October 31, 2010|accessdate=November 3, 2010}} During the conversation, they laughingly considered [[Twitter|tweeting]] about chaos at a Miller rally, and falsely reporting that sex offenders were there. The station's general manager initially took no action, saying the remarks were taken out of context,{{Cite news|author=Greg Sargent|title = Alaska station says Breitbart Web site audio attack is bogus|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 31, 2010|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/plum-line/2010/10/alaska_station_denies_big_gove.html|accessdate=November 1, 2010}} but he later fired two producers involved, and canceled two newscasts to hold a staff meeting discussing ethics in journalism.{{cite news|url=http://articles.ktuu.com/2010-11-02/alaska-cbs_24811178|title=KTVA fires 2 producers over Miller voicemail|author=Jackie Bartz|date=November 2, 2010|publisher=KTUU}} ====Election result==== {{for|details on Miller's lawsuits|Miller v. Campbell}} On November 3, the winner remained undetermined; write-in ballots comprised 41% of the vote, Miller had 34%, and McAdams had 24%. McAdams later conceded, but the result required a hand-count of the write-in ballots to see what names were written on them.{{cite news|url=http://alaskadispatch.com/dispatches/politics/7387-mcadams-concedes-senate-race-we-left-everything-out-on-the-field|title=McAdams concedes Senate race: 'We left everything out on the field'|author=Joshua Saul |date=November 3, 2010|accessdate=November 11, 2010}} Miller's campaign manager announced that several teams, including attorneys, would be going to Alaska to watch the ballot count.{{cite news|url=http://www.adn.com/2010/11/02/1533320/miller-teams-of-lawyers-to-watch.html|title=Teams of Miller lawyers to watch Senate write-in count|author=Becky Bohrer|date=November 2, 2010|agency=Associated Press|newspaper=Anchorage Daily News}} Miller gained about 2,100 votes in the count of absentee ballots that was done on November 9 in Juneau, and trailed the write-in votes by 11,333 at the end of the day. The hand count of the write-in ballots began on November 10. After two days, the Alaska Division of Elections had examined about 48 percent of the ballots and had tallied about 98 percent of them as votes for Murkowski, despite objections from Miller's team of observers{{cite news|url=http://www.ktuu.com/news/ktuu-2010elect-miller-voter-fraud-state-lawsuit-111110,0,6134122.story|title=Miller campaign plans to sue state over alleged voter fraud|author=Jason Lamb|date=November 11, 2010|publisher=KTUU-TV}} to spelling errors, legibility, and additional words such as "Republican". When the last of the more than 100,000 write-in votes were counted on November 17, the [[Associated Press]] and the Republican Party of Alaska called the race for Murkowski.{{cite news|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/politics/2013461497_murkowski18.html|title=Murkowski triumphs in Alaska Senate race: Alaska's Murkowski appears to be first write-in candidate to win Senate since 1954|author=Seattle Times news services|publisher=The Seattle Times|date=November 17, 2010|accessdate=November 18, 2010}}{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2010/11/17/131391244/ap-murkowski-wins-alaska-senate-race|title=AP: Murkowski Wins Alaska Senate Race|author=AP staff reporter|agency=Associated Press|date=November 17, 2010|publisher=NPR}} At that point, Murkowski's lead was more than 2,000 votes larger than the number of ballots challenged by Miller.{{cite news|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2013330853_apusalaskasenate.html?syndication=rss|title=In Alaska, fierce ballot-by-ballot count looms|author=Becky Bohrer|agency=Associated Press|date=November 3, 2010|newspaper=The Seattle Times|accessdate=Sep 18, 2014}}{{cite news|url=http://www.adn.com/2010/11/09/1545716/miller-sues-to-force-exact-spelling.html|title=Count continues; Miller sues over spelling: NO LEEWAY: Campaign says intent doesn't make write-in vote legitimate|author=Kyle Hopkins and Sean Cockerham|newspaper=Anchorage Daily News|date=November 9, 2010|accessdate=November 10, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101110171039/http://www.adn.com/2010/11/09/1545716/miller-sues-to-force-exact-spelling.html|archivedate=November 10, 2010}} On November 18, Murkowski declared victory, but Miller did not concede the race. Miller hoped to win the Senate seat by means of a federal lawsuit that he filed on November 9, 2010. He alleged that Alaska election officials were violating the [[Article One of the United States Constitution#Section 4: Congressional elections|Elections Clause]] of the U.S. Constitution and the [[Equal Protection Clause]] of the 14th Amendment because they were using a voter intent standard to determine which ballots to count for Murkowski. He argued that the State statute regarding write-in votes should be strictly applied and asked the federal court to throw out all the ballots that misspelled the name "Murkowski", or that did not write in Murkowski's name exactly as it appeared on the list of write-in candidates.{{cite news|url=http://www.adn.com/2010/11/10/1548282/senator-leading-as-write-ins-counted.html|title=98 percent of write-in votes go to Murkowski, SPELL CHECK: Despite objections from Miller's team, most Murkowski votes are being accepted|author=Sean Cockerham|date=November 10, 2010|newspaper=Anchorage Daily News}} He cited an Alaska election statute that states: ''"The rules set out in this section are mandatory and there are no exceptions to them. A ballot may not be counted unless marked in compliance with these rules."''Alaska Stat. § 15.15.360. : Alaska Statutes – Section 15.15.360.: Rules for counting ballots. Election officials said that state [[case law]] allowed them to use discretion in counting ballots with misspellings or other variations.{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/politics/2010-11-10-alaska-senate-lawsuit_N.htm|title=Joe Miller camp files suit over Alaska write-in ballots|author=Staff|agency=Associated Press|newspaper=USA Today|date=November 10, 2010}} The first judge assigned to the case recused himself because he said he had a negative opinion of Miller dating to 2004 when he was Miller's judicial supervisor.{{cite news|title=Judge with 'negative opinion' of Miller bows out of write-in case, QUIT: Republican nominee left his job without notice when Sedwick was his supervisor|url=http://www.adn.com/2010/11/10/1547601/judge-with-negative-opinion-of.html#ixzz14y7Zq6Im|author=Richard Mauer|publisher=Anchorage Daily News|date=November 11, 2010|accessdate=November 11, 2010}} Miller filed a [[preliminary injunction]] as part of the suit, asking that the federal judge immediately order the State to stop counting the ballots, due to irreparable harm that would happen if the counting continued, but the request was denied.{{cite news|title=Injunction denied for write-in vote count|agency=Associated Press|author=AP staff reporter|date=November 10, 2010|url=http://www.adn.com/2010/11/10/1547438/judge-denies-injunction-for-alaska.html}} The votes challenged by Miller's team were put in separate boxes, leaving it to the lawsuit to decide whether they would be counted for Murkowski. On November 11, the Miller campaign alleged it had received reports of voter intimidation and fraud and that it would be filing a lawsuit in Alaska state court asking for voters rolls for certain precincts to determine whether the precincts had counted more ballots than there were registered voters. Miller told [[Fox News Channel]] on November 18 that his campaign may request a recount, investigate the voting machines, and look into whether the absentee ballots for the military were mailed in a timely fashion. The federal judge held the suit could be decided by reference to State law, and directed Miller to file in State court, which he did on November 22, stopping the certification of election results and possibly delaying the seating of a second Senator for Alaska at the beginning of the new term in January.{{cite news|url=https://vancouversun.com/news/Alaska+candidate+Miller+sues+over+Senate+election+results/3868930/story.html|title=Alaska candidate Joe Miller sues over Senate election results|author=Yareth Rosen|agency=Reuters|date=November 22, 2010|newspaper=Vancouver Sun}} Miller's Alaska state court lawsuit essentially repeated his federal suit allegations, but added new charges of voter fraud, claiming that precinct election officials had allowed voting without proper identification, and claiming that identical handwriting was suspiciously found on multiple ballots, which was also a violation of the requirement that a voter must personally pen a write-in ballot.{{cite news|url=http://www.adn.com/2010/11/22/1567823/miller-files-vote-suit-in-state.html|title=Miller files suit in state court over Senate vote court STATE COURT: New claims focus on handwriting and lack of voter identification|author=Richard Mauer|date=November 22, 2010|newspaper=Anchorage Daily News}} Miller offered a new argument at a December 8 hearing; that hundreds of convicted sex offenders and possibly other felons were allowed to vote in the November election. On December 10, the Alaska Superior Court ruled against all of Miller's claims, finding the hand count of the write-in ballots valid.{{cite news|url=http://www.adn.com/article/20101210/judge-rules-against-miller-suit-over-senate-election|title=Judge rules against Miller in Senate suit|author=Sean Cockerham|newspaper=Anchorage Daily News|date=December 10, 2010|accessdate=Sep 18, 2014}} The court said that the State statute does not require perfect spelling, and said that if the State legislature intended exact spelling it, would have said so. The emphasis, the court said, should be on making sure voters are not disenfranchised.{{cite news|url=http://www.juneaublogger.com/updates/?p=6664|title=Court rejects Miller's election challenge|author=Pat Forgey|newspaper=Juneau Empire|date=December 10, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713125154/http://www.juneaublogger.com/updates/?p=6664|archivedate=July 13, 2011|df=}} The judge also wrote, "To allow for write-in votes with less than a perfect spelling of a candidate's name, as long as voter intent is clear ...[is] a commonsense interpretation, which the court believes would be evident to most Alaskans". The judge also rejected Miller's demands for a hand count of all the ballots cast in the election, not just those with write-in votes, because state law did not provide for it. He dismissed Miller's claims of possible vote fraud as based on speculation, "Miller's affidavits do not provide any facts of wrongful conduct at polling stations and not even circumstantial evidence of wrongdoing," he said.{{Cite news|url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2010/12/10/breaking-alaska-superior-court-rules-against-joe-miller|title=BREAKING: Alaska Superior Court rules against Joe Miller|work=cnn.com|accessdate=2010-12-10|date=December 10, 2010}} The Miller campaign responded to the ruling by stating that votes that did not meet the standard established by the state legislature were not valid, and that that equal protection and fundamental fairness required a hand count of all the votes and an investigation of fraud allegations. The judge allowed a brief stay so that Miller could appeal to the Alaska Supreme Court.{{cite news|url=http://alaskadispatch.com/dispatches/news/7767-judge-expect-friday-ruling-on-alaska-senate-race|title=Judge: Friday ruling on Alaska Senate race|author=Patti Epler|date=December 8, 2010|publisher=Alaska Dispatch}} On December 22, 2010, the Alaska Supreme Court upheld a lower court decision and denied Miller's suit. The high court, in its ruling, called voter intent "paramount," and said "any misspelling, abbreviation, or other minor variation in the form of the candidate's name on a write-in ballot does not invalidate a ballot so long as the intention of the voter can be ascertained." and "The State characterizes the standard urged by Miller as the 'perfection standard,' and we agree that such a standard would tend to disenfranchise many Alaskans on the basis of 'technical errors".{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/alaska-high-court-throws-out-joe-miller-claims/|title=Alaska high court throws out Miller claims|work=AP|accessdate=January 8, 2014|date=Dec 22, 2010}}[http://www.touchngo.com/sp/html/sp-6532.htm Miller v. Treadwell (12/22/2010)] On December 28, U.S. District Judge Ralph Beistline dismissed Miller's claim and allowed certification of the election of Senator Lisa Murkowski to go forward without delay.{{Cite news|last=Demer |first=Lisa |title=Court Rejects Miller: Lifts Certification Hold |newspaper=Anchorage Daily News |date=December 28, 2010 |url=http://www.adn.com/2010/12/28/1622554/federal-judge-overturns-miller.html |accessdate=January 8, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140108092615/http://www.adn.com/2010/12/28/1622554/federal-judge-overturns-miller.html |archivedate=January 8, 2014 |df= }} On December 30, 2010, Alaska state officials certified the election of Lisa Murkowski as the winner of the Senatorial election, making her the first U.S. Senate candidate to win election via write-in since [[Strom Thurmond]] [[United States Senate election in South Carolina, 1954|in 1954]].{{Cite news|date=December 30, 2010|url=http://www.adn.com/2010/12/30/1625216/state-set-to-certify-alaska-senate.html|accessdate=December 30, 2010|title=Murkowski certified Senate election winner|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110101192617/http://www.adn.com/2010/12/30/1625216/state-set-to-certify-alaska-senate.html|archivedate=January 1, 2011|df=}} Miller conceded the race on December 31.{{Cite news|date=December 31, 2010|url=http://www.politicsdaily.com/2010/12/31/joe-miller-ends-legal-challenge-to-murkowski-in-alaska-senate-ra/|accessdate=January 8, 2014|title=Joe Miller Ends Legal Challenge to Lisa Murkowski's Win in Alaska Senate Race}} In June 2011, a judge found that Miller's lawsuit was aimed at winning the election and not in the interest of upholding the state constitution as Miller had claimed. He was ordered to compensate the State of Alaska approximately $18,000 for legal fees incurred by the State.[http://www.alaskapublic.org/2011/06/24/judge-orders-joe-miller-to-pay-legal-fees-from-election-challenge/ Judge Orders Joe Miller to Pay Legal Fees from Election Challenge] Associated Press/Alaska Public Radio Network 6/24/2011 ==2014 Senate primary campaign== Miller ran in the [[United States Senate election in Alaska, 2014| 2014 U.S. Senate election]] as a Republican, although a late-race endorsement of Miller by former governor [[Sarah Palin]] did not yield a win, as former Alaska Attorney General and Commissioner of Natural Resources [[Daniel S. Sullivan]] won the primary on August 19, 2014, with 40% of the vote, having vastly outspent Miller (who gathered 32%) and Lt. Governor [[Mead Treadwell]] (25%) combined.[https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-politics/wp/2014/08/15/sarah-palin-endorses-joe-miller-in-alaska-senate-race/ "Sarah Palin endorses Joe Miller in Alaska Senate race"], [[Washington Post]], Sean Sullivan, August 15, 2014. Retrieved 22 August 2014.[http://www.adn.com/article/20140820/sullivan-declares-victory-high-stakes-gop-senate-primary 'Sullivan declares victory in high- takes GOP Senate primary'], [[Alaska Dispatch News]], Dermot Cole, August 20, 2014. Retrieved 22 August 2014. ==2016 U.S. Senate general election campaign== After Cean Stevens, the winner of the Libertarian primary, stepped aside in the 2016 [[United States Senate election in Alaska, 2016| 2016 U.S. Senate election]], Miller received the [[Libertarian Party of Alaska|Libertarian]] nomination in order to again challenge incumbent Republican Senator [[Lisa Murkowski]]. He said he would not be supporting [[Gary Johnson]], the Libertarian presidential nominee, however, and would instead vote for [[Donald Trump]]. He is also, contrary to the Libertarian national platform, opposed to abortion and same-sex marriage.[http://www.adn.com/politics/2016/09/07/with-joe-miller-now-running-alaskas-u-s-senate-race-is-even-more-topsy-turvy/ With Joe Miller now running, Alaska's U.S. Senate race is even more topsy-turvy], ''[[Alaska Dispatch News]], Nathaniel Herz and Erica Martinson, September 9, 2016. Retrieved 22 September 2016. Miller again lost to Murkowski in a four-way race, taking 29% of the vote.[https://www.adn.com/alaska-news/2016/11/09/alaska-voting-results/ Alaska voting results 2016] ''Alaska dispatch News'' 11/10/2016 ==Political positions== He opposes federal aid programs such as federal farm subsidies,{{cite web|url=http://www.realclearpolitics.com/articles/2010/09/02/interview_with_alaska_senate_candidate_joe_miller_107035.html|title= Interview with Candidate Joe Miller|author=John King|work=Real Clear Politics|date= September 2, 2010|accessdate=September 23, 2010}} Miller has said that under the existing system, farmers do not have much choice but to accept the subsidies – which is the reason why he accepted subsidies for property he owned in Kansas.{{cite web|url=http://aprn.org/2010/09/22/miller-defends-acceptance-of-federal-farm-subsidies/|title=Miller Defends Acceptance of Federal Farm Wage|publisher=''ABC News''|date=October 4, 2010|accessdate=October 18, 2010}} and [[Unemployment benefits#United States|unemployment benefits]].{{cite news|url=http://blogs.abcnews.com/thenote/2010/07/alaska-senate-candidate-miller-unemployment-benefits-not-constitutionally-authorized.html|author=Rick Klein |title=Alaska Senate Candidate Miller: Department of Education]].{{cite web|url=http://aprn.org/2010/08/20/murkowski-defends-against-miller's-accusations|title=Murkowski Defends Against Miller's Accusations|date=August 20, 2010|author=Libby Casey|publisher=Alaska Public Radio Network}} Miller supports a repeal of the [[Seventeenth Amendment to the United States Constitution]], which would return the election of U.S. Senators to the state legislatures.{{cite news|url=http://community.adn.com/adn/node/153492|title=No word from Miller camp on 17th Amendment remark|author=Kyle Hopkins|newspaper=Anchorage Daily News|date=October 5, 2010}} He would reduce American foreign aid.{{cite web|url=http://joemiller.us/download/Senior_Letter_July2010.pdf|publisher=Joe Miller campaign website|title=Senior Letter|date=July 8, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101001011915/http://joemiller.us/download/Senior_Letter_July2010.pdf|archivedate=October 1, 2010}} He would vote to repeal the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act|2010 health care legislation]]. He opposes cuts to [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]] or [[Social Security (United States)|Social Security]] benefits for current retirees. He supports privatizing (or "personalizing") Social Security and Medicare for younger workers.{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-20014693-503544.html|title=Alaska Primary Results: If Joe Miller Pulls Out Win Over Lisa Murkowsi, Will Alaskans Really Turn Backs on Federal Government Largess?|author=Brian Montopoli |work=Political Hotsheet|publisher=''CBS News''|date=August 25, Allan|publisher=The Atlantic|date=October 19, 2010|accessdate=October 27, 2010}} Miller believes illegal immigration is a "critically important" issue to deal with because of its economic effects on health care, education and employment. Miller wants to secure the border to stop more immigrants from entering America illegally and protect the country from possible terrorist threats. Miller does not believe the millions of immigrants already here illegally should be granted amnesty. {{refimprove|date=August 2012}} {{Infobox criminal | name = Johannes van Damme | birth_date = {{birth date|1935|06|01|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Middelburg]], the [[Netherlands]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1994|09|23|1935|06|01|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Changi]], [[Singapore]] | death_cause = Execution by [[hanging]] | nationality = [[Dutch nationality law|Dutch]] | occupation = [[Engineer]], [[businessman]] | criminal_charge = [[Illegal drug trade|Drug trafficking]] | conviction_penalty = [[Capital punishment|Death]] | conviction_status = Deceased | spouse = 1 wife, 1 ex-wife | children = 4 }} '''Johannes van Damme''' (1 June 1935 – 23 September 1994) was a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[engineer]] and [[businessman]] executed in [[Singapore]] for [[Illegal drug trade|drug trafficking]]. He was the first [[Europe]]an to be [[Capital punishment|executed]] in Singapore since its independence.
==Biography== Van Damme had lived in [[Nigeria]] for a while and was married to a Nigerian woman at the time of his arrest. He was arrested on September 27, 1991, at [[Singapore Changi Airport]]. In a secret compartment of his trunk, {{convert|4.32|kg}} of heroin was found. Van Damme claimed he had been framed by his Nigerian engineer partner, but this claim was rejected by the court. In November 1993, his [[appeal]] was rejected, and the sentence was upheld. A plea for [[clemency]] from the Dutch government was rejected by the [[President of Singapore]], [[Ong Teng Cheong]], and nor could a letter from [[Beatrix of the Netherlands|Queen Beatrix]] sent to the President prevent Van Damme from being executed.<ref>[http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/12740893.Last_ditch_appeals_fail_to_save_drugs_man_from_gallows/ Last-ditch appeals fail to save drugs man from gallows], ''[[The Herald (Glasgow)|The Herald]]'', 23 September 1994</ref>
He was hanged at [[Changi Prison]] on the morning of Friday, September 23, 1994, between 6:30 a.m. and 7:00 a.m.<ref>{{cite news|title=Singapore Executes a Dutch Engineer Arrested on Drug Charges|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/09/24/world/singapore-executes-a-dutch-engineer-arrested-on-drug-charges.html?scp=1|accessdate=4 July 2011|newspaper=New York Times|date=24 September 1994}}</ref> It was his case, along with that of [[Mat Repin]] (executed by hanging on 13 May 1994 at Changi prison for having smuggled 1 kg of cannabis from [[Malaysia]]).<ref>[http://www.refworld.org/docid/3ae6aa0c18.html Amnesty International Report 1995 - Singapore],</ref>) which prompted science fiction author [[William Gibson]] to describe [[Singapore]] as [[Disneyland with the Death Penalty]], the title of in his first major non-fiction piece which was first published by ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' magazine in its September/October 1993 issue (1.4).<ref>{{cite news|title=Disneyland With the Death Penalty|url=https://www.wired.com/1993/04/gibson-2/|accessdate=6 December 2015}}</ref>
The article had an immediate and lasting impact. The Singapore government banned ''Wired'' upon the publication of the issue, and the phrase "Disneyland with the death penalty" became a byword for bland authoritarianism that the city-state could not easily discard.
