[[Légion d'honneur]] (France) | relations = | laterwork = | signature = John J Pershing Signature.svg | signature_size = 175 }} [[General of the Armies]] '''John Joseph''' "'''Black Jack'''" '''Pershing''' (September 13, 1860 – July 15, 1948) was a senior [[United States Army]] [[Officer (armed forces)|officer]]. His most famous post was when he served as the commander of the [[American Expeditionary Forces]] (AEF) on the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]] in [[World War I]], 1917–18. Pershing rejected British and French demands that American forces be integrated with their armies, and insisted that the AEF would operate as a single unit under his command, although some American divisions fought under British command, and he also allowed all-black units to be integrated with the [[French army]]. Pershing's soldiers first saw serious battle at [[Cantigny, Somme|Cantigny]], [[Battle of Château-Thierry (1918)|Chateau-Thierry]], [[Battle of Belleau Wood|Belleau Wood]], and [[Battle of Soissons (1918)|Soissons]]. To speed up the arrival of the [[doughboy]]s, they embarked for France leaving the heavy equipment behind, and used British and French tanks, artillery, airplanes and other munitions. In September 1918 at [[Battle of Saint-Mihiel|St. Mihiel]], the [[First United States Army|First Army]] was directly under Pershing's command; it overwhelmed the [[Salients, re-entrants and pockets|salient]] – the encroachment into [[Allies of World War I|Allied]] territory – that the [[German Army (German Empire)|German Army]] had held for three years. For the [[Meuse-Argonne Offensive]], Pershing shifted roughly 600,000 American soldiers to the heavily defended forests of the Argonne, keeping his divisions engaged in hard fighting for 47 days, alongside the French. The [[Allies of World War I|Allied]] [[Hundred Days Offensive]], which the Argonne fighting was part of, contributed to Germany calling for an [[Armistice of 11 November 1918|armistice]]. Pershing was of the opinion that the war should continue and that all of [[Germany]] should be occupied in an effort to permanently destroy German militarism. Pershing is the only American to be promoted in his own lifetime to [[General of the Armies]] rank, the highest possible rank in the United States Army.An act was passed in 1976 retroactively promoting [[George Washington]] to the same rank but with higher seniority, ensuring that he would always be considered the senior ranking officer in the United States Army. Allowed to select his own insignia, Pershing chose to use [[General of the Armies#John Pershing|four gold stars]] to distinguish himself from those officers who held the rank of [[General (United States)|General]], which was signified with four silver stars.{{cite news |date=April 18, 1925 |title=Lest We Forget: Over There; The Reduction of the Marne Salient |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/83256506/ |newspaper=The Evening Star |location=Franklin, IN |page=7 |subscription=yes |quote= ... and the boys stood in formation from noon till evening before the arrival of the automobile bearing the impressive insignia of four gold stars. |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170116131222/https://www.newspapers.com/image/83256506/ |archivedate=January 16, 2017 |df=mdy-all }} After the creation of the five-star [[General of the Army (United States)|General of the Army]] rank during [[World War II]], his rank of General of the Armies could unofficially be considered that of a [[six-star general]], but he died before the proposed insignia could be considered and acted on by [[United States Congress|Congress]]. Some of his tactics have been criticized both by other commanders at the time and by modern historians. His reliance on costly [[frontal assault]]s, long after other Allied armies had abandoned such tactics, has been blamed for causing unnecessarily high American casualties.Sheffield, G. (2001). ''Forgotten Victory: The First World War: Myths and Realities'' (2002 ed.). London: Headline Book Publishing. {{ISBN|0-7472-7157-7}} In addition to leading the A.E.F. to victory in World War I, Pershing notably served as a mentor to many in the generation of generals who led the United States Army during [[World War II]], including [[George Marshall]], [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]], [[Omar Bradley]], [[Lesley J. McNair]], [[George S. Patton]], and [[Douglas MacArthur]].{{cite book |last=Tucker |first=Spencer C. |date=2014 |title=World War I: The Definitive Encyclopedia and Document Collection |volume=1 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DBwTBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA1238&dq=%22pershing%22+%22macarthur%22+%22mentor%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjI7I-rpbzLAhXIdR4KHVtsCgcQ6AEIIjAB#v=onepage&q=%22pershing%22%20%22macarthur%22%20%22mentor%22&f=false |location=Santa Barbara, CA |publisher=ABC-CLIO |page=1238 |isbn=978-1-85109-964-1 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160430011411/https://books.google.com/books?id=DBwTBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA1238&dq=%22pershing%22+%22macarthur%22+%22mentor%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjI7I-rpbzLAhXIdR4KHVtsCgcQ6AEIIjAB#v=onepage&q=%22pershing%22%20%22macarthur%22%20%22mentor%22&f=false |archivedate=April 30, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite book |last=Keane |first=Michael |date=2012 |title=George S. Patton: Blood, Guts, and Prayer |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=byMjBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA73&dq=%22pershing%22+%22patton%22+%22mentor%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjhxqjpprzLAhXCRSYKHd_pDaYQ6AEIJTAA#v=onepage&q=%22pershing%22%20%22patton%22%20%22mentor%22&f=false |location=Washington, DC |publisher=Regnery History |page=73 |isbn=978-1-59698-326-7 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160430082127/https://books.google.com/books?id=byMjBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA73&dq=%22pershing%22+%22patton%22+%22mentor%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjhxqjpprzLAhXCRSYKHd_pDaYQ6AEIJTAA#v=onepage&q=%22pershing%22%20%22patton%22%20%22mentor%22&f=false |archivedate=April 30, 2016 |df=mdy-all }} ==Early life== Pershing was born on a farm near [[Laclede, Missouri]], to businessman John Fletcher Pershing and homemaker Ann Elizabeth Thompson. Pershing's great-great-grandfather, Frederick Pershing, whose name originally was Pfersching, [[Alsatians (people)|emigrated from Alsace]], leaving [[Amsterdam]] on the ship ''Jacob'', and arriving in [[Philadelphia]] on October 2, 1749. Pershing's mother was of [[English American|English descent]]. He also had five siblings: brothers James F. (1862–1933) and Ward (1874–1909), and sisters Mary Elizabeth (1864–1928), Anna May (1867–1955) and Grace (1867–1903); three other children died in infancy.Ruth and Rose, twins who died in 1872, and Frederick, who died in 1876. Vandiver, v. 1, p. 6{{cite news |author=[[Associated Press]] |title=Pershing's Sister Dies at 89 |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C01E6D9103AE53BBC4C53DFBE66838E649EDE |quote=Anna May Pershing, a sister of the late General of the Armies John J. Pershing, died yesterday at the age of 89. ... |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=August 4, 1955 |accessdate=2015-02-06 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150207003237/http://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C01E6D9103AE53BBC4C53DFBE66838E649EDE |archivedate=February 7, 2015 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite news |author=Staff |title=James F. Pershing Dies At Age Of 71 |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=990DEEDC1E3AE333A25753C1A9649C946294D6CF |quote=Brother of General Succumbs to Cerebral Thrombosis After a Long Illness. Was President of an Insurance Company. Formerly a Clothing Manufacturer. ... |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=February 10, 1933 |accessdate=2015-02-07 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150207053605/http://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=990DEEDC1E3AE333A25753C1A9649C946294D6CF |archivedate=February 7, 2015 |df=mdy-all }} When the [[American Civil War|Civil War]] began, his father supported the [[Union (American Civil War)|Union]] and was a [[sutler]] for the [[18th Missouri Volunteer Infantry]]. Pershing attended a school in Laclede that was reserved for precocious students who were also the children of prominent citizens. Completing high school in 1878, he became a teacher of local [[African American]] children. While pursuing his teaching career, Pershing also studied at the State [[Normal School]] (now [[Truman State University]]) in [[Kirksville, Missouri]], from which he graduated in 1880 with a [[bachelor of science]] degree in [[Didactic method|scientific didactics]].{{cite book |last=Russell |first=Thomas Herbert |date=1919 |title=America's War for Humanity: Pictorial History of the World War for Liberty |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CVs-AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA497 |location=New York, NY |publisher=L.H. Walter |page=497 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180113013544/https://books.google.com/books?id=CVs-AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA497 |archivedate=January 13, 2018 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite book |last1=Muench |first1=James |last2=Miller |first2=John E. |date=2006 |title=Five Stars: Missouri's Most Famous Generals |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rCkzoxphG80C&pg=PA82 |location=Columbia, MO |publisher=University of Missouri Press |page=82 |isbn=978-0-8262-1656-4 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180113013544/https://books.google.com/books?id=rCkzoxphG80C&pg=PA82 |archivedate=January 13, 2018 |df=mdy-all }} Two years later, he applied to the [[United States Military Academy]]. Pershing later admitted that serving in the military was secondary to attending West Point, and he had applied because the education offered was better than that obtainable in rural Missouri. ==West Point years== [[File:CadetJPershing.jpg|thumb|left|175px|Pershing as a cadet in 1886]] Pershing was sworn in as a West Point cadet in the fall of 1882.{{cite book |last=Lacey |first=Jim |date=2008 |title=Pershing: Lessons in Leadership |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FFCAHW7vcWkC&pg=PA10 |location=New York, NY |publisher=Palgrave Macmillan |page=10 |isbn=978-0-230-61445-1 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180113013544/https://books.google.com/books?id=FFCAHW7vcWkC&pg=PA10 |archivedate=January 13, 2018 |df=mdy-all }} He was selected early for leadership positions and became successively First Corporal, First Sergeant, First Lieutenant, and First Captain, the highest possible cadet rank.{{cite magazine |last=MacAdam |first=George |date=December 1, 1918 |title=The Life of General Pershing: West Point Days |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O6Q6AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA161 |magazine=The World's Work |location=Garden City, NY |publisher=Doubleday, Page & Company |page=161 |ref={{sfnRef|"The Life of General Pershing: West Point Days"}} |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180113013544/https://books.google.com/books?id=O6Q6AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA161 |archivedate=January 13, 2018 |df=mdy-all }} Pershing also commanded, ''[[ex officio]],'' the honor guard that saluted the funeral train of [[President of the United States|President]] [[Ulysses S. Grant]] as it passed West Point in August 1885.{{cite book |last=Flood |first=Charles Bracelen |date=2011 |title=Grant's Final Victory: Ulysses S. Grant's Heroic Last Year |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=peH34cPtkbAC&pg=PA241 |location=Philadelphia, PA |publisher=Da Capo Press |page=241 |isbn=978-0-306-82151-6}} Pershing graduated in the summer of 1886 ranked 30th in his class of 77, and was commissioned a [[Second Lieutenant#United States|second lieutenant]];{{cite book |last=Henry |first=Mark |date= |title=The US Army of World War I |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=v90bDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA10 |location=Cumnor Hill, Oxford, UK |publisher=Osprey Publishing |page=10 |isbn=978-1-84176-486-3 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180113013544/https://books.google.com/books?id=v90bDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA10 |archivedate=January 13, 2018 |df=mdy-all }} he was commended by the West Point Superintendent, General [[Wesley Merritt]], who said Pershing gave early promise of becoming an outstanding officer.{{cite magazine |date=October 1, 1918 |title=General Pershing |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1fZYAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA10-PA5 |magazine=The American Marine Engineer |volume=XIII |issue=10 |location=Washington, DC |publisher=National Marine Engineers' Beneficial Association |page=5 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180113013544/https://books.google.com/books?id=1fZYAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA10-PA5 |archivedate=January 13, 2018 |df=mdy-all }} Pershing briefly considered petitioning the Army to let him study law and delay the start of his mandatory military service.{{cite book |last=Marley |first=David |date=2008 |title=Wars of the Americas: A Chronology of Armed Conflict in the Western Hemisphere, 1492 to the Present |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=An4ZAQAAIAAJ&dq=pershing+take+leave+%22study+law%22&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%22taking+leave+to+study+law%22 |location=Santa Barbara, CA |publisher=ABC-CLIO |page=961 |isbn=978-0-87436-837-6 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180113013544/https://books.google.com/books?id=An4ZAQAAIAAJ&dq=pershing+take+leave+%22study+law%22&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%22taking+leave+to+study+law%22 |archivedate=January 13, 2018 |df=mdy-all }} He also considered joining several classmates in a partnership that would pursue development of an irrigation project in [[Oregon]].{{sfn|"The Life of General Pershing: West Point Days"|page=172}} He ultimately decided against both courses of action in favor of active Army duty.{{cite book |last=Worcester Hall Rowell |first=Cora |date=1920 |title=Leaders of the Great War |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9k4ZAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA261 |location=New York, NY |publisher=The Macmillan Company |page=261}} ==Early career== Pershing reported for active duty on September 30, 1886, and was assigned to Troop L of the [[6th Cavalry Regiment (United States)|6th U.S. Cavalry]] stationed at [[Fort Bayard National Cemetery|Fort Bayard]], in the [[New Mexico Territory]]. While serving in the 6th Cavalry, Pershing participated in several [[American Indian Wars|Indian campaigns]] and was cited for bravery for actions against the [[Apache]]. During his time at [[Fort Stanton]], Pershing and close friends Lt. Julius Penn and Lt. [[Richard B. Paddock]] were nicknamed "The Three Green P's," spending their leisure time hunting and attending Hispanic dances. Pershing's sister Grace married Paddock in 1890.Vandiver, v.1, p. 67. Between 1887 and 1890, Pershing served with the 6th Cavalry at various postings in [[California]], [[Arizona]], and [[North Dakota]]. He also became an expert marksman and, in 1891, was rated second in pistol and fifth in rifle out of all soldiers in the U.S. Army. On December 9, 1890, Pershing and the 6th Cavalry arrived at [[Sioux City, Iowa]], where Pershing played a role in suppressing the last uprisings of the [[Sioux|Lakota (Sioux)]] [[Native Americans in the United States|Indians]]. Though he and his unit did not participate in the [[Wounded Knee Massacre]], they did fight three days after it on January 1, 1891 when Sioux warriors attacked the 6th Cavalry's supply wagons. When the Sioux began firing at the wagons, Pershing and his troops heard the shots, and rode more than six miles to the location of the attack. The cavalry fired at the forces of Chief War Eagle, causing them to retreat. This would be the only occasion where Pershing would see action in the [[Ghost Dance War|Ghost Dance campaign]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JccTct3j3DUC&pg=PA39&dq=John+J.+Pershing+wounded+knee&hl=en&ei=7OfNTrS-KarW0QGD3ungBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=John J. Pershing|author=McNeese, Tim|page=39|publisher=[[Infobase Publishing]]|year=2004|isbn=0-7910-7404-8|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160506112925/https://books.google.com/books?id=JccTct3j3DUC&pg=PA39&dq=John+J.+Pershing+wounded+knee&hl=en&ei=7OfNTrS-KarW0QGD3ungBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false|archivedate=May 6, 2016|df=mdy-all}} In September 1891 he was assigned as the Professor of Military Science and Tactics at the [[University of Nebraska-Lincoln]], a position he held until 1895. While carrying out this assignment, Pershing attended the university's [[University of Nebraska College of Law|College of Law]],{{cite magazine |last=MacAdam |first=George |date=March 1, 1919 |title=The Life of General Pershing |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r0RYAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA543 |magazine=The World's Work |location=Garden City, NY |publisher=Doubleday, Page & Company |page=543 }} from which he received his [[bachelor of laws|LL.B.]] degree in 1893.{{cite magazine |date=April 1, 1920 |title=Alumni in the Primaries |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VeDmAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA6 |magazine=The University Journal |location=Lincoln, NE |publisher=University of Nebraska |page=6}} He formed a drill company of chosen university cadets, Company A. In March 1892, it won the Maiden Prize competition of the National Competitive Drills in [[Omaha, Nebraska]]. The Citizens of Omaha presented the company with a large silver cup, the "Omaha Cup." On October 2, 1894, former members of Company A established a fraternal military drill organization named the Varsity Rifles. The group renamed itself the [[Pershing Rifles]] in 1895 in honor of its mentor and patron.{{cite web|title=Gen. John J. Pershing: Contributions and Commemoration at UNL 1891-1895: Pershing Rifles|url=http://unlhistory.unl.edu/exhibits/show/generalpershing/the-pershing-rifles/pershingrifles|website=Nebraska U: A Collaborative History|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171201031104/http://unlhistory.unl.edu/exhibits/show/generalpershing/the-pershing-rifles/pershingrifles|archivedate=December 1, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Pershing maintained a close relationship with Pershing Rifles for the remainder of his life.{{cite book |last=O'Connor |first=Richard |date=1961 |title=Black Pershing Company |url=https://archive.org/stream/blackjackpershin030769mbp#page/n75/mode/2up/ |location=Garden City, NY |publisher=Doubleday & Company |page=73}}{{cite book |last=Christy |first=Helen Anne Hirst |date=1996 |title=Hirst/Sheppard family history |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IZ1RAAAAMAAJ&q=%22pershing+rifles%22+troops+review+pershing+1933&dq=%22pershing+rifles%22+troops+review+pershing+1933&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwji_LyEwL_YAhVSGt8KHbuLDjAQ6AEIKTAA |location=Denver, CO |publisher=H. A. H. Christy |page=11}} On October 20, 1892,{{cite web|last=US Army Center for Military History|title=John Joseph Pershing|url=http://www.history.army.mil/html/faq/pershing.html|work=US Army Chiefs of Staff|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110507013003/http://www.history.army.mil/html/faq/pershing.html|archivedate=May 7, 2011|df=mdy-all}} Pershing was promoted to [[US First Lieutenant|first lieutenant]] and in 1895 took command of a troop of the [[10th Cavalry Regiment (United States)|10th Cavalry Regiment]], one of the original [[Buffalo Soldier]] regiments composed of African-American soldiers under white officers. From [[Fort Assinniboine]] in north central [[Montana]], he commanded an expedition to the south and southwest that rounded up and deported a large number of [[Cree Indians]] to [[Canada]]. ==West Point instructor {{anchor|nickname}}== [[File:CAPTJPershing.jpg|thumb|187px|Captain John J. Pershing, c.1902]] [[File:John J. Pershing and family.jpg|right|thumb|187px|Pershing with his wife Helen and three of their children]] In 1897, Pershing was appointed to the West Point tactical staff as an instructor, where he was assigned to Cadet Company A. Because of his strictness and rigidity, Pershing was unpopular with the cadets, who took to calling him "[[Nigger]] Jack" because of his service with the 10th Cavalry.Vandiver v.1, p.171[http://www.nps.gov/pwso/honor/pershing.htm "Buffalo Soldier Cavalry Commander"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070915020632/http://www.nps.gov/pwso/honor/pershing.htm |date=September 15, 2007 }} on the [[National Park Service]] websiteBak, Richard, Editor. "The Rough Riders" by Theodore Roosevelt. p. 172. Taylor Publishing, 1997. During the course of his tour at the [[United States Military Academy|Academy]], this epithet softened to "Black Jack," although, according to Vandiver, "the intent remained hostile." Still, this nickname would stick with Pershing for the rest of his life, and was known to the public as early as 1917.{{cite news |author=Staff |title=Pershing Won Fame in Moros Campaign ... 'Black Jack' Was Youngest West Pointer Ever Made General in Peacetime |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1917/05/19/102345143.pdf |quote=Maj. Gen. John J. Pershing, the famous "Black jack" of the regulars, will go down in history as the first American army officer to command troops on the battlefields of Europe. He (Pershing) is one of the officers picked by Colonel Roosevelt, when the Colonel was President, for rapid promotion to the highest of army commands. ... |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=May 19, 1917 |accessdate=2015-02-06 }} ==Spanish– and Philippine–American wars== At the start of the [[Spanish–American War]], First Lieutenant Pershing was the regimental quartermaster for the 10th Cavalry; he fought on Kettle and [[Battle of San Juan Hill|San Juan Hill]]s in [[Cuba]], and was cited for gallantry. In 1919, he was awarded the [[Citation Star|Silver Citation Star]] for these actions, and in 1932 the award was upgraded to the [[Silver Star]] decoration. A commanding officer here commented on Pershing's calm demeanor under fire, saying he was "cool as a bowl of cracked ice.".Boot, p. 191 Pershing also served with the 10th Cavalry during the siege and surrender of [[Santiago de Cuba]]. Pershing was commissioned as a major of United States Volunteers on August 26, 1898, and assigned as an ordnance officer. In March 1899, after suffering from [[malaria]], Pershing was put in charge of the Office of Customs and Insular Affairs which oversaw occupation forces in territories gained in the Spanish–American War, including Cuba, [[Puerto Rico]], the [[Philippines]], and [[Guam]]. He was honorably discharged from the volunteers and reverted to his permanent rank of first lieutenant on May 12, 1899. He was again commissioned as a major of Volunteers on June 6, 1899, this time as an assistant adjutant general. When the [[Philippine–American War]] began, Pershing reported to Manila on August 17, 1899, was assigned to the Department of [[Mindanao]] and [[Jolo]], and commanded efforts to suppress the [[Filipino Insurrection]].{{cite web|last=Rojas|first=Julietta|title=John J. Pershing: A Teacher's Guide|url=http://academics.utep.edu/Portals/1719/Publications/Pershing.pdf|accessdate=April 12, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131017030751/http://academics.utep.edu/Portals/1719/Publications/Pershing.pdf|archivedate=October 17, 2013|df=mdy-all}} On November 27, 1900, Pershing was appointed Adjutant General of his department and served in this posting until March 1, 1901. He was cited for bravery for actions on the [[Cagayan River (Mindanao)|Cagayan River]] while attempting to destroy a Philippine stronghold at Macajambo. Pershing wrote in his autobiography that "The bodies [of some [[Moro people|Moro]] outlaws] were publicly buried in the same grave with a dead pig."{{Cite web|author=Johnson, Jenna and DelReal, Jose A.|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2016/02/20/trumps-story-about-killing-terrorists-with-bullets-dipped-in-pigs-blood-is-likely-not-true/|title=Trump tells story about killing terrorists with bullets dipped in pigs' blood, though there's no proof of it|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=February 20, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160228092733/https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2016/02/20/trumps-story-about-killing-terrorists-with-bullets-dipped-in-pigs-blood-is-likely-not-true/|archivedate=February 28, 2016|df=mdy-all}} This treatment was used against captured ''[[juramentado]]'' so that the Moro would believe they would be going to hell.Smythe, Donald (1973) [https://books.google.com/books?id=l4oLAAAAYAAJ&dq=%22c.c.+booth%22+pershing&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=pig ''Guerrilla Warrior: The Early Life of John J. Pershing''], p.162 New York: Scribner. {{isbn|0684129337}}. Quote: "To combat the ''jurementado'', Pershing tried burying him when caught with a pig, thinking that this was equivalent to burying the Moro in hell, for pigs were impure animals to a Moslem." Pershing added that "it was not pleasant [for the Army] to have to take such measures".Pershing, John (2013) [https://books.google.com/books?id=a74_JIbehzsC&q=materially+reduced+#v=snippet&q=materially%20reduced&f=false ''My Life Before the World War, 1860–1917: A Memoir''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160430233418/https://books.google.com/books?id=a74_JIbehzsC |date=April 30, 2016 }}, pp. 284-85 Lexington, Kentucky: University Press of Kentucky. {{isbn|9780813141978}} Quote: "... the commanding office, Colonel Frank West, had seen the attack and called out the guard, and before the man could kill anyone else he was shot dead in his tracks. These ''juramentado'' attacks were materially reduced in number by a practice the army had already adopted, one that Muhhamadans held in abhorrence. The bodies were publicly buried in the same grave with a dead pig. It was not pleasant to have to take such measures, but the prospect of going to hell instead of heaven sometimes deterred the would-be assassins." A footnote in the 2013 edition cites a letter from Maj. Gen. J. Franklin Bell to Pershing: "Of course there is nothing to be done, but I understand it has long been a custom to bury (insurgents) with pigs when they kill Americans. I think this a good plan, for if anything will discourage the (insurgents) it is the prospect of going to hell instead of to heaven. You can rely on me to stand by you in maintaining this custom. It is the only possible thing we can do to discourage crazy fanatics."{{cite book|author=Lacey, Jim|title=Pershing (Great Generals)|date=2008|publisher=PalgraveMacmillan|isbn=978-0-230-60383-7 |page=66 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FFCAHW7vcWkC&pg=PP6&dq=lacey+pershing&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjAt_DtvN_VAhUK6yYKHVtUDLkQ6AEIJTA}} Historians do not believe that Pershing was directly involved with such incidents, or that he personally gave such orders to his subordinates. Letters and memoirs from soldiers describing events similar to this do not have credible evidence of Pershing having been personally involved. Similarly, the claim made by [[Donald Trump]] during his presidential campaign in February 2016 that Pershing executed 49 "Muslim terrorists" with bullets dipped in pig's blood, then let the 50th go free to spread the word about the religious atrocity, which Trump alluded to again while serving as president in August 2017, has been repeatedly debunked by historians, who find no evidence that such an incident occurred.Horton, Alex (August 18, 2017) [https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/retropolis/wp/2017/08/18/after-barcelona-attack-trump-said-to-study-general-pershing-heres-what-the-president-got-wrong/ "Trump said to study General Pershing. Here’s what the president got wrong"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170819024443/https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/retropolis/wp/2017/08/18/after-barcelona-attack-trump-said-to-study-general-pershing-heres-what-the-president-got-wrong/ |date=August 19, 2017 }} ''[[The Washington Post]]''Qiu, Linda (August 18, 2017) [https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/17/us/politics/trump-tweet-pershing-fact-check.html?_r=0 "Study Pershing, Trump Said. But the Story Doesn’t Add Up"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170819022903/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/17/us/politics/trump-tweet-pershing-fact-check.html?_r=0 |date=August 19, 2017 }} ''[[The New York Times]]''Mikkelson, David (August 17, 2017) [http://www.snopes.com/rumors/pershing.asp "Fact Check: General Pershing on How to Stop Islamic Terrorists"] [[Snopes.com]]On August 17, 2017 Trump tweeted: "Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!" On June 30, 1901, Pershing was honorably discharged from the Volunteers and he reverted to the rank of captain in the [[Regular Army (United States)|Regular Army]] to which he had been promoted on February 2, 1901. He served with the [[1st Cavalry Regiment (United States)|1st Cavalry Regiment]] in the Philippines. He later was assigned to the [[15th Cavalry Regiment (United States)|15th Cavalry Regiment]], serving as an intelligence officer and participating in actions [[Moro Rebellion|against the Moros]]. He was cited for bravery at [[Lake Lanao]]. In June 1901, he served as Commander of Camp Vicars in Lanao, Philippines, after the previous camp commander had been promoted to [[Brigadier general (United States)|brigadier general]]. ==Rise to general== In June 1903, Pershing was ordered to return to the United States. President [[Theodore Roosevelt]], taken by Pershing's ability, petitioned the Army General Staff to promote Pershing to [[Colonel (United States)|colonel]]. At the time, Army officer promotions were based primarily on seniority rather than merit, and although there was widespread acknowledgment that Pershing should serve as a colonel, the Army General Staff declined to change their seniority-based promotion tradition just to accommodate Pershing. They would not consider a promotion to [[Lieutenant colonel (United States)|lieutenant colonel]] or even [[Major (United States)|major]]. This angered Roosevelt, but since the President could only name and promote army officers in the General ranks, his options for recognizing Pershing through promotion were limited. [[File:Leon Hornecker-general-Pershing.jpg|thumb|left|175px|Portrait of Captain Pershing by [[Léon Hornecker]] (1903)]] In 1904, Pershing was assigned as the Assistant Chief of Staff of the Southwest Army Division stationed at [[Oklahoma City, Oklahoma]]. In October 1904, he attended the [[United States Army War College|Army War College]], and then was ordered to [[Washington, D.C.]] for "general duties unassigned." Since Roosevelt could not yet promote Pershing, he petitioned the [[United States Congress]] to authorize a diplomatic posting, and Pershing was stationed as [[military attaché]] in [[Tokyo]] in 1905. Also in 1905, Pershing married Helen Frances Warren, the daughter of powerful [[United States Senate|U.S. Senator]] [[Francis E. Warren]], a [[Wyoming]] [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] who served at different times as chairman of the [[United States Senate Committee on Armed Services|Military Affairs]] and [[United States Senate Committee on Appropriations|Appropriations]] Committees. This union with the daughter of a powerful politician who had also received the [[Medal of Honor]] during the [[American Civil War]] continued to aid Pershing's career even after his wife died in 1915.{{cite web |url=http://www.warren.af.mil/library/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=4696 |title=F. E. Warren History |date= |work=Factsheets |publisher=U.S. Air Force – Warren AFB |accessdate=January 18, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090905010958/http://www.warren.af.mil/library/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=4696 |archivedate=September 5, 2009 |df=mdy-all }} After serving as an [[Military attachés and observers in the Russo-Japanese War|observer in the Russo-Japanese War]] attached to General [[Kuroki Tamemoto]]'s [[First Army (Japan)|Japanese First Army]] in [[Manchuria]] from March to September,{{cite book | last = Kowner| first = Rotem|authorlink=Rotem Kowner| coauthors = | year = 2006 | title = Historical Dictionary of the Russo-Japanese War| publisher = The Scarecrow Press | location = |isbn=0-8108-4927-5 | page =282 }} Pershing returned to the United States in the fall of 1905. President Roosevelt employed his presidential prerogative and nominated Pershing as a [[Brigadier general (United States)|brigadier general]], a move which Congress approved. In skipping three ranks and more than 835 officers senior to him, the promotion gave rise to accusations that Pershing's appointment was the result of political connections and not military abilities.{{cite book |last=Lacey |first=Jim |date=2008 |title=Pershing: A Biography: lessons in Leadership |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FFCAHW7vcWkC&pg=PA55&lpg=PA55&dq=pershing+political+promotion&source=bl&ots=cDaGuPPP5k&sig=OUoOu433nY3EVtE3kak309CaZeQ&hl=en&ei=d-ogTa2ZO4essAOCnJy5Ag&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&sqi=2&ved=0CB4Q6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=pershing%20political%20promotion&f=false |location=New York, NY |publisher=Palgrave MacMillan |page=55 |isbn=978-0-230-61445-1 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160430063554/https://books.google.com/books?id=FFCAHW7vcWkC&pg=PA55&lpg=PA55&dq=pershing+political+promotion&source=bl&ots=cDaGuPPP5k&sig=OUoOu433nY3EVtE3kak309CaZeQ&hl=en&ei=d-ogTa2ZO4essAOCnJy5Ag&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&sqi=2&ved=0CB4Q6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=pershing%20political%20promotion&f=false |archivedate=April 30, 2016 |df=mdy-all }} However, several other junior officers were similarly advanced to brigadier general ahead of their peers and seniors, including [[Albert Leopold Mills|Albert L. Mills]] (captain), [[Tasker H. Bliss]] (major), and [[Leonard Wood]] (captain). Pershing's promotion, while unusual, was not unprecedented, and had the support of many soldiers who admired his abilities.{{cite book |last=Runkle |first=Benjamin |date=2011 |title=Wanted Dead or Alive: Manhunts from Geronimo to Bin Laden |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JbFLWGHj20cC&pg=PA77&dq=%22john+j.+pershing%22+%22promotion%22+%22brigadier%22+%22seniority%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=o8vwVLOwBcqVNsCPgIAD&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%22john%20j.%20pershing%22%20%22promotion%22%20%22brigadier%22%20%22seniority%22&f=false |location=New York, NY |publisher=Palgrave MacMillan |pages=77–79 |isbn=978-0-230-10485-3 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150602161920/https://books.google.com/books?id=JbFLWGHj20cC&pg=PA77&dq=%22john+j.+pershing%22+%22promotion%22+%22brigadier%22+%22seniority%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=o8vwVLOwBcqVNsCPgIAD&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%22john%20j.%20pershing%22%20%22promotion%22%20%22brigadier%22%20%22seniority%22&f=false |archivedate=June 2, 2015 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite book |last=Goldhurst |first=Richard |date=1977 |title=Pipe Clay and Drill: John J. Pershing, the Classic American Soldier |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rGorAQAAIAAJ&q=%22john+j.+pershing%22+%22medal+of+honor%22+%22bagsak%22&dq=%22john+j.+pershing%22+%22medal+of+honor%22+%22bagsak%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=gtDwVNWUC4W_ggTP8IKQDw&ved=0CBwQ6AEwADgK |location=Pleasantville, NY |publisher=Reader's Digest Press |page=151 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150602161510/https://books.google.com/books?id=rGorAQAAIAAJ&q=%22john+j.+pershing%22+%22medal+of+honor%22+%22bagsak%22&dq=%22john+j.+pershing%22+%22medal+of+honor%22+%22bagsak%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=gtDwVNWUC4W_ggTP8IKQDw&ved=0CBwQ6AEwADgK |archivedate=June 2, 2015 |df=mdy-all }} In 1908, Pershing briefly served as a U.S. military observer in the [[Balkans]], an assignment which was based in [[Paris]]. Upon returning to the United States at the end of 1909, Pershing was assigned once again to the Philippines, an assignment in which he served until 1913. While in the Philippines, he served as Commander of [[Fort William McKinley|Fort McKinley]], near Manila, and also was the governor of the Moro Province. The last of Pershing's four children was born in the Philippines, and during this time he became an [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopalian]]. |archivedate=October 16, 2015 |df=mdy-all }} ==Pancho Villa and Mexico== {{main|Pancho Villa Expedition}} [[File:File-Los Generales, Ft Bliss 1913.jpg|thumb|175px|Generals [[Álvaro Obregón|Obregón]], [[Pancho Villa|Villa]], and Pershing, August 1914. A year later, Pershing's wife and three of his children died, and Villa sent him condolences. Six months later, Pershing chased Villa in Mexico.]] [[File:Nita Patton (Sister of General George S. Patton).jpg|thumb|175px|Nita Patton was engaged to Pershing in 1917–18.]] [[File:Camping on the Border, near El Paso, Texas.jpg|thumb|175px|Postcard of Pershing's camp at Fort Bliss.]] On December 20, 1913, Pershing received orders to take command of the 8th Brigade at the [[Presidio of San Francisco|Presidio]] in [[San Francisco]]. With tensions running high on the border between the United States and Mexico, the brigade was deployed to [[Fort Bliss, Texas]] on April 24, 1914, arriving there on the 27th.Vandiver, Volume I, p. 582 ===Death of wife and children=== After a year at Fort Bliss, Pershing decided to take his family there. The arrangements were almost complete, when on the morning of August 27, 1915, he received a telegram informing him of a fire in the [[Presidio of San Francisco|Presidio]] in [[San Francisco]], where a lacquered floor caught fire and the flames rapidly spread, resulting in the smoke inhalation deaths of his wife, Helen Frances Warren, and three young daughters, Mary, age 3, Anne, age 7, and Helen, age 8. Only his 6-year-old son Francis Warren survived.{{cite web|work=nps.gov|url=http://www.nps.gov/prsf/historyculture/john-pershing.htm|title=Pershing history and house photos|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120711023105/http://www.nps.gov/prsf/historyculture/john-pershing.htm|archivedate=July 11, 2012|df=mdy-all}}Vandiver, Volume I, pp. 593–94 After the funerals at Lakeview Cemetery in Cheyenne, Wyoming, Pershing returned to Fort Bliss with his son, Warren, and his sister May, and resumed his duties as commanding officer.Boot, p. 192Vandiver, Volume II, pp. 599–602 ===Relationship with Nita Patton=== Two years after the death of his wife and children, Pershing courted Anne Wilson "Nita" Patton, the younger sister of his protégé, [[George S. Patton]]. Pershing met her when she traveled to Fort Bliss to visit her brother,{{cite book |last=Keane |first=Michael |date=2012 |title=George S. Patton: Blood, Guts, and Prayer |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=byMjBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA71 |location=Washington, DC |publisher=Regnery History |pages=71–72 |isbn=978-1-62157-298-5}} and he introduced them. Pershing and Nita Patton soon began a relationship; they became engaged in 1917, but their separation because of Pershing's time in France during World War I ended it.Vandiver, v.II, pp. 606, 608, 657–58, 666, 674, 684–87, 698, 735, 737, 791, 1008 Pershing had wartime affairs, including one with Micheline Resco (1894–1968), an artist who painted his portrait, and he later expressed regret that he had let Nita Patton "get away".{{cite book |last=D'Este |first=Carlo |date=2002 |title=Eisenhower: A Soldier's Life |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g72pCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA191 |location=New York|publisher=Henry Holt |page=191 |isbn=978-0-8050-5687-7}} Nita Patton never married, while Pershing married French-Romanian portrait artist Micheline Resco in his Walter Reed Hospital apartment in 1946. Pershing was 85 at the time and Resco was 50.https://news.unl.edu/newsrooms/today/article/11-things-you-probably-didnt-know-about-john-j-pershing/{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/local/2006/01/15/a-hospitals-storied-halls-span-classbankheadrelics-of-walter-reeds-famed-patients-face-uncertain-fate-span/5a183cc8-5dad-4b0b-ad3f-168ea45f4f78/?utm_term=.0045b9c70ba7|title=A Hospital's Storied Halls Relics of Walter Reed's Famed Patients Face Uncertain Fate|publisher=Washingtonpost.com|date=15 January 2006|accessdate=16 October 2018}} ===Commander of Villa expedition=== On March 15, 1916,{{cite web |url=http://www.history.army.mil/html/reference/army_flag/mexex.html |title=Mexican Expedition Campaign |publisher=History.army.mil |date= |accessdate=2014-04-28 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140718210806/http://www.history.army.mil/html/reference/army_flag/mexex.html |archivedate=July 18, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web |url=https://www.archives.gov/publications/prologue/1997/fall/mexican-punitive-expedition-1.html |title=Prologue: Selected Articles |publisher=Archives.gov |date= |accessdate=2014-04-28 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140423065711/http://www.archives.gov/publications/prologue/1997/fall/mexican-punitive-expedition-1.html |archivedate=April 23, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite journal |title=Buffalo Soldiers at Huachuca: Organizing the Punitive Expedition |url=http://net.lib.byu.edu/estu/wwi/comment/huachuca/HI1-13.htm |journal=Huachuca Illustrated |volume=1 |year=1993 |accessdate=August 2, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120618044540/http://net.lib.byu.edu/estu/wwi/comment/huachuca/HI1-13.htm |archivedate=June 18, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} Pershing led an expedition into Mexico to capture [[Pancho Villa]]. This expedition was ill-equipped and hampered by a lack of supplies due to the breakdown of the Quartermaster Corps. Although there had been talk of war on the border for years, no steps had been taken to provide for the handling of supplies for an expedition. Despite this and other hindrances, such as the lack of aid from the former Mexican government, and their refusal to allow American troops to transport troops and supplies over their railroads, Pershing organized and commanded the [[Pancho Villa Expedition|Mexican Punitive Expedition]], a combined armed force of 10,000 men that penetrated {{convert|350|mi}} into Mexico. They routed Villa's revolutionaries, but failed to capture him.Boot, ''passim'' pp. 192–204Vandiver, Volume II, ''passim'' pp. 604–68 ==World War I== [[File:John Pershing, Bain bw photo as major general, 1917.jpg|thumb|right|175px|left|Major General Pershing of the [[National Army (USA)|National Army]]]] At the start of the United States' involvement in [[World War I]] President [[Woodrow Wilson]] considered mobilizing an army to join the fight. [[Frederick Funston]], Pershing's superior in Mexico, was being considered for the top billet as the Commander of the American Expeditionary Force (AEF) when he died suddenly from a heart attack on February 19, 1917. Pershing was the most likely candidate other than Funston, and following America's entrance into the war in May, Wilson briefly interviewed Pershing, and then selected him for the command. He was officially installed in the position on May 10, 1917, and held the post until 1918. On October 6, 1917, Pershing, then a [[Major general (United States)|major general]], was promoted to full general in the [[National Army (USA)|National Army]]. He bypassed the three star rank of lieutenant general, and was the first full general since [[Philip Sheridan]] in 1888. As AEF commander, Pershing was responsible for the organization, training, and supply of a combined professional and draft Army and National Guard force that eventually grew from 27,000 inexperienced men to two Armies, with a third forming as the war ended, totaling over two million soldiers. Pershing exercised significant control over his command, with a full delegation of authority from Wilson and [[United States Secretary of War|Secretary of War]] [[Newton D. Baker]]. Baker, cognizant of the endless problems of domestic and allied political involvement in military decision making in wartime, gave Pershing unmatched authority to run his command as he saw fit. In turn, Pershing exercised his prerogative carefully, not engaging in politics or disputes over government policy that might distract him from his military mission. While earlier a champion of the African-American soldier, he did not advocate their full participation on the battlefield, understanding the general racial attitudes of white Americans. In addition, Wilson held reactionary views on race and owed political debts to southern Democratic politicians. [[George Marshall]] served as one of Pershing's top assistants during and after the war. Pershing's initial chief of staff was [[James Harbord]], who later took a combat command but worked as Pershing's closest assistant for many years and remained extremely loyal to him. [[File:Pershing at Lafayette Tomb.jpg|left|thumb|282px|Pershing saluting the [[Gilbert du Motier, marquis de Lafayette|Marquis de Lafayette]]'s grave in [[Paris]]]] After departing from [[Fort Jay]] at [[Governors Island]] in New York Harbor under top secrecy in May 1917, Pershing arrived in France in June 1917. In a show of American presence, part of the [[16th Infantry Regiment (United States)#World War I|16th Infantry Regiment]] marched through Paris shortly after his arrival. Pausing at the tomb of [[Gilbert du Motier, Marquis de Lafayette]], he was reputed to have uttered the famous line "Lafayette, we are here," a line spoken, in fact, by his aide, Colonel [[Charles E. Stanton]].{{cite web|url=http://www.unc.edu/depts/diplomat/AD_Issues/amdipl_16/edit16_print.html|title=Mattox: Natural Allies|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070330165559/http://www.unc.edu/depts/diplomat/AD_Issues/amdipl_16/edit16_print.html|archivedate=March 30, 2007|df=mdy-all}} American forces were deployed in France in the autumn of 1917. In September 1917 the French government commissioned a portrait of Pershing by 23-year-old Romanian artist Micheline Resco. Pershing removed the stars and flag from his car and sat up front with his chauffeur while traveling from his AEF headquarters to visit her by night in her apartment on the rue Descombes. Their friendship continued for the rest of his life.{{cite journal |last=Fleming |first=Thomas |year=1995 |title=Iron General |journal=[[MHQ: The Quarterly Journal of Military History]] |volume=7 |issue=2 |pages=66, 73 |publisher=American Historical Publications }} In 1946, at 85, Pershing secretly wed French-Romanian portrait artist Micheline Resco in his Walter Reed Hospital apartment. Resco was 35 years his junior ===Battle of Hamel=== For the first time in American history, Pershing allowed American soldiers to be under the command of a foreign power. In late June, General [[Henry Rawlinson, 1st Baron Rawlinson|Rawlinson]], commanding the British Fourth Army, suggested to Australian Lieutenant General [[John Monash]] that American involvement in a set-piece attack alongside the experienced Australians in the upcoming [[Battle of Hamel]] would both give the American troops experience and also strengthen the Australian battalions by an additional company each. On June 29, General Bell, commanding the American 33rd Division, selected two companies each from the 131st and 132nd Infantry regiments of the 66th brigade. Monash had been promised ten companies of American troops and on June 30 the remaining companies of the 1st and 2nd battalions of the 131st regiment were sent. Each American platoon was attached to an Australian company, but there was difficulty in integrating the American platoons (which numbered 60 men) among the Australian companies of 100 men. This difficulty was overcome by reducing the size of each American platoon by one-fifth and sending the troops thus removed, which numbered 50 officers and men, back to battalion reinforcement camps. The day before the attack was scheduled to commence, Pershing learnt of the plan and ordered the withdrawal of six American companies.Nunan, Peter (2000). "Diggers' Fourth of July". ''Military History''. 17 (3): 26–32 & 80. {{ISSN|0889-7328}} While a few Americans, such as those attached to the 42nd Battalion, disobeyed the order, the majority, although disappointed, moved back to the rear. This meant that battalions had to rearrange their attack formations and caused a serious reduction in the size of the Allied force. For example, the 11th Brigade was now attacking with 2,200 men instead of 3,000.Bean, C.E.W (1942). The Australian Imperial Force in France during the Allied Offensive, 1918. Official History of Australia in the War of 1914–1918. Volume VI. Sydney, New South Wales: Angus and Robertson. OCLC 41008291 There was a further last-minute call for the removal of all American troops from the attack, but Monash, who had chosen 4 July as the date of the attack out of "deference" to the US troops, protested to Rawlinson and received support from Field Marshal Douglas Haig, commander of the British Expeditionary Force.an, C.E.W (1942). The Australian Imperial Force in France during the Allied Offensive, 1918. Official History of Australia in the War of 1914–1918. Volume VI. Sydney, New South Wales: Angus and Robertson. OCLC 41008291 The four American companies that had joined the Australians during the assault were withdrawn from the line after the battle and returned to their regiments, having gained valuable experience. Monash sent Bell his personal thanks, praising the Americans' gallantry, while Pershing set out explicit instructions to ensure that US troops would not be employed in a similar manner again. ===African-American units=== Under [[civilian control of the military]], Pershing adhered to the racial policies of [[President of the United States|President]] [[Woodrow Wilson]], [[United States Secretary of War|Secretary of War]] [[Newton D. Baker]], and southern Democrats who promoted the "[[separate but equal]]" doctrine. African-American "[[Buffalo Soldier]]s" units were not allowed to participate with the [[American Expeditionary Forces|American Expeditionary Force (AEF)]] during [[World War I]], but experienced [[non-commissioned officer]]s were provided to other segregated black units for combat service—such as the 317th Engineer Battalion.{{cite web |url=http://www.history.army.mil/html/forcestruc/lineages/branches/eng/0317enbn.htm |title=Lineage and Honors Information, 317th Engineer Battalion |website=history.army.mil/ |publisher=US Army Center of Military History |access-date=October 2, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161111203615/http://www.history.army.mil/html/forcestruc/lineages/branches/eng/0317enbn.htm |archivedate=November 11, 2016 |df=mdy-all }} The American Buffalo Soldiers of the [[92nd Infantry Division (United States)|92nd]] and [[93rd Infantry Division (United States)|93rd Infantry Divisions]] were the first American soldiers to fight in France in 1918, but they did so under French command as Pershing had detached them from the AEF. Most regiments of the 92nd and all of the 93rd would continue to fight under French command for the duration of the war.{{Citation| author=Buckley, Gail Lumet| title=American Patriots: The Story of Blacks in the Military from the Revolution to Desert Storm| location=| publisher=Random House| year=2001| id=| isbn=0-375-50279-3| url=}} ==World War I: 1918 and full American participation== [[File:John Pershing.jpg|thumb|175px|right|Pershing at General Headquarters in [[Chaumont (Haute-Marne)|Chaumont]], France, October 1918.]] In early 1918, entire divisions were beginning to serve on the front lines alongside French troops. Pershing insisted that the AEF fight as units under American command rather than being split up by battalions to augment British and French regiments and brigades (although the [[27th Infantry Division (United States)|27th]] and [[30th Infantry Division (United States)|30th Divisions]], grouped under [[II Corps (United States)|II Corps]] command, were loaned during the [[Spring Offensive|desperate days of spring 1918]], fought with the British/Australian/Canadian [[Fourth Army (United Kingdom)|Fourth Army]] until the end of the war, taking part in the breach of the [[Hindenburg Line]] in October). In October 1918, Pershing saw the need for a dedicated [[Military Police Corps (United States)|Military Police Corps]] and the first U.S. Army MP School was established at Autun, France. For this, he is considered the founding father of the United States MPs.Wright, Robert K. Jr. (ed.) ''[http://www.history.army.mil/books/Lineage/mp/mp.htm Army Lineage Series:Military Police] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111117192807/http://www.history.army.mil/books/Lineage/mp/mp.htm |date=November 17, 2011 }}'' Because of the effects of [[trench warfare]] on soldiers' feet, in January 1918, Pershing oversaw the creation of an improved [[combat boot]], the "[[Trench boot|1918 Trench Boot]]," which became known as the "Pershing Boot" upon its introduction.{{cite web|url=http://www.worldwar1.com/dbc/l_tanks.htm|title=The American Field Shoe|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090815103701/http://www.worldwar1.com/dbc/l_tanks.htm|archivedate=August 15, 2009|df=mdy-all}} American forces first saw serious action during the summer of 1918, contributing eight large divisions, alongside 24 French ones, at the [[Second Battle of the Marne]]. Along with the British Fourth Army's victory at [[Battle of Amiens (1918)|Amiens]], the Allied victory at the Second Battle of the Marne marked the turning point of World War I on the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]]. In August 1918 the [[First United States Army|U.S. First Army]] had been formed, first under Pershing's direct command and then by Lieutenant General [[Hunter Liggett]], when the [[Second United States Army|U.S. Second Army]] under Lieutenant General [[Robert Lee Bullard|Robert Bullard]] was created. After a quick victory at [[Battle of Saint-Mihiel|Saint-Mihiel]], east of [[Verdun]], some of the more bullish AEF commanders had hoped to push on eastwards to [[Metz]], but this did not fit in with the plans of the Allied Supreme Commander, [[Ferdinand Foch|Marshal Foch]], for three simultaneous offensives into the "bulge" of the Western Front (the other two being the Fourth Army's breach of the Hindenburg Line and an Anglo-Belgian offensive, led by [[Herbert Plumer, 1st Viscount Plumer|Plumer's]] Second Army, in Flanders). Instead, the AEF was required to redeploy and, aided by French tanks, launched a major offensive northwards in very difficult terrain at [[Meuse-Argonne Offensive|Meuse-Argonne]]. Initially enjoying numerical odds of eight to one, this offensive eventually engaged 35 or 40 of the 190 or so German divisions on the Western Front, although to put this in perspective, around half the German divisions were engaged on the [[British Expeditionary Force (World War I)|British Expeditionary Force]] (BEF) sector at the time. [[File:Stars and Stripes first issue.tif|thumb|left|Pershing on the front page of the first issue of ''[[Stars and Stripes (newspaper)|Stars and Stripes]]'', February 8, 1918.]] The offensive was marked by a Pershing failure, specifically his reliance on massed infantry attacks with little artillery support led to high casualty rates in the capturing of three key points. This was despite the AEF facing only second-line German troops after the decision by [[Erich Ludendorff]], the [[German General Staff|German Chief of Staff]], to withdraw to the Hindenburg Line on October 3–and in notable contrast to the simultaneous British breakthrough of the Hindenburg Line in the north. Pershing was subsequently forced to reorganize the AEF with the creation of the Second Army, and to step down as the commander of the First Army.Trask, David F. ''The AEF and Coalition Warmaking, 1917–1918''. University Press of Kansas, 1993, p. 141. When he arrived in Europe, Pershing had openly scorned the slow trench warfare of the previous three years on the Western Front, believing that American soldiers' skill with the rifle would enable them to avoid costly and senseless fighting over a small area of [[no-man's land]]. This was regarded as unrealistic by British and French commanders, and (privately) by a number of Americans such as [[Chief of Staff of the United States Army|Army Chief of Staff]] General [[Tasker H. Bliss|Tasker Bliss]] and even Liggett. Even German generals were negative, with Ludendorff dismissing Pershing's strategic efforts in the Meuse-Argonne offensive by recalling how "the attacks of the youthful American troops broke down with the heaviest losses".Trask, David F. ''The AEF and Coalition Warmaking, 1917–1918''. University Press of Kansas, 1993, p. 142. The AEF had performed well in the relatively open warfare of the Second Battle of the Marne, but the eventual American casualties against German defensive positions in the Argonne (roughly 120,000 American casualties in six weeks, against 35 or 40 German divisions) were not noticeably better than those of the Franco-British [[Battle of the Somme|offensive on the Somme]] two years earlier (600,000 casualties in four and a half months, versus 50 or so German divisions). More ground was gained, but by this stage of the war the [[German Army (German Empire)|German Army]] was in worse shape than in previous years. {{Listen |filename=Pershing - Address from France.ogg |title="Address from France" |description=A speech given from Allied Headquarters, Chaumont, France, 1918 }} Some writerse.g., David F. Trask (1993) have speculated that Pershing's frustration at the slow progress through the Argonne was the cause of two incidents which then ensued. First, he ordered the U.S. First Army to take "the honor" of recapturing [[Sedan, France|Sedan]], site of the [[Battle of Sedan|French defeat in 1870]]; the ensuing confusion (an order was issued that "boundaries were not to be considered binding") exposed American troops to danger not only from the French on their left, but even from one another, as the [[1st Infantry Division (United States)|1st Division]] tacked westward by night across the path of the [[42nd Infantry Division (United States)|42nd Division]] (accounts differ as to whether [[Brigadier general (United States)|Brigadier General]] [[Douglas MacArthur]], then commanding the 84th Brigade of the 42nd Division, was really mistaken for a German officer and arrested). Liggett, who had been away from headquarters the previous day, had to sort out the mess and implement the instructions from the Allied Supreme Command, Marshal Foch, allowing the French to recapture the city; he later recorded that this was the only time during the war in which he lost his temper. Second, Pershing sent an unsolicited letter to the Allied [[Supreme War Council]], demanding that the Germans not be given an armistice and that instead, the Allies should push on and obtain an unconditional surrender.{{cite journal|title=Pershing and the Armistice|author=Lowry, Bullitt|journal=[[The Journal of American History]]|volume=55|number=2|date=September 1968|page=281|url=https://www.jstor.org/pss/1899558}} Although in later years, many, including President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]], felt that Pershing had been correct, at the time, this was a breach of political authority. Pershing narrowly escaped a serious reprimand from Wilson's aide, [[Edward M. House|"Colonel" Edward M. House]], and later apologized.{{Citation needed|date=January 2009}} [[File:Gen Pershing decorating soldiers in Trier c1919.jpg|thumb|right|General Pershing decorating soldiers in Trier, 1919.]] At the time of the [[Armistice of 11 November 1918|Armistice]], another Franco-American offensive was due to start on November 14, thrusting towards [[Metz]] and into [[Lorraine]], to take place simultaneously with further BEF advances through [[Belgium]]. In his memoirs, Pershing claimed that the American breakout from the Argonne at the start of November was the decisive event leading to the [[Germany|German]] acceptance of an armistice, because it made untenable the Antwerp–Meuse line. This is probably an exaggeration; the outbreak of civil unrest and naval mutiny in Germany, the collapse of [[Kingdom of Bulgaria|Bulgaria]], the [[Ottoman Empire]], and particularly [[Austria-Hungary]] following [[Allies of World War I|Allied]] victories in [[Thessaloniki|Salonika]], Syria, and Italy, and the Allied victories on the Western Front were among a series of events in the autumn of 1918 which made it clear that Allied victory was inevitable, and diplomatic inquiries about an armistice had been going on throughout October. President Wilson was keen to tie matters up before the mid-term elections,{{Citation needed|date=June 2009}} and as the other Allies were running low on supplies and manpower,{{cite book |last=Peare |first=Catherine Owens |date=1963 |title=The Woodrow Wilson Story: An Idealist in Politics |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=q9UEAQAAIAAJ&q=%22the+war+in+Europe+at+the+time+that+the+United+States+became+an+associate+of+the+Allies+was+still+at+a+stalemate.+The+Allied+countries+were+reaching+the+exhaustion+of+both+men+and+supplies%22&dq=%22the+war+in+Europe+at+the+time+that+the+United+States+became+an+associate+of+the+Allies+was+still+at+a+stalemate.+The+Allied+countries+were+reaching+the+exhaustion+of+both+men+and+supplies%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj3k6aTw8jJAhXCPD4KHc2VAjMQ6AEIHDAA |location=New York, NY |publisher=Thomas Y. Crowell Co. |page=235 |quote=The war in Europe at the time that the United States became an associate of the Allies was still at a stalemate. The Allied countries were reaching the exhaustion of both men and supplies ...|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160430074304/https://books.google.com/books?id=q9UEAQAAIAAJ&q=%22the+war+in+Europe+at+the+time+that+the+United+States+became+an+associate+of+the+Allies+was+still+at+a+stalemate.+The+Allied+countries+were+reaching+the+exhaustion+of+both+men+and+supplies%22&dq=%22the+war+in+Europe+at+the+time+that+the+United+States+became+an+associate+of+the+Allies+was+still+at+a+stalemate.+The+Allied+countries+were+reaching+the+exhaustion+of+both+men+and+supplies%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj3k6aTw8jJAhXCPD4KHc2VAjMQ6AEIHDAA |archivedate=April 30, 2016 |df=mdy-all }} they followed Wilson's lead.{{Citation needed|date=January 2016}} [[File:Pershing and his General Staff at Headquarters, Chaumont.jpg|thumb|left|Pershing and his General Staff at Headquarters, Chaumont.]] American successes were largely credited to Pershing, and he became the most celebrated American leader of the war. Critics, {{Who|date=June 2009}} however, claimed that Pershing commanded from far behind the lines and was critical of commanders who personally led troops into battle. {{Citation needed|date=June 2009}} MacArthur saw Pershing as a desk soldier, and the relationship between the two men deteriorated by the end of the war. Similar criticism of senior commanders by the younger generation of officers (the future generals of [[World War II]]) was made in the British and other armies, but in fairness to Pershing, although it was not uncommon for brigade commanders to serve near the front and even be killed, the state of communications in World War I made it more practical for senior generals to command from the rear. He controversially ordered his troops to continue fighting after the armistice was signed. This resulted in 3,500 American casualties on the last day of the war, an act which was regarded as murder by several officers under his command.{{cite web|url=http://www.historynet.com/world-war-i-wasted-lives-on-armistice-day.htm|title=World War I: Wasted Lives on Armistice Day|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110515085844/http://www.historynet.com/world-war-i-wasted-lives-on-armistice-day.htm|archivedate=May 15, 2011|df=mdy-all}} The year of 1918 also saw a personal health struggle for Pershing as he was sickened during the [[1918 flu pandemic]], but unlike many who were not so fortunate, Pershing survived.Collier, Richard. ''The Plague of the Spanish Lady: The Influenza Pandemic of 1918–1919'' (Atheneum, 1974) He rode his horse, Kidron, in the Paris victory parade in 1919.{{cite news |author=[[United Press]] |title=Gen. Pershing's Horse Dies |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F01E5DA1339E33BBC4B52DFB6678389659EDE |quote= |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=October 13, 1942 |accessdate=2015-02-07 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150207065157/http://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F01E5DA1339E33BBC4B52DFB6678389659EDE |archivedate=February 7, 2015 |df=mdy-all }}{{clear left}} ==Later career== [[File:GEN Pershing as Chief Of Staff.jpg|thumb|left|160px|Gen. Pershing as Army Chief of Staff]] In 1919, in recognition of his distinguished service during World War I, the [[Congress of the United States|U.S. Congress]] authorized the President to promote Pershing to [[General of the Armies of the United States]], the highest rank possible for any member of the United States armed forces, which was created especially for him.{{cite book |last=McCarl |first=J. R. |date=1925 |title=Decisions of the Comptroller General of the United States |volume=4 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iAEWAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA317&dq=%22john+j+pershing%22+%22promoted%22+%221919%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwis-e3wrMDLAhVI2T4KHY4sC-c4ChDoAQghMAE#v=onepage&q=%22john%20j%20pershing%22%20%22promoted%22%20%221919%22&f=false |location=Washington, DC |publisher=U.S. Government Printing Office |page=317 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160430074942/https://books.google.com/books?id=iAEWAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA317&dq=%22john+j+pershing%22+%22promoted%22+%221919%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwis-e3wrMDLAhVI2T4KHY4sC-c4ChDoAQghMAE#v=onepage&q=%22john%20j%20pershing%22%20%22promoted%22%20%221919%22&f=false |archivedate=April 30, 2016 |df=mdy-all }} (In 1976 Congress authorized President [[Gerald Ford]] to posthumously promote [[George Washington]] to this rank as part of the [[United States Bicentennial]]; Washington previously held the rank of [[General (United States)|General]] in the [[Continental Army]], and wore a three-star insignia;{{cite web |url=https://allthingsliberty.com/2013/09/clarifying-washingtons-rank/ |title=Clarifying Washington's Rank |last=Welsch |first=William |date=September 16, 2013 |website=allthingsliberty.com/ |publisher=Journal of the American Revolution |location=Naperville, IL |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171012201821/https://allthingsliberty.com/2013/09/clarifying-washingtons-rank/ |archivedate=October 12, 2017 |df=mdy-all }} his earlier date of rank in the 1976 promotion ensured that Washington would always be considered the U.S. Army's highest-ranking officer.){{cite book |last=Oliver |first=Raymond |date=2007 |title=Why Is a Colonel Called a Kernal? the Origin of American Ranks and Insignia |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9TcKmEs-I_UC&pg=PA52&dq=%22george+washington%22+%221976%22+%22general+of+the+armies%22+%22promotion%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj6qsWMp8DLAhWC2T4KHasHD-IQ6AEIMzAB#v=onepage&q=%22george%20washington%22%20%221976%22%20%22general%20of%20the%20armies%22%20%22promotion%22&f=false |location=Tucson, AZ |publisher=Fireship Press |page=52 |isbn=978-1-934757-59-8 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160506180933/https://books.google.com/books?id=9TcKmEs-I_UC&pg=PA52&dq=%22george+washington%22+%221976%22+%22general+of+the+armies%22+%22promotion%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj6qsWMp8DLAhWC2T4KHasHD-IQ6AEIMzAB#v=onepage&q=%22george%20washington%22%20%221976%22%20%22general%20of%20the%20armies%22%20%22promotion%22&f=false |archivedate=May 6, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite journal |last=Jenks |first=J. |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DBwTBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA1721 |location=Santa Barbara, CA |publisher=ABC-CLIO |page=1721 |isbn=978-1-85109-964-1}} In 1919, Pershing created the [[Military Order of the World Wars|Military Order of the World War]] as an officer's fraternity for veterans of the First World War, modeled after the [[Military Order of Foreign Wars]]. Both organizations still exist today and welcome new officer members to their ranks. Pershing himself would join the MOFW in 1924. There was a movement to draft Pershing as a candidate for president in 1920; he refused to campaign, but indicated that he "wouldn't decline to serve" if the people wanted him.{{cite book |last=Yockelson |first=Mitchell |date=2016 |title=Forty-Seven Days: How Pershing's Warriors Came of Age to Defeat the German Army in World War I |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cRbZCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA324 |location=New York, NY |publisher=NAL Caliber |page=324 |isbn=978-0-451-46695-2}} Though Pershing was a Republican, many of his party's leaders considered him too closely tied to the policies of the [[United States Democratic Party|Democratic Party's]] President Wilson.{{cite book |last=Fleming |first=Thomas |date=2003 |title=The Illusion Of Victory: America In World War I |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=a6OTYMWr8S4C&pg=RA1-PA51 |location=New York, NY |publisher=Basic Books |page=451 |isbn=978-0-465-02467-4}} Another general, [[Leonard Wood]], was the early [[1920 Republican National Convention|Republican front runner]], but the nomination went to Senator [[Warren G. Harding]] of [[Ohio]], who went on to win the [[U.S. presidential election, 1920|general election]].{{cite book |last1=Hodge |first1=Carl Cavanagh |last2=Nolan |first2=Cathal J. |date=2007 |title=US Presidents and Foreign Policy from 1789 to the Present |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qXeRALIwozgC&pg=PA226&dq=%22leonard+wood%22+%22president%22+%221920%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjIyJms65LKAhVM4SYKHUMWBvgQ6AEISDAI#v=onepage&q=%22leonard%20wood%22%20%22president%22%20%221920%22&f=false |location=Santa Barbara, CA |publisher=ABC-CLIO |page=226 |isbn=978-1-85109-790-6 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160429080201/https://books.google.com/books?id=qXeRALIwozgC&pg=PA226&dq=%22leonard+wood%22+%22president%22+%221920%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjIyJms65LKAhVM4SYKHUMWBvgQ6AEISDAI#v=onepage&q=%22leonard%20wood%22%20%22president%22%20%221920%22&f=false |archivedate=April 29, 2016 |df=mdy-all }} [[File:PershingVictoryMemorialKC crop.jpg|thumb|150px|Bronze relief of Pershing, Kansas City, Missouri, [[Liberty Memorial]]]] In 1921, Pershing became [[Chief of Staff of the United States Army]], serving for three years. He created the [[Pershing Map]], a proposed national network of military and civilian highways. The [[Interstate Highway System]] instituted in 1956 bears considerable resemblance to the Pershing map. On his 64th birthday, September 13, 1924, Pershing retired from active military service. (Army regulations from the late 1860s to the early 1940s required officers to retire on their 64th birthday.) On November 1, 1921, Pershing was in [[Kansas City, Missouri|Kansas City]] to take part in the groundbreaking ceremony for the Liberty Memorial that was being constructed there, (now known as the [[National World War I Museum and Memorial]]). Also present that day were Lieutenant General [[Jules Marie Alphonse Jacques de Dixmude|Baron Jacques]] of Belgium, Admiral of the Fleet [[David Beatty, 1st Earl Beatty|David Beatty]] of Great Britain, Marshal [[Ferdinand Foch]] of France, and General [[Armando Diaz]] of Italy. One of the main speakers was Vice President [[Calvin Coolidge]]. In 1935, bas-reliefs of Pershing, Jacques, Foch and Diaz by sculptor [[Walker Hancock]] were added to the memorial. Pershing also laid the cornerstone of the [[Indiana War Memorial#The War Memorial|World War Memorial]] in Indianapolis on July 4, 1927.{{cite book|last=Price|first=Nelson|title=Indianapolis Then & Now|publisher=Thunder Bay Press|location=San Diego, California|year=2004|pages=102–03|isbn=1-59223-208-6}} On October 2, 1922, amid several hundred officers, many of them combat veterans of World War I, Pershing formally established the [[Reserve Officers Association]] (ROA) as an organization at the Willard Hotel in Washington, D.C. ROA is a 75,000-member, professional association of officers, former officers, and spouses of all the uniformed services of the United States, primarily the Reserve and United States National Guard. It is a congressionally chartered Association that advises the Congress and the President on issues of national security on behalf of all members of the Reserve Component. In 1924 Pershing became a member of the Pennsylvania Society of the [[Sons of the American Revolution]]. He was also an honorary member of the [[Society of the Cincinnati]] and a Veteran Companion of the [[Military Order of Foreign Wars]]. [[File:John Pershing Newsreel 1940.ogv|thumb|left|1940 newsreel]] Pershing served on a committee of the [[Sons of the American Revolution]] to establish and recognize [[Constitution Day (United States)|Constitution Day]] in the United States.{{cite book |editor=Williams, Winston C. |title=Centennial History of the National Society of the Sons of the American Revolution 1889–1989 |publisher=Turner Publishing Company |location=Paducah, Kentucky |page=9 |year=1991 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0SHHzcZnVwEC |accessdate=January 15, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131231132048/http://books.google.com/books?id=0SHHzcZnVwEC |archivedate=December 31, 2013 |df=mdy-all }} During the 1930s, Pershing largely retreated to private life, but returned to the public eye with publication of his memoirs, ''[[My Experiences in the World War]]'', which were awarded the 1932 [[Pulitzer Prize]] for history. He was also an active [[Civitan International|Civitan]] during this time.{{cite book |last= Leonhart |first= James Chancellor |title= The Fabulous Octogenarian |year= 1962 |publisher= Redwood House, Inc. |location= Baltimore Maryland |page= 277 }} In 1940, before and after the [[Fall of France]], Pershing was an outspoken advocate of aid for the [[United Kingdom]] during [[World War II]]. In August 1940, he publicly supported the "[[Destroyers for Bases Agreement]]", whereby the United States sold fifty warships from World War I to the UK in exchange for lengthy leases of land on British possessions for the establishment for military bases. In 1944, with Congress' creation of the five star rank of General of the Army, Pershing was still considered to be the highest-ranking officer of the United States military as his rank was General of the Armies. "In [1799] Congress created for [[George Washington]] the rank of General of the Armies ... General [[Ulysses S. Grant|[Ulysses S.] Grant]] received the title of General of the Army in 1866 . ... Carefully Congress wrote a bill (HR 7594) to revive the rank of General of the Armies for General Pershing alone to hold during his lifetime. The rank would cease to exist upon Pershing's death." Later, when asked if this made Pershing a five-star general, [[United States Secretary of War|Secretary of War]] [[Henry L. Stimson]] commented that it did not, since Pershing never wore more than four stars, but that Pershing was still to be considered senior to the present five-star generals of World War II.{{cite book |last=Cray |first=Ed |date=1990 |title=General of the Army: George C. Marshall, Soldier and Statesman |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Gwq6WvWxe6oC&pg=PA491&dq=%22stimson%22+%22pershing%22+%22five+star%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjO-JmVwbjKAhVEmh4KHYoxBBoQ6AEIHDAA#v=onepage&q=%22stimson%22%20%22pershing%22%20%22five%20star%22&f=false |location=New York, NY |publisher=Cooper Square Press |page=491 |isbn=978-0-8154-1042-3 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160430075028/https://books.google.com/books?id=Gwq6WvWxe6oC&pg=PA491&dq=%22stimson%22+%22pershing%22+%22five+star%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjO-JmVwbjKAhVEmh4KHYoxBBoQ6AEIHDAA#v=onepage&q=%22stimson%22%20%22pershing%22%20%22five%20star%22&f=false |archivedate=April 30, 2016 |df=mdy-all }} In July 1944, Pershing was visited by [[Free French]] leader General [[Charles de Gaulle]]. When Pershing asked after the health of his old friend, Marshal [[Philippe Pétain]] – who had headed the pro-German [[Vichy France|Vichy]] regime until it was dissolved in late 1942 – de Gaulle replied tactfully that, when he last saw him, the Marshal was well.{{cite book |authorlink=Roy Jenkins |first=Roy |last=Jenkins |title=Churchill: A Biography |publisher=Farrar, Straus & Giroux |year=2001 |page=743 |location=New York |isbn=978-0-374-12354-3 |oclc=47658851}}{{clear left}} ==Death== [[File:Pershing's Tombstone.jpg|thumb|200px|Pershing's tombstone at [[Arlington National Cemetery]]]] On July 15, 1948, Pershing died of [[coronary artery disease]] and [[congestive heart failure]] at [[Walter Reed Army Medical Center|Walter Reed General Hospital]] in Washington, D.C., which was his home after 1944. He [[lying in state#United States|lay in state]] at the [[United States Capitol rotunda]]{{cite web|url=https://www.aoc.gov/nations-stage/lying-state-honor |title= "Lying in State or in Honor" |publisher=US Architect of the Capitol (AOC) |accessdate=2018-09-01}} and following a [[state funeral]], he was buried in [[Arlington National Cemetery]],{{Find a Grave|806|John Joseph "Black Jack" Pershing}} near the grave sites of the soldiers he commanded in Europe. ==Family== It was during his initial assignment in the American West that Pershing's mother died.Vandiver, v.1 On March 16, 1906, his father died. Colonel Francis Warren Pershing (1909–1980), John J. Pershing's son, served in the [[Second World War]] as an advisor to the Army Chief of Staff, General [[George C. Marshall]]. After the war he continued with his financial career and founded a stock brokerage firm, [[Pershing LLC|Pershing & Company]]. He was father to two sons, Richard W. Pershing (1942–1968) and John Warren Pershing III (1941–1999). Richard Pershing served as a second lieutenant in the [[502nd Infantry]] and was killed in action on February 17, 1968, in [[Vietnam War|Vietnam]].{{cite web|url=http://www.arlingtoncemetery.net/richardw.htm|title=Arlington Cemetery records: Richard Warren Pershing|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060616173158/http://arlingtoncemetery.net/richardw.htm|archivedate=June 16, 2006|df=mdy-all}} John Pershing III served as a special assistant to former Army Chief of Staff General [[Gordon R. Sullivan]], also attaining the rank of [[colonel]]. He helped shape army and the [[Reserve Officers' Training Corps|ROTC]] programs nationwide. Colonel Pershing died of cardiovascular disease in 1999.{{cite web|url=http://www.arlingtoncemetery.net/jwpershing.htm|title=Arlington Cemetery records: John Warren Pershing III|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070312115707/http://www.arlingtoncemetery.net/jwpershing.htm|archivedate=March 12, 2007|df=mdy-all}} ==Summary of service== ===Dates of rank=== {| class="wikitable" |+ !
